{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Intransitive dice VII â€” aiming for further results","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6345","description":"<p>While Polymath13 has (barring a mistake that we have not noticed) led to an interesting and clearly publishable result, there are some obvious follow-up questions that we would be wrong not to try to answer before finishing the project, especially as some of them seem to be either essentially solved or promisingly close to a solution. The ones I myself have focused on are the following.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Is it true that if two random elements <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" /> are chosen, then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> with very high probability if it has a sum that is significantly larger? (Here &#8220;significantly larger&#8221; should mean larger by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f(n)\" title=\"f(n)\" class=\"latex\" /> for some function <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28n%29%3Do%28n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f(n)=o(n^{3/2})\" title=\"f(n)=o(n^{3/2})\" class=\"latex\" /> &#8212; note that the standard deviation of the sum has order <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{3/2}\" title=\"n^{3/2}\" class=\"latex\" />, so the idea is that this condition should be satisfied one way or the other with probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-o%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-o(1)\" title=\"1-o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />).</li>\n<li>Is it true that the stronger conjecture, which is equivalent (given what we now know) to the statement that for almost all pairs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28A%2CB%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(A,B)\" title=\"(A,B)\" class=\"latex\" /> of random dice, the event that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats a random die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> has almost no correlation with the event that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />, is false?</li>\n<li>Can the proof of the result obtained so far be modified to show a similar result for the multisets model?</li>\n</ol>\n<p>The status of these three questions, as I see it, is that the first is basically solved &#8212; I shall try to justify this claim later in the post, for the second there is a promising approach that will I think lead to a solution &#8212; again I shall try to back up this assertion, and while the third feels as though it shouldn&#8217;t be impossibly difficult, we have so far made very little progress on it, apart from experimental evidence that suggests that all the results should be similar to those for the balanced sequences model. [Added after finishing the post: I may possibly have made significant progress on the third question as a result of writing this post, but I haven&#8217;t checked carefully.]<br />\n<span id=\"more-6345\"></span></p>\n<h3>The strength of a die depends strongly on the sum of its faces.</h3>\n<p>Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" title=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%3D%28b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B=(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" title=\"B=(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> be elements of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" /> chosen uniformly and independently at random. I shall now show that the average of </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5C%7B%28i%2Cj%29%3Aa_i%3Eb_j%5C%7D%7C-%7C%5C%7B%28i%2Cj%29%3Aa_i%3Cb_j%5C%7D%7C-%5Csum_ia_i%2B%5Csum_jb_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;{(i,j):a_i&#62;b_j&#92;}|-|&#92;{(i,j):a_i&#60;b_j&#92;}|-&#92;sum_ia_i+&#92;sum_jb_j\" title=\"|&#92;{(i,j):a_i&#62;b_j&#92;}|-|&#92;{(i,j):a_i&#60;b_j&#92;}|-&#92;sum_ia_i+&#92;sum_jb_j\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>is zero, and that the probability that this quantity differs from its average by substantially more than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n&#92;log n\" title=\"n&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" /> is very small. Since typically the modulus of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i-%5Csum_jb_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i-&#92;sum_jb_j\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i-&#92;sum_jb_j\" class=\"latex\" /> has order <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{3/2}\" title=\"n^{3/2}\" class=\"latex\" />, it follows that whether or not <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> is almost always determined by which has the bigger sum.</p>\n<p>As in the proof of the main theorem, it is convenient to define the functions</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29%3D%7C%5C%7Bi%3Aa_i%3Cj%5C%7D%7C%2B%5Cfrac+12%7C%5C%7Bi%3Aa_i%3Dj%5C%7D%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A(j)=|&#92;{i:a_i&#60;j&#92;}|+&#92;frac 12|&#92;{i:a_i=j&#92;}|\" title=\"f_A(j)=|&#92;{i:a_i&#60;j&#92;}|+&#92;frac 12|&#92;{i:a_i=j&#92;}|\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>and </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29%3Df_A%28j%29-j%2B%5Cfrac+12&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)=f_A(j)-j+&#92;frac 12\" title=\"g_A(j)=f_A(j)-j+&#92;frac 12\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Then </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%3Cb_j%7D%2B%5Cfrac+12%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%3Db_j%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i&#60;b_j}+&#92;frac 12&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i=b_j}\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i&#60;b_j}+&#92;frac 12&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i=b_j}\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>from which it follows that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> if and only if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29%3En%5E2%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)&#62;n^2/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)&#62;n^2/2\" class=\"latex\" />. Note also that</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29%3D%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29-%5Csum_jb_j%2B%5Cfrac+n2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)=&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)-&#92;sum_jb_j+&#92;frac n2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)=&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)-&#92;sum_jb_j+&#92;frac n2\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>If we choose <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> purely at random from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" />, then the expectation of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A(j)\" title=\"f_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j-1%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j-1/2\" title=\"j-1/2\" class=\"latex\" />, and Chernoff&#8217;s bounds imply that the probability that there exists <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7Cg_A%28j%29%7C%3D%7Cf_A%28j%29-j%2B1%2F2%7C%5Cgeq+C%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|g_A(j)|=|f_A(j)-j+1/2|&#92;geq C&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" title=\"|g_A(j)|=|f_A(j)-j+1/2|&#92;geq C&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" /> is, for suitable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-10%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-10}\" title=\"n^{-10}\" class=\"latex\" />. Let us now fix some <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> for which there is no such <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />, but keep <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> as a purely random element of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is a sum of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> independent random variables, each with maximum at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" title=\"C&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" />. The expectation of this sum is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28j%29%3D%5Csum_jf_A%28j%29-n%5E2%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(j)=&#92;sum_jf_A(j)-n^2/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(j)=&#92;sum_jf_A(j)-n^2/2\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>But</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28j%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%3Cj%7D%2B%5Cfrac+12%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%3Dj%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i&#60;j}+&#92;frac 12&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i=j}\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i&#60;j}+&#92;frac 12&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i=j}\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%3D%5Csum_i%28n-a_i%29%2B%5Cfrac+n2%3Dn%5E2%2B%5Cfrac+n2-%5Csum_ia_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"=&#92;sum_i(n-a_i)+&#92;frac n2=n^2+&#92;frac n2-&#92;sum_ia_i\" title=\"=&#92;sum_i(n-a_i)+&#92;frac n2=n^2+&#92;frac n2-&#92;sum_ia_i\" class=\"latex\" />, </p>\n<p>so the expectation of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2-%5Csum_ia_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2-&#92;sum_ia_i\" title=\"n(n+1)/2-&#92;sum_ia_i\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>By standard probabilistic estimates for sums of independent random variables, with probability at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-n%5E%7B-10%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-n^{-10}\" title=\"1-n^{-10}\" class=\"latex\" /> the difference between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> and its expectation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28j%29-n%5E2%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(j)-n^2/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(j)-n^2/2\" class=\"latex\" /> is at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Cn%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Cn&#92;log n\" title=\"Cn&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" />. Writing this out, we have</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29-%5Csum_jb_j%2B%5Cfrac+n2-n%28n%2B1%29%2F2%2B%5Csum_ia_i%7C%5Cleq+Cn%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)-&#92;sum_jb_j+&#92;frac n2-n(n+1)/2+&#92;sum_ia_i|&#92;leq Cn&#92;log n\" title=\"|&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)-&#92;sum_jb_j+&#92;frac n2-n(n+1)/2+&#92;sum_ia_i|&#92;leq Cn&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>which works out as</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29-%5Cfrac+%7Bn%5E2%7D2-%5Csum_jb_j%2B%5Csum_ia_i%7C%5Cleq+Cn%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)-&#92;frac {n^2}2-&#92;sum_jb_j+&#92;sum_ia_i|&#92;leq Cn&#92;log n\" title=\"|&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)-&#92;frac {n^2}2-&#92;sum_jb_j+&#92;sum_ia_i|&#92;leq Cn&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Therefore, if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3E%5Csum_jb_j%2BCn%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i&#62;&#92;sum_jb_j+Cn&#92;log n\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i&#62;&#92;sum_jb_j+Cn&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" />, it follows that with high probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29%3Cn%5E2%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)&#60;n^2/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)&#60;n^2/2\" class=\"latex\" />, which implies that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />, and if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jb_j%3E%5Csum_ia_i%2BCn%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jb_j&#62;&#92;sum_ia_i+Cn&#92;log n\" title=\"&#92;sum_jb_j&#62;&#92;sum_ia_i+Cn&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" />, then with high probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />. But one or other of these two cases almost always happens, since the standard deviations of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jb_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jb_j\" title=\"&#92;sum_jb_j\" class=\"latex\" /> are of order <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{3/2}\" title=\"n^{3/2}\" class=\"latex\" />. So almost always the die that wins is the one with the bigger sum, as claimed. And since &#8220;has a bigger sum than&#8221; is a transitive relation, we get transitivity almost all the time.</p>\n<h3>Why the strong conjecture looks false</h3>\n<p>As I mentioned, the experimental evidence seems to suggest that the strong conjecture is false. But there is also the outline of an argument that points in the same direction. I&#8217;m going to be very sketchy about it, and I don&#8217;t expect all the details to be straightforward. (In particular, it looks to me as though the argument will be harder than the argument in the previous section.) </p>\n<p>The basic idea comes from <a href=\"https://gowers.wordpress.com/2017/07/25/intransitive-dice-vi-sketch-proof-of-the-main-conjecture-for-the-balanced-sequences-model/#comment-187118\">a comment of Thomas Budzinski</a>. It is to base a proof on the following structure.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>With probability bounded away from zero, two random dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> are &#8220;close&#8221;.</li>\n<li>If <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> are two fixed dice that are close to each other and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> is random, then the events &#8220;<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />&#8221; and &#8220;<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />&#8221; are positively correlated.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Here is how I would imagine going about defining &#8220;close&#8221;. First of all, note that the function <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A\" title=\"g_A\" class=\"latex\" /> is somewhat like a random walk that is constrained to start and end at zero. There are results that show that random walks have a positive probability of never deviating very far from the origin &#8212; at most half a standard deviation, say &#8212; so something like the following idea for proving the first step (remaining agnostic for the time being about the precise definition of &#8220;close&#8221;). We choose some fixed positive integer <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"k\" title=\"k\" class=\"latex\" /> and let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%3C%5Cdots%3Cx_k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_1&#60;&#92;dots&#60;x_k\" title=\"x_1&#60;&#92;dots&#60;x_k\" class=\"latex\" /> be integers evenly spread through the interval <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />. Then we argue &#8212; and this should be very straightforward &#8212; that with probability bounded away from zero, the values of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28x_i%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A(x_i)\" title=\"f_A(x_i)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_B%28x_i%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_B(x_i)\" title=\"f_B(x_i)\" class=\"latex\" /> are close to each other, where here I mean that the difference is at most some small (but fixed) fraction of a standard deviation.</p>\n<p>If that holds, it should also be the case, since the intervals between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_%7Bi-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_{i-1}\" title=\"x_{i-1}\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_i\" title=\"x_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are short, that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A\" title=\"f_A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_B\" title=\"f_B\" class=\"latex\" /> are uniformly close with positive probability.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;m not quite sure whether proving the second part would require the local central limit theorem in the paper or whether it would be an easier argument that could just use the fact that since <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A\" title=\"f_A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_B\" title=\"f_B\" class=\"latex\" /> are close, the sums <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_B%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_B(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_B(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> are almost certainly close too. Thomas Budzinski sketches an argument of the first kind, and my guess is that that is indeed needed. But either way, I think it ought to be possible to prove something like this.</p>\n<h3>What about the multisets model?</h3>\n<p>We haven&#8217;t thought about this too hard, but there is a very general approach that looks to me promising. However, it depends on something happening that should be either quite easy to establish or not true, and at the moment I haven&#8217;t worked out which, and as far as I know neither has anyone else.</p>\n<p>The difficulty is that while we still know in the multisets model that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if and only if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29%3Cn%5E2%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)&#60;n^2/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)&#60;n^2/2\" class=\"latex\" /> (since this depends just on the dice and not on the model that is used to generate them randomly), it is less easy to get traction on the sum because it isn&#8217;t obvious how to express it as a sum of independent random variables. </p>\n<p>Of course, we had that difficulty with the balanced-sequences model too, but there we got round the problem by considering purely random sequences <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and conditioning on their sum, having established that certain events held with sufficiently high probability for the conditioning not to stop them holding with high probability.</p>\n<p>But with the multisets model, there isn&#8217;t an obvious way to obtain the distribution over random dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> by choosing <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_1,&#92;dots,b_n\" title=\"b_1,&#92;dots,b_n\" class=\"latex\" /> independently (according to some distribution) and conditioning on some suitable event. (A quick thought here is that it would be enough if we could <em>approximate</em> the distribution of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> in such a way, provided the approximation was good enough. The obvious distribution to take on each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_i\" title=\"b_i\" class=\"latex\" /> is the marginal distribution of that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_i\" title=\"b_i\" class=\"latex\" /> in the multisets model, and the obvious conditioning would then be on the sum, but it is far from clear to me whether that works.)</p>\n<p>A somewhat different approach that I have not got far with myself is to use the standard one-to-one correspondence between increasing sequences of length <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> taken from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" /> and subsets of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B2n-1%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[2n-1]\" title=\"[2n-1]\" class=\"latex\" /> of size <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />. (Given such a sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" title=\"(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> one takes the subset <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7Ba_1%2Ca_2%2B1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%2Bn-1%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{a_1,a_2+1,&#92;dots,a_n+n-1&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{a_1,a_2+1,&#92;dots,a_n+n-1&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />, and given a subset <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%3D%5C%7Bs_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cs_n%5C%7D%5Csubset%5B2n-1%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S=&#92;{s_1,&#92;dots,s_n&#92;}&#92;subset[2n-1]\" title=\"S=&#92;{s_1,&#92;dots,s_n&#92;}&#92;subset[2n-1]\" class=\"latex\" />, where the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"s_i\" title=\"s_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are written in increasing order, one takes the multiset of all values <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s_i-i%2B1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"s_i-i+1\" title=\"s_i-i+1\" class=\"latex\" />, with multiplicity.) Somehow a subset of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B2n-1%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[2n-1]\" title=\"[2n-1]\" class=\"latex\" /> of size <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> feels closer to a bunch of independent random variables. For example, we could model it by choosing each element with probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%2F%282n-1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n/(2n-1)\" title=\"n/(2n-1)\" class=\"latex\" /> and conditioning on the number of elements being exactly <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />, which will happen with non-tiny probability.</p>\n<p>Actually, now that I&#8217;m writing this, I&#8217;m coming to think that I may have accidentally got closer to a solution. The reason is that earlier I was using a holes-and-pegs approach to defining the bijection between multisets and subsets, whereas with this approach, which I had wrongly assumed was essentially the same, there is a nice correspondence between the elements of the multiset and the elements of the set. So I suddenly feel more optimistic that the approach for balanced sequences can be adapted to the multisets model.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;ll end this post on that optimistic note: no doubt it won&#8217;t be long before I run up against some harsh reality.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 12 Aug 2017 13:30:56 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"f8d7dd460cee07ff3033ee31e24c2afd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-709_4d3c0474cfeb94c8.webp","destWidth":12,"destHeight":11,"sourceBytes":178,"destBytes":172,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-709_4d3c0474cfeb94c8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-23-346_ea1814038d50c869.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn22@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-28-033_b051a32e96ccab1c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn55@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-18-102_9c98ffaf9b6c8a2c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28n%29%3Do%28n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn34@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-30-991_7bfeddcdddaaa4ae.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-20-023_385afbdbb3b43a29.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-o%281%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn41@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-30-231_e3827cf6ae546486.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28A%2CB%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn50@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-27-658_66a9e7ab8825fcc6.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-21-111_3c93e6d018418370.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn70@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-27-678_7276d3bb7efa52f3.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%3D%28b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn6@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-29-911_737fcf8b26b6b2b6.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5C%7B%28i%2Cj%29%3Aa_i%3Eb_j%5C%7D%7C-%7C%5C%7B%28i%2Cj%29%3Aa_i%3Cb_j%5C%7D%7C-%5Csum_ia_i%2B%5Csum_jb_j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn91@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-24-539_34a2b247b83689a6.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5Clog+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn62@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-31-093_6173fe31ac2eda12.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i-%5Csum_jb_j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn95@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-19-212_6a4f12c8aa338245.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29%3D%7C%5C%7Bi%3Aa_i%3Cj%5C%7D%7C%2B%5Cfrac+12%7C%5C%7Bi%3Aa_i%3Dj%5C%7D%7C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn44@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-26-287_7698e71ff304aa9c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29%3Df_A%28j%29-j%2B%5Cfrac+12&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn39@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-26-801_395c973d04c50c1c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%3Cb_j%7D%2B%5Cfrac+12%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%3Db_j%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn4@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-22-704_a1100116aeb729b5.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29%3En%5E2%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn87@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-19-113_2ccfe15ee82de169.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29%3D%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29-%5Csum_jb_j%2B%5Cfrac+n2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn5@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-32-045_a6c3c9f1e5d34fa0.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn23@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-24-219_272d13e99d194a8e.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j-1%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-16-084_812732684a0a36fc.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn52@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-23-673_47f134be96b55f4c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7Cg_A%28j%29%7C%3D%7Cf_A%28j%29-j%2B1%2F2%7C%5Cgeq+C%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn80@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-16-089_dcdd95cfd0e1bc01.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-10%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn25@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-28-089_13c34faa5e10105a.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-25-224_a65d6899ba4d6172.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn68@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-22-389_6ab62d296203464e.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28j%29%3D%5Csum_jf_A%28j%29-n%5E2%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn74@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-29-103_3cf0a22c659cf100.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28j%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%3Cj%7D%2B%5Cfrac+12%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%3Dj%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn17@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-28-700_6caa81a459e38d93.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%3D%5Csum_i%28n-a_i%29%2B%5Cfrac+n2%3Dn%5E2%2B%5Cfrac+n2-%5Csum_ia_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn75@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-21-171_bc7558bec60d6e80.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2-%5Csum_ia_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn44@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-19-861_d6585e29c4ad7e71.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-n%5E%7B-10%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn11@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-26-101_28d9e1acabc0204e.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28j%29-n%5E2%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn58@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-18-049_3251044e5ef1817f.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Cn%5Clog+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-16-055_079b19c00c5c0e54.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29-%5Csum_jb_j%2B%5Cfrac+n2-n%28n%2B1%29%2F2%2B%5Csum_ia_i%7C%5Cleq+Cn%5Clog+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn92@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-18-123_65d7b971cd247051.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29-%5Cfrac+%7Bn%5E2%7D2-%5Csum_jb_j%2B%5Csum_ia_i%7C%5Cleq+Cn%5Clog+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn67@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-16-084_57652dcd2b89a855.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3E%5Csum_jb_j%2BCn%5Clog+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-20-985_cb7e08c603c5eafe.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29%3Cn%5E2%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn3@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-17-062_ba946b9a0300e9c1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jb_j%3E%5Csum_ia_i%2BCn%5Clog+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn60@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-27-027_ac139aed5094ab21.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn43@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-17-096_989f50b74d3caae8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jb_j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-20-224_d8964e99b95780ca.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn60@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-19-964_3d8356ba5d52ce15.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=k&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn76@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-21-962_e0c73d8090a7427a.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%3C%5Cdots%3Cx_k&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn76@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-23-479_ecb3e8700a817d6c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn19@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-27-224_d4ff4e1ff3ba1864.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28x_i%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-18-976_7ef5e69ca3b2a8b6.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_B%28x_i%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn52@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-20-365_d8cec43fde347021.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_%7Bi-1%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn29@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-30-178_b67daa547fe1d4e6.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn72@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-17-131_2a02e4af07f30b26.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn47@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-23-653_71440b7e5dd34d24.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_B&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn64@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-21-922_908418c1ecda0727.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28c_j%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn83@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-27-175_02882cf4448f720e.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_B%28c_j%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn13@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-28-679_f8bafd748f8209c8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn67@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-23-852_a46ce567ebdada63.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn64@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-24-358_b1c5b5f3345434fe.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn25@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-30-032_1bb5e933d295d0a4.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B2n-1%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn13@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-30-041_d309711f46f23cfe.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn27@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-23-449_6ad599cd68cee88b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7Ba_1%2Ca_2%2B1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%2Bn-1%5C%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn3@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-20-109_c98a34886358695f.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%3D%5C%7Bs_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cs_n%5C%7D%5Csubset%5B2n-1%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn87@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-25-206_0ad9af1f5de50829.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn32@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-26-705_b42fc4e15df3cd9b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s_i-i%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn69@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-31-837_bbc00a8a03dea2b4.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%2F%282n-1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn100@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-17-127_963ff1d56a008857.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694450},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"A potential new Polymath project: intransitive dice","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6224","description":"<p>A few days ago I received an email from Brian Conrey, who has a suggestion for a possible Polymath project. The problem he wants to see solved is a little different from the problems in most previous projects, in that it is not a well known and long-standing question of acknowledged importance. However, that is not an argument against trying it out, since it is still far from clear what kinds of problems are best suited to the polymathematical approach, and it would be good to get more data. And this problem has other qualities that could make it very suitable indeed. First of all, it is quite new &#8212; it arises from a paper published last year, <a href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1311.6511\">though it appeared on arXiv in 2013</a> &#8212; so we do not yet have a clear idea of how difficult it is, which should give us hope that it may turn out to be doable. Secondly, and more importantly, it is a very attractive question.</p>\n<p>Suppose you have a pair of dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1%2CD_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1,D_2\" title=\"D_1,D_2\" class=\"latex\" /> with different numbers painted on their sides. Let us say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1\" title=\"D_1\" class=\"latex\" /> <em>beats</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_2\" title=\"D_2\" class=\"latex\" /> if, thinking of them as random variables, the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1%3ED_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1&#62;D_2\" title=\"D_1&#62;D_2\" class=\"latex\" /> is greater than the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2%3ED_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_2&#62;D_1\" title=\"D_2&#62;D_1\" class=\"latex\" />. (Here, the rolls are of course independent, and each face on each die comes up with equal probability.) It is a famous fact in elementary probability that this relation is not transitive. That is, you can have three dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1%2CD_2%2CD_3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1,D_2,D_3\" title=\"D_1,D_2,D_3\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1\" title=\"D_1\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_2\" title=\"D_2\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_2\" title=\"D_2\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_3\" title=\"D_3\" class=\"latex\" />, and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_3\" title=\"D_3\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1\" title=\"D_1\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>Brian Conrey, James Gabbard, Katie Grant, Andrew Liu and Kent E. Morrison became curious about this phenomenon and asked the kind of question that comes naturally to an experienced mathematician: to what extent is intransitivity &#8220;abnormal&#8221;? The way they made the question precise is also one that comes naturally to an experienced mathematician: they looked at <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice for large <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> and asked about limiting probabilities. (To give another example where one might do something like this, suppose one asked &#8220;How hard is Sudoku?&#8221; Well, any Sudoku puzzle can be solved in constant time by brute force, but if one generalizes the question to arbitrarily large Sudoku boards, then one can prove that the puzzle is NP-hard to solve, which gives a genuine insight into the usual situation with a <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=9%5Ctimes+9&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"9&#92;times 9\" title=\"9&#92;times 9\" class=\"latex\" /> board.)<br />\n<span id=\"more-6224\"></span></p>\n<p>Let us see how they formulate the question. The &#8220;usual&#8221; <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die can be thought of as a random variable that takes values in the set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />, each with equal probability. A general <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die is one where different probability distributions on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+N&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb N\" title=\"&#92;mathbb N\" class=\"latex\" /> are allowed. There is some choice about which ones to go for, but Conrey et al go for the following natural conditions.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>For each integer <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m\" title=\"m\" class=\"latex\" />, the probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p_m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"p_m\" title=\"p_m\" class=\"latex\" /> that it occurs is a multiple of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/n\" title=\"1/n\" class=\"latex\" />.</li>\n<li>If <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=p_m%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"p_m&#62;0\" title=\"p_m&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" />, then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%5Cleq+m%5Cleq+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1&#92;leq m&#92;leq n\" title=\"1&#92;leq m&#92;leq n\" class=\"latex\" />.</li>\n<li>The expectation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_mmp_m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_mmp_m\" title=\"&#92;sum_mmp_m\" class=\"latex\" /> is the same as it is for the usual die &#8212; namely <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(n+1)/2\" title=\"(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Equivalently, an <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die is a multiset of size <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> with elements in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> and sum <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. For example, (2,2,3,3,5,6) and (1,2,3,3,6,6) are six-sided dice.</p>\n<p>If we have two <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> represented in this way as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_1%2Ca_2%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(a_1,a_2,&#92;dots,a_n)\" title=\"(a_1,a_2,&#92;dots,a_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28b_1%2Cb_2%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(b_1,b_2,&#92;dots,b_n)\" title=\"(b_1,b_2,&#92;dots,b_n)\" class=\"latex\" />, then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if the number of pairs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_i%2Cb_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(a_i,b_j)\" title=\"(a_i,b_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Eb_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i&#62;b_j\" title=\"a_i&#62;b_j\" class=\"latex\" /> exceeds the number of pairs with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Cb_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i&#60;b_j\" title=\"a_i&#60;b_j\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>The question can be formulated a little over-precisely as follows.</p>\n<p><strong>Question.</strong> <em>Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> be three <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice chosen uniformly at random. What is the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> if you are given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />?</em></p>\n<p>I say &#8220;over-precisely&#8221; because there isn&#8217;t a serious hope of finding an exact formula for this conditional probability. However, it is certainly reasonable to ask about the limiting behaviour as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> tends to infinity.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s important to be clear what &#8220;uniformly at random&#8221; means in the question above. The authors consider two <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice to be the same if the probability distributions are the same, so in the sequence representation a random die is a random non-decreasing sequence of integers from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> that add up to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> &#8212; the important word there being &#8220;non-decreasing&#8221;. Another way of saying this is that, as indicated above, the distribution is uniform over multisets (with the usual notion of equality) rather than sequences.</p>\n<p>What makes the question particularly nice is that there is strong evidence for what the answer ought to be, and the apparent answer is, at least initially, quite surprising. The authors make the following conjecture.</p>\n<p><strong>Conjecture.</strong> <em>Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> be three <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice chosen uniformly at random. Then the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> if you are given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> tends to 1/2 as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> tends to infinity.</em></p>\n<p>This is saying that if you know that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />, you basically have no information about whether <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>They back up this conjecture with some experimental evidence. When <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D6&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n=6\" title=\"n=6\" class=\"latex\" />, there turn out to be 4417 triples of dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28A%2CB%2CC%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(A,B,C)\" title=\"(A,B,C)\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />. For 930 of these triples, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> were tied, for 1756, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beat <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />, and for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1731&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1731\" title=\"1731\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> beat <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>It seems obvious that as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> tends to infinity, the probability that two random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice are tied tends to zero. Somewhat surprisingly, that is not known, and is also conjectured in the paper. It might make a good first target. </p>\n<p>The reason these problems are hard is at least in part that the uniform distribution over non-decreasing sequences of length <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> with entries in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{1,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{1,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> that add up to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> is hard to understand. In the light of that, it is tempting to formulate the original question &#8212; just how abnormal is transitivity? &#8212; using a different, more tractable distribution. However, experimental evidence presented by the authors in their paper indicates that the problem is quite sensitive to the distribution one chooses, so it is not completely obvious that a good reformulation of this kind exists. But it might still be worth thinking about.</p>\n<p>Assuming that the conjecture is true, I would imagine that the heuristic reason for its being true is that for large <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />, two random dice will typically be &#8220;close&#8221; in the sense that although one beats the other, it does not do so by very much, and therefore we do not get significant information about what it looks like just from knowing that it beats the other one. </p>\n<p>That sounds a bit vague, so let me give an analogy. Suppose we choose random unit vectors <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2Cv%2Cw&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"u,v,w\" title=\"u,v,w\" class=\"latex\" /> in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb R^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb R^2\" class=\"latex\" /> and are given the additional information that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+u%2Cv%5Crangle%5Cgeq+0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle u,v&#92;rangle&#92;geq 0\" title=\"&#92;langle u,v&#92;rangle&#92;geq 0\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+v%2Cw%5Crangle%5Cgeq+0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle v,w&#92;rangle&#92;geq 0\" title=\"&#92;langle v,w&#92;rangle&#92;geq 0\" class=\"latex\" />. What is the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+u%2Cw%5Crangle%5Cgeq+0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle u,w&#92;rangle&#92;geq 0\" title=\"&#92;langle u,w&#92;rangle&#92;geq 0\" class=\"latex\" />? This is a simple exercise, and, unless I&#8217;ve messed up, the answer is 3/4. That is, knowing that in some sense <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"u\" title=\"u\" class=\"latex\" /> is close to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"v\" title=\"v\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"v\" title=\"v\" class=\"latex\" /> is close to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=w&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"w\" title=\"w\" class=\"latex\" /> makes it more likely that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"u\" title=\"u\" class=\"latex\" /> is close to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=w&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"w\" title=\"w\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>But now let&#8217;s choose our random vectors from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb R^n\" title=\"&#92;mathbb R^n\" class=\"latex\" />. The picture changes significantly. For fixed <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"u\" title=\"u\" class=\"latex\" />, the concentration of measure phenomenon tells us that for almost all <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"v\" title=\"v\" class=\"latex\" /> the inner product <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+u%2Cv%5Crangle&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle u,v&#92;rangle\" title=\"&#92;langle u,v&#92;rangle\" class=\"latex\" /> is close to zero, so we can think of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"u\" title=\"u\" class=\"latex\" /> as the North Pole and the unit sphere as being almost all contained in a thin strip around the equator. And if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"v\" title=\"v\" class=\"latex\" /> happens to be just in the northern hemisphere &#8212; well, it could just as easily have landed in the southern hemisphere. After a change of basis, we can assume that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%3De_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"u=e_1\" title=\"u=e_1\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"v\" title=\"v\" class=\"latex\" /> is very close to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e_2\" title=\"e_2\" class=\"latex\" />. So when we choose a third vector <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=w&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"w\" title=\"w\" class=\"latex\" />, we are asking whether the sign of its second coordinate is correlated with the sign of its first. And the answer is no &#8212; or rather, yes but only very weakly.</p>\n<p>One can pursue that thought and show that the graph where one joins <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"u\" title=\"u\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=v&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"v\" title=\"v\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+u%2Cv%5Crangle%5Cgeq+0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle u,v&#92;rangle&#92;geq 0\" title=\"&#92;langle u,v&#92;rangle&#92;geq 0\" class=\"latex\" /> is, for large <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />, quasirandom, which means, roughly speaking, that it has several equivalent properties that are shared by almost all random graphs. (For a more detailed description, Googling &#8220;quasirandom graphs&#8221; produces lots of hits.) </p>\n<p>For the problem of Conrey et al, the combinatorial object being examined is not a graph but a <em>tournament</em>: that is, a complete graph with orientations on each of its edges. (The vertices are dice, and we draw an arrow from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1\" title=\"D_1\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_2\" title=\"D_2\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1\" title=\"D_1\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_2\" title=\"D_2\" class=\"latex\" />. Strictly speaking this is not a tournament, because of ties, but I am assuming that ties are rare enough for this to make no significant difference to the discussion that follows.) It is natural to speculate that the main conjecture is a consequence of a much more general statement, namely that this tournament is quasirandom in some suitable sense. In their paper, the authors do indeed make this speculation (it appears there as Conjecture 4). </p>\n<p>It turns out that <a href=\"http://www.math.ucsd.edu/~ronspubs/91_03_quasi_tournaments.pdf\">there is a theory of quasirandom tournaments</a>, due to Fan Chung and Ron Graham. Chung and Graham showed that a number of properties that a tournament can have are asymptotically equivalent. It is possible that one of the properties they identified could be of use in proving the conjecture described in the previous paragraph, which, in the light of the Chung-Graham paper, is exactly saying that the tournament is quasirandom. I had hoped that there might be an analogue for tournaments of the spectral characterization of quasirandom graphs (which says that a graph is quasirandom if its second largest eigenvalue is small), since that could give a significantly new angle on the problem, but there is no such characterization in Chung and Graham&#8217;s list of properties. Perhaps it is worth looking for something of this kind.</p>\n<p>Here, once again, is a link to <a href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1311.6511\">the paper where the conjectures about dice are set out, and more detail is given</a>. If there is enough appetite for a Polymath project on this problem, I am happy to host it on this blog. All I mean by this is that I am happy for the posts and comments to appear here &#8212; at this stage I am not sure what level of involvement I would expect to have with the project itself, but I shall certainly follow the discussion to start with and I hope I&#8217;ll be able to make useful contributions.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 28 Apr 2017 13:39:14 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1%2CD_2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"04939d317e865cbf2b37b83d127eba42","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn1@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-625_549974f85076709f.webp","destWidth":46,"destHeight":15,"sourceBytes":336,"destBytes":436,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1%2CD_2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn1@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-625_549974f85076709f.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-19-029_9e7321bbf37f498f.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn99@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-16-084_aa76c4a8027f1966.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1%3ED_2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn69@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-32-390_24a69d662eaebafd.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2%3ED_1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn55@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-23-696_54070b8c0a250828.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1%2CD_2%2CD_3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn45@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-28-929_c3efca1b62a530ae.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-22-294_a94b7d0a96f077af.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=9%5Ctimes+9&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn46@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-27-591_be882239f5f888b7.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/ _n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn52@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-18-039_c46996caaf5446db.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28b_1%2Cb_2%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn84@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-25-215_1597009f0d4a6be1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_i%2Cb_j%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn24@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-26-133_c8e90648e3648a6a.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Eb_j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn57@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-31-042_ec1ef855134253a1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Cb_j&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn66@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-28-994_8cb9bf7b8afd3175.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-21-111_3c93e6d018418370.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D6&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-16-975_5e19da1737435837.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28A%2CB%2CC%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn61@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-31-569_791b86c520745b1d.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1731&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn95@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-26-459_07410c9c8d6f3499.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn33@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-28-139_3db641592346eb0b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2Cv%2Cw&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn59@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-26-268_a52e296280df6050.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn3@202
