07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Advances in Combinatorics fully launched","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6456","description":"<p>It&#8217;s taken longer than we originally intended, but I am very happy to report that <a href=\"https://www.advancesincombinatorics.com/\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Advances in Combinatorics</a>, a new arXiv overlay journal that is run along similar lines to <a href=\"https://discreteanalysisjournal.com/\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">Discrete Analysis</a>, has just published its first five articles, with plenty more in the pipeline.</p>\n<p>I am excited by the business model of the journal, which is that its very small running costs (like Discrete Analysis, it uses <a href=\"https://scholasticahq.com/\" rel=\"noopener\" target=\"_blank\">the Scholastica platform</a>, which charges $10 per submission, as well as a fixed annual charge of $250, and there are a few other costs such as archiving articles with CLOCKSS and having DOIs) are being met, for the next five years in the first instance, by the library of Queens University in Kingston Ontario, who are also providing us with very useful administrative support. My dream would be for other libraries to have the foresight to support similar ventures, since the potential for savings if the stranglehold of the big commercial publishers is broken is huge. I do not underestimate the obstacles, but for a long time I have felt that what we are waiting for is a tipping point, and even quite a small venture can in principle have a significant effect on when that tipping point occurs.</p>\n<p>The aim of Advances in Combinatorics is to be a top specialist combinatorics journal. Information about the editorial board, the submission process, and of course the articles themselves, can all be found on the website. Like Discrete Analysis, the journal has Editorial Introductions to each article, with the aim of making the webpage informative and fun to browse. We will be grateful for any feedback, and even more grateful for support in the form of excellent combinatorics papers while we are still getting established.</p>\n<p>A final remark is that although I have reached the limit of the number of journals of this type that I can be closely involved in, I would be delighted to hear from anybody who thinks that they can put together a high-quality editorial board in an area that does not have a suitable journal for people who want to publish good papers without supporting the big commercial publishers. I know people who can offer advice about suitable platforms, funding, and similar matters. It would be great if free-to-read free-to-publish journals could cover all of mathematics, but we are still a long way from that at the moment.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 30 Oct 2019 16:36:55 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"c3d4a47070433a3d389c2f8cbb0bd5c0","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694447},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Intransitive dice IV: first problem more or less solved?","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6269","description":"<p>I hope, but am not yet sure, that this post is a counterexample to <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betteridge%27s_law_of_headlines\">Betteridge&#8217;s law of headlines</a>. To back up that hope, let me sketch an argument that has arisen from the discussion so far, which appears to get us close to showing that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2CB&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A,B\" title=\"A,B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> are three <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice chosen independently at random from the sequences model (I will recap some of these definitions in a moment), then the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2F2%2Bo%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/2+o(1)\" title=\"1/2+o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />. Loosely speaking, the information that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> tells you nothing about how likely <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is to beat <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />. Having given the argument, I will try to isolate a statement that looks plausible, not impossible to prove, and sufficient to finish off the argument.</p>\n<h3>Basic definitions</h3>\n<p>An <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />&#8211;<em>sided die</em> in the sequence model is a sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" title=\"(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> of elements of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%3D%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]=&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"[n]=&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />, or equivalently such that the average value of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(n+1)/2\" title=\"(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />, which is of course the average value of a random element of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" />. A <em>random</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die in this model is simply an <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die chosen uniformly at random from the set of all such dice.</p>\n<p>Given <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" title=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%3D%28b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B=(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" title=\"B=(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" class=\"latex\" />, we say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> <em>beats</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5C%7B%28i%2Cj%29%3Aa_i%3Eb_j%5C%7D%7C%3E%7C%5C%7B%28i%2Cj%29%3Aa_i%3Cb_j%5C%7D%7C.&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;{(i,j):a_i&#62;b_j&#92;}|&#62;|&#92;{(i,j):a_i&#60;b_j&#92;}|.\" title=\"|&#92;{(i,j):a_i&#62;b_j&#92;}|&#62;|&#92;{(i,j):a_i&#60;b_j&#92;}|.\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>If the two sets above have equal size, then we say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> <em>ties with</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6269\"></span></p>\n<h3>A first reduction</h3>\n<p>When looking at this problem, it is natural to think about the following directed graph: the vertex set is the set of all <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice and we put an arrow from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>We believe (and even believe we can prove) that ties are rare. Assuming that to be the case, then the conjecture above is equivalent to the statement that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2CB%2CC&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A,B,C\" title=\"A,B,C\" class=\"latex\" /> are three vertices chosen independently at random in this graph, then the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=ABC&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"ABC\" title=\"ABC\" class=\"latex\" /> is a directed cycle is what you expect for a random tournament, namely 1/8.</p>\n<p>One can also make a more general conjecture, namely that the entire (almost) tournament is quasirandom in a sense defined by Chung and Graham, which turns out to be equivalent to the statement that for almost all pairs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28A%2CB%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(A,B)\" title=\"(A,B)\" class=\"latex\" /> of dice, the four possible pairs of truth values for the pair of statements</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(A\" title=\"(A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%2C+B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C, B\" title=\"C, B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C)\" title=\"C)\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>each occur with probability approximately 1/4. If this is true, then given <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"k\" title=\"k\" class=\"latex\" /> random dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1%2C%5Cdots%2CA_k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_1,&#92;dots,A_k\" title=\"A_1,&#92;dots,A_k\" class=\"latex\" />, all the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5E%7B%5Cbinom+k2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"2^{&#92;binom k2}\" title=\"2^{&#92;binom k2}\" class=\"latex\" /> possibilities for which <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_i\" title=\"A_i\" class=\"latex\" /> beat which <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_j\" title=\"A_j\" class=\"latex\" /> have probability approximately <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5E%7B-%5Cbinom+k2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"2^{-&#92;binom k2}\" title=\"2^{-&#92;binom k2}\" class=\"latex\" />. This would imply, for example, that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1%2C%5Cdots%2CA_k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_1,&#92;dots,A_k\" title=\"A_1,&#92;dots,A_k\" class=\"latex\" /> are independent random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice, then the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_1\" title=\"A_1\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_k\" title=\"A_k\" class=\"latex\" /> given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_i\" title=\"A_i\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_j\" title=\"A_j\" class=\"latex\" /> for all other pairs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28i%2Cj%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(i,j)\" title=\"(i,j)\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i%3Cj&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i&#60;j\" title=\"i&#60;j\" class=\"latex\" /> is still <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2F2%2Bo%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/2+o(1)\" title=\"1/2+o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>Several of us have done computer experiments to test these conjectures, and it looks as though the first one is true and the second one false. A further reason to be suspicious of the stronger conjecture is that a natural approach to prove it appears to be morally equivalent to a relationship between the correlations of certain random variables that doesn&#8217;t seem to have any heuristic justification or to fit with experimental evidence. So although we don&#8217;t have a disproof of the stronger conjecture (I think it would be very interesting to find one), it doesn&#8217;t seem like a good idea to spend a lot of effort trying to prove it, unless we can somehow explain away the evidence that appears to be stacking up against it.</p>\n<p>The first conjecture turns out to be equivalent to a statement that doesn&#8217;t mention transitivity. The very quick proof I&#8217;ll give here <a href=\"https://gowers.wordpress.com/2017/05/19/intransitive-dice-iii/#comment-170228\">was supplied by Luke Pebody</a>. Suppose we have a tournament (that is, a complete graph with each edge directed in one of the two possible directions) and write <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=d_%2B%28x%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"d_+(x)\" title=\"d_+(x)\" class=\"latex\" /> for the out-degree of a vertex <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> (that is, the number of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" /> such that there is an arrow from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" />) and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=d_-%28x%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"d_-(x)\" title=\"d_-(x)\" class=\"latex\" /> for the in-degree. Then let us count the number of ordered triples <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x%2Cy%2Cz%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x,y,z)\" title=\"(x,y,z)\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5Cto+y%5Cto+z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x&#92;to y&#92;to z\" title=\"x&#92;to y&#92;to z\" class=\"latex\" />. Any directed triangle <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=xyz&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"xyz\" title=\"xyz\" class=\"latex\" /> in the tournament will give rise to three such triples, namely <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x%2Cy%2Cz%29%2C+%28y%2Cz%2Cx%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x,y,z), (y,z,x)\" title=\"(x,y,z), (y,z,x)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28z%2Cx%2Cy%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(z,x,y)\" title=\"(z,x,y)\" class=\"latex\" />. And any other triangle will give rise to just one: for example, if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5Cto+y%2C+x%5Cto+z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x&#92;to y, x&#92;to z\" title=\"x&#92;to y, x&#92;to z\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5Cto+z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y&#92;to z\" title=\"y&#92;to z\" class=\"latex\" /> we get just the triple <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x%2Cy%2Cz%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x,y,z)\" title=\"(x,y,z)\" class=\"latex\" />. So the number of ordered triples <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x%2Cy%2Cz%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x,y,z)\" title=\"(x,y,z)\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5Cto+y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x&#92;to y\" title=\"x&#92;to y\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5Cto+z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y&#92;to z\" title=\"y&#92;to z\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbinom+n3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;binom n3\" title=\"&#92;binom n3\" class=\"latex\" /> plus twice the number of directed triangles. Note that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbinom+n3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;binom n3\" title=\"&#92;binom n3\" class=\"latex\" /> is approximately <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E3%2F6&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^3/6\" title=\"n^3/6\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>But the number of these ordered triples is also <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_yd_%2B%28y%29d_-%28y%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_yd_+(y)d_-(y)\" title=\"&#92;sum_yd_+(y)d_-(y)\" class=\"latex\" />. If almost all in-degrees and almost all out-degrees are roughly <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n/2\" title=\"n/2\" class=\"latex\" />, then this is approximately <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E3%2F4&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^3/4\" title=\"n^3/4\" class=\"latex\" />, which means that the number of directed triangles is approximately <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28n%5E3%2F4-n%5E3%2F6%29%2F2%5Capprox%5Cbinom+n3%2F4&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(n^3/4-n^3/6)/2&#92;approx&#92;binom n3/4\" title=\"(n^3/4-n^3/6)/2&#92;approx&#92;binom n3/4\" class=\"latex\" />. That is, in this case, the probability that three dice form an intransitive triple is approximately 1/4, as we are hoping from the conjecture. If on the other hand several in-degrees fail to be roughly <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n/2\" title=\"n/2\" class=\"latex\" />, then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_yd_%2B%28y%29d_-%28y%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_yd_+(y)d_-(y)\" title=\"&#92;sum_yd_+(y)d_-(y)\" class=\"latex\" /> is substantially lower than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E3%2F4&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^3/4\" title=\"n^3/4\" class=\"latex\" /> and we get a noticeably smaller proportion of intransitive triples.</p>\n<p>Thus, the weaker conjecture is equivalent to the statement that almost every die beats approximately half the other dice.</p>\n<h3>Why should a &#8220;typical&#8221; die beat approximately half the other dice?</h3>\n<p>The answer to this is fairly simple, heuristically at least. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> be an arbitrary die. For <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%3D1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j=1,2,&#92;dots,n\" title=\"j=1,2,&#92;dots,n\" class=\"latex\" /> define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be the number of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%5Cleq+j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i&#92;leq j\" title=\"a_i&#92;leq j\" class=\"latex\" /> and define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)\" title=\"h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29-j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)-j\" title=\"g_A(j)-j\" class=\"latex\" />. Then </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28j%29%3D%5Csum_j%5Csum_i%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%5Cleq+j%5D%7D%3D%5Csum_i%28n-a_i%2B1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(j)=&#92;sum_j&#92;sum_i&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq j]}=&#92;sum_i(n-a_i+1)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(j)=&#92;sum_j&#92;sum_i&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq j]}=&#92;sum_i(n-a_i+1)\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%3Dn%28n%2B1%29-%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"=n(n+1)-&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"=n(n+1)-&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>from which it follows that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jh_A%28j%29%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(j)=0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(j)=0\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>We also have that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> is another die, then </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jh_A%28b_j%29%3D%5Csum_j%28%5Csum_i%5Cmathbf+1_%7Ba_i%5Cleq+b_j%7D-b_j%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%5Cleq+b_j%5D%7D-n%28n%2B1%29%2F2.&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(b_j)=&#92;sum_j(&#92;sum_i&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i&#92;leq b_j}-b_j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq b_j]}-n(n+1)/2.\" title=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(b_j)=&#92;sum_j(&#92;sum_i&#92;mathbf 1_{a_i&#92;leq b_j}-b_j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq b_j]}-n(n+1)/2.\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>If we make the simplifying assumption that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Db_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i=b_j\" title=\"a_i=b_j\" class=\"latex\" /> sufficiently infrequently to make no real difference to what is going on (which is not problematic, as a slightly more complicated but still fairly simple function can be used instead of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" /> to avoid this problem), then we find that to a reasonable approximation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> if and only if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jh_A%28b_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(b_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(b_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is positive.</p>\n<p>So what we would like to prove is that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_1,&#92;dots,b_n\" title=\"b_1,&#92;dots,b_n\" class=\"latex\" /> are chosen independently at random from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" />, then </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5CBigl%5B%5Csum_jh_A%28b_j%29%3E0%5CBigm%7C%5Csum_jb_j%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2%5CBigr%5D%5Capprox+1%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P&#92;Bigl[&#92;sum_jh_A(b_j)&#62;0&#92;Bigm|&#92;sum_jb_j=n(n+1)/2&#92;Bigr]&#92;approx 1/2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P&#92;Bigl[&#92;sum_jh_A(b_j)&#62;0&#92;Bigm|&#92;sum_jb_j=n(n+1)/2&#92;Bigr]&#92;approx 1/2\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>We are therefore led to consider the random variable</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29%3D%28%5Csum_jh_A%28b_j%29%2C%5Csum_j%28b_j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)=(&#92;sum_jh_A(b_j),&#92;sum_j(b_j-(n+1)/2))\" title=\"(X,Y)=(&#92;sum_jh_A(b_j),&#92;sum_j(b_j-(n+1)/2))\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>where now <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%3D%28b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B=(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" title=\"B=(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> is chosen uniformly at random from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" /> without any condition on the sum. To write this in a more transparent way, let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> be the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28h_A%28x%29%2C+x-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(h_A(x), x-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"(h_A(x), x-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" />, where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> is chosen uniformly at random from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" />. Then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> is a sum of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> independent copies of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />. What we are interested in is the distribution we obtain when we condition the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y=0\" title=\"Y=0\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>This should mean that we are in an excellent position, since under appropriate conditions, a lot is known about sums of independent random variables, and it looks very much as though those conditions are satisfied by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />, at least when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is &#8220;typical&#8221;. Indeed, what we would expect, by the central limit theorem, is that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> will approximate a bivariate normal distribution with mean 0 (since both <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=U&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"U\" title=\"U\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"V\" title=\"V\" class=\"latex\" /> have mean zero). But a bivariate normal distribution is centrally symmetric, so we expect the distribution of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BX%7CY%3D0%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[X|Y=0]\" title=\"[X|Y=0]\" class=\"latex\" /> to be approximately centrally symmetric, which would imply what we wanted above, since that is equivalent to the statement that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5BX%3E0%7CY%3D0%5D%5Capprox+1%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[X&#62;0|Y=0]&#92;approx 1/2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[X&#62;0|Y=0]&#92;approx 1/2\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<h3>Why are we not immediately done?</h3>\n<p>How can we make the above argument rigorous? The central limit theorem on its own is not enough, for two reasons. The first is that it does not give us information about the speed of convergence to a normal distribution, whereas we need a sum of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> copies of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be close to normal. The second is that the notion of &#8220;close to normal&#8221; is not precise enough for our purposes: it will allow us to approximate the probability of an event such as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BX%5Cgeq+x%5Cwedge+Y%5Cgeq+y%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[X&#92;geq x&#92;wedge Y&#92;geq y]\" title=\"[X&#92;geq x&#92;wedge Y&#92;geq y]\" class=\"latex\" /> but not of a &#8220;probability zero&#8221; event such as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BX%3E0%5Cwedge+Y%3D0%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[X&#62;0&#92;wedge Y=0]\" title=\"[X&#62;0&#92;wedge Y=0]\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>The first of these difficulties is not too worrying, since plenty of work has been done on the speed of convergence in the central limit theorem. In particular, there is a famous theorem of Berry and Esseen that is often used when this kind of information is needed.</p>\n<p>However, the Berry-Esseen theorem still suffers from the second drawback. To get round that one needs to turn to more precise results still, known as <em>local</em> central limit theorems, often abbreviated to LCLTs. With a local central limit theorem, one can even talk about the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> takes a specific value after a specific number of steps. Roughly speaking, it says (in its 2-dimensional version) that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> is a random variable of mean zero taking values in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" /> and if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> satisfies suitable moment conditions and is not supported in a proper sublattice of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" />, then writing <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> for a sum of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> copies of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />, we have that the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> takes a particular value differs from the &#8220;expected&#8221; probability (given by a suitable Gaussian formula) by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=O%28n%5E%7B-2%7D%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"O(n^{-2})\" title=\"O(n^{-2})\" class=\"latex\" />. (I&#8217;m not 100% sure I&#8217;ve got that right: the theorem in question is Theorem 2.1.1 from <a href=\"http://www.math.uchicago.edu/~lawler/srwbook.pdf\">this book</a>.)</p>\n<p>That looks very close to what we want, but it still falls short. The problem is that the implied constant depends on the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />. A simple proof of this is that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> is not supported in a sublattice but very nearly is &#8212; for example, if the probability that it takes a value outside the sublattice is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5E%7B-2%5En%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"2^{-2^n}\" title=\"2^{-2^n}\" class=\"latex\" /> &#8212; then one will have to add together an extremely large number of copies of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> before the sum ceases to be concentrated in the sublattice.</p>\n<p>So the situation we appear to be in is the following. We have more precise information about the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> than is assumed in the LCLT in the reference above, and we want to use that to obtain an explicit constant in the theorem.</p>\n<p>It could be that out there in the literature is exactly the result we need, which would be nice, but it also seems possible that we will have to prove an appropriate version of the LCLT for ourselves. I&#8217;d prefer the first, but the second wouldn&#8217;t be too disappointing, as the problem is quite appealing and even has something of an additive-combinatorial flavour (since it is about describing an iterated convolution of a subset of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" /> under appropriate assumptions). </p>\n<h3>What properties can we establish about the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />?</h3>\n<p>I said above, with no justification, that we have more precise information about the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />. Let me now try to give the justification.</p>\n<p>First of all, we know everything we could possibly want to know about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"V\" title=\"V\" class=\"latex\" />: it is the uniform distribution on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D+-+%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n] - (n+1)/2\" title=\"[n] - (n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. (In particular, if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> is odd, then it is the uniform distribution on the set of integers in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B-%28n-1%29%2F2%2C+%28n-1%29%2F2%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[-(n-1)/2, (n-1)/2]\" title=\"[-(n-1)/2, (n-1)/2]\" class=\"latex\" />.) </p>\n<p>How about the distribution of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=U&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"U\" title=\"U\" class=\"latex\" />? That question is equivalent to asking about the values taken by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)\" title=\"h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" />, and their multiplicities. There is quite a lot one can say about those. For example, I claim that with high probability (if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is a random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die) <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)\" title=\"h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is never bigger than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" title=\"C&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" />. That is because if we choose a fully random sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29%5Cin%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)&#92;in[n]^n\" title=\"(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)&#92;in[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" />, then the expected number of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%5Cleq+j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i&#92;leq j\" title=\"a_i&#92;leq j\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />, and the probability that this number differs from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> by more than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"t&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cexp%28-ct%5E2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;exp(-ct^2)\" title=\"&#92;exp(-ct^2)\" class=\"latex\" />, by standard probabilistic estimates, so if we set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t%3DC%5Csqrt%7B%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t=C&#92;sqrt{&#92;log n}\" title=\"t=C&#92;sqrt{&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" />, then this is at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-cC%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-cC}\" title=\"n^{-cC}\" class=\"latex\" />, which we can make a lot smaller than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1}\" title=\"n^{-1}\" class=\"latex\" /> by choosing <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> to be, say, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=10c%5E%7B-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"10c^{-1}\" title=\"10c^{-1}\" class=\"latex\" />. (I think <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c\" title=\"c\" class=\"latex\" /> can be taken to be 1/8 if you want me to be more explicit.) Since the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> is proportional to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/n\" title=\"1/n\" class=\"latex\" />, it follows that this conclusion continues to hold even after we condition on that event.</p>\n<p>Another simple observation is that the values taken by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=U&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"U\" title=\"U\" class=\"latex\" /> are not contained in a sublattice (assuming, that is, that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" /> is ever non-zero). That is simply because <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%2B1%29%5Cgeq+h_A%28j%29-1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j+1)&#92;geq h_A(j)-1\" title=\"h_A(j+1)&#92;geq h_A(j)-1\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" /> averages zero.</p>\n<p>A third simple observation is that with probability 1-o(1) <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" /> will take a value of at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n%2F%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n/&#92;log n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n/&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" /> at least somewhere. I&#8217;ll sketch a proof of this. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"k\" title=\"k\" class=\"latex\" /> be around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;log n\" title=\"&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" /> and let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m_1%3C%5Cdots%3Cm_k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m_1&#60;&#92;dots&#60;m_k\" title=\"m_1&#60;&#92;dots&#60;m_k\" class=\"latex\" /> be evenly spaced in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" />, staying away from the end points 1 and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> be a purely random sequence in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" />. Then the standard deviation of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28m_1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(m_1)\" title=\"h_A(m_1)\" class=\"latex\" /> is around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt%7Bn%2F%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt{n/&#92;log n}\" title=\"&#92;sqrt{n/&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" />, so the probability that it is less than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n%2F%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n/&#92;log n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n/&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" /> is around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clog+n%29%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;log n)^{-1/2}\" title=\"(&#92;log n)^{-1/2}\" class=\"latex\" />. The same is true of the conditional probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28m_i%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(m_i)\" title=\"h_A(m_i)\" class=\"latex\" /> is less than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n%2F%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n/&#92;log n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n/&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" /> conditioned on the value of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28m_%7Bi-1%7D%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(m_{i-1})\" title=\"h_A(m_{i-1})\" class=\"latex\" /> (the worst case being when this value is 0). So the probability that this happens for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" /> is at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clog+n%29%5E%7B-%5Clog+n%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;log n)^{-&#92;log n/2}\" title=\"(&#92;log n)^{-&#92;log n/2}\" class=\"latex\" />. This is much smaller than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1}\" title=\"n^{-1}\" class=\"latex\" />, so the conclusion remains valid when we condition on the sum of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> being <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. So the claim follows. Note that because of the previous simple observation, it follows that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" /> must be at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%5Csqrt%7Bn%2F%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c&#92;sqrt{n/&#92;log n}\" title=\"c&#92;sqrt{n/&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" /> in magnitude at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%5Csqrt%7Bn%2F%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c&#92;sqrt{n/&#92;log n}\" title=\"c&#92;sqrt{n/&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" /> times, so up to log factors we get that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jh_A%28j%29%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(j)^2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(j)^2\" class=\"latex\" /> is at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{3/2}\" title=\"n^{3/2}\" class=\"latex\" />. With a bit more effort, it should be possible to push this up to something more like <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^2\" title=\"n^2\" class=\"latex\" />, since one would expect that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)\" title=\"h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> would have rough order of magnitude <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" /> for a positive fraction of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />. Maybe this would be a good subproblem to think about, and ideally not too difficult.</p>\n<p>How about the joint distribution <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />? It seems highly likely that for typical <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> this will not be concentrated in a lattice, and that elementary arguments such as the above can be used to prove this. But let me indicate the kind of situation that we would have to prove is not typical. Suppose that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%3D15&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n=15\" title=\"n=15\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%281%2C1%2C1%2C1%2C1%2C8%2C8%2C8%2C8%2C8%2C15%2C15%2C15%2C15%2C15%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A=(1,1,1,1,1,8,8,8,8,8,15,15,15,15,15)\" title=\"A=(1,1,1,1,1,8,8,8,8,8,15,15,15,15,15)\" class=\"latex\" />. Then as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> runs from 1 to 15 the values taken by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A\" title=\"g_A\" class=\"latex\" /> are <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%285%2C5%2C5%2C5%2C5%2C5%2C5%2C10%2C10%2C10%2C10%2C10%2C10%2C10%2C15%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(5,5,5,5,5,5,5,10,10,10,10,10,10,10,15)\" title=\"(5,5,5,5,5,5,5,10,10,10,10,10,10,10,15)\" class=\"latex\" /> and the values taken by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" /> are <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%284%2C3%2C2%2C1%2C0%2C-1%2C-2%2C2%2C1%2C0%2C-1%2C-2%2C-3%2C-4%2C0%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(4,3,2,1,0,-1,-2,2,1,0,-1,-2,-3,-4,0)\" title=\"(4,3,2,1,0,-1,-2,2,1,0,-1,-2,-3,-4,0)\" class=\"latex\" />. For this example, all the points <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28h_A%28x%29%2Cx%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(h_A(x),x)\" title=\"(h_A(x),x)\" class=\"latex\" /> live in the lattice of points <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28u%2Cv%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(u,v)\" title=\"(u,v)\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=u%2Bv&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"u+v\" title=\"u+v\" class=\"latex\" /> is a multiple of 5. </p>\n<p>This wouldn&#8217;t necessarily be a disaster for us actually, since the LCLT can be restricted to a sublattice and if after conditioning on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y=0\" title=\"Y=0\" class=\"latex\" /> we happen to have that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> is always a multiple of 5, that isn&#8217;t a problem if we still have the central symmetry. But it would probably be nicer to prove that it is an atypical occurrence, so that we don&#8217;t have to worry about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> living inside a sublattice (or even being concentrated in one).</p>\n<p>My guess is that if we were to pursue these kinds of thoughts, we would end up being able to prove a statement that would say something like that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> takes a pretty representative sample of values with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"V\" title=\"V\" class=\"latex\" /> being between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=-%28n-1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"-(n-1)/2\" title=\"-(n-1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28n-1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(n-1)/2\" title=\"(n-1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=U&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"U\" title=\"U\" class=\"latex\" /> being in a range of width around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" />. I would expect, for example, that if we add three or four independent copies of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />, then we will have a distribution that is similar in character to the uniform distribution on a rectangle of width of order of magnitude <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> and height of order of magnitude <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" />. And if that&#8217;s true, then adding <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> of them should give us something very close to normal (in an appropriate discrete sense of the word &#8220;normal&#8221;).</p>\n<h3>What next?</h3>\n<p>There are two obvious tasks here. One is to try to prove as much as we can about the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />. The other is to try to prove a suitable LCLT that is strong enough to give us that the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X&#62;0\" title=\"X&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" /> given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y=0\" title=\"Y=0\" class=\"latex\" /> is approximately 1/2, under suitable assumptions about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" />. And then we have to hope that what we achieve for the first is sufficient for the second.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s possible that the second task can be achieved by simply going through one of the existing proofs of the LCLT and being more careful about the details. But if that&#8217;s the case, then we should spend some time trying to find out whether anyone has done it already, since there wouldn&#8217;t be much point in duplicating that work. I hope I&#8217;ve set out what we want clearly enough for any probabilist who might stumble upon this blog post to be able to point us in the right direction if indeed the result we want is out there somewhere.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 27 May 2017 15:53:07 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2CB&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"510eb41ea665bad6037a9ce260b7751e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn78@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-717_0100e86a311f163d.webp","destWidth":32,"destHeight":14,"sourceBytes":285,"destBytes":310,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2CB&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn78@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-717_0100e86a311f163d.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-21-111_3c93e6d018418370.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-709_4d3c0474cfeb94c8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-23-346_ea1814038d50c869.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2F2%2Bo%281%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn72@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-24-405_59ed3e9a915c98e0.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn27@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-23-449_6ad599cd68cee88b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%3D%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn16@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-16-089_5223b6452ff9b38a.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn99@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-21-171_0bbe9f8890c99a60.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&bg=ffffff&fg=3333
