m/latex.php?latex=X%3E0&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn77@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-29-128_7a0469a877bc64e0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694457},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Quick update on Leicester","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6203","description":"<p>I&#8217;m very happy to report that it seems that some kind of deal seems to have been reached, the details of which I don&#8217;t yet know anything about, which means that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> of the mathematics faculty at Leicester will not after all have to reapply for their positions with only <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n-6&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n-6\" title=\"n-6\" class=\"latex\" /> of those positions on offer. If I find out more, I will add to this post, and if I learn of some kind of announcement online I will provide a link to it. But in the meantime, many thanks to the thousands of people from around the world who signed the petition &#8212; the strength of feeling was impressive and I think it may have made a difference.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 02 Nov 2016 17:44:35 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"ede1faa4c0253fa195a0bfc254d59f2c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","destWidth":10,"destHeight":7,"sourceBytes":165,"destBytes":154,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n-6&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn28@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-25-492_4d17e234a4d652ad.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694455},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Intransitive dice II","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6233","description":"<p>I&#8217;m not getting the feeling that this intransitive-dice problem is taking off as a Polymath project. However, I myself like the problem enough to want to think about it some more. So here&#8217;s a post with some observations and with a few suggested subproblems that shouldn&#8217;t be hard to solve and that should shed light on the main problem. If the rate of comments by people other than me doesn&#8217;t pick up, then I think I&#8217;ll simply conclude that there wasn&#8217;t sufficient interest to run the project. However, if I do that, I have a back-up plan, which is to switch to a more traditional collaboration &#8212; that is, done privately with a small number of people. The one non-traditional aspect of it will be that the people who join the collaboration will select themselves by emailing me and asking to be part of it. And if the problem gets solved, it will be a normal multi-author paper. (There&#8217;s potentially a small problem if someone asks to join in with the collaboration and then contributes very little to it, but we can try to work out some sort of &#8220;deal&#8221; in advance.) </p>\n<p>But I haven&#8217;t got to that point yet: let me see whether a second public post generates any more reaction. </p>\n<p>I&#8217;ll start by collecting a few thoughts that have already been made in comments. And I&#8217;ll start that with some definitions. First of all, I&#8217;m going to change the definition of a die. This is because it probably makes sense to try to prove rigorous results for the simplest model for which they are true, and random multisets are a little bit frightening. But I am told that experiments suggest that the conjectured phenomenon occurs for the following model as well. We define an <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /><em>-sided die</em> to be a sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" title=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> of integers between 1 and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. A random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die is just one of those chosen uniformly from the set of all of them. We say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> <em>beats</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if<br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%3Eb_j%5D%7D%3E%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%3Cb_j%5D%7D.&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#62;b_j]}&#62;&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#60;b_j]}.\" title=\"&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#62;b_j]}&#62;&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#60;b_j]}.\" class=\"latex\" /><br />\nThat is, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if the probability, when you roll the two dice, that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> shows a higher number than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> is greater than the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> shows a higher number than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />. If the two probabilities are equal then we say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> <em>ties with</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6233\"></span></p>\n<p>The main two conjectures are that the probability that two dice tie with each other tends to zero as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> tends to infinity and that the &#8220;beats&#8221; relation is pretty well random. This has a precise meaning, but one manifestation of this randomness is that if you choose three dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2C+B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A, B\" title=\"A, B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> uniformly at random and are given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />, then the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> is, for large <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />, approximately <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/2\" title=\"1/2\" class=\"latex\" />. In other words, transitivity doesn&#8217;t happen any more often than it does for a random tournament. (Recall that a <em>tournament</em> is a complete graph in which every edge is directed.) </p>\n<p>Now let me define a function that helps one think about dice. Given a die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />, define a function <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A\" title=\"f_A\" class=\"latex\" /> on the set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%3D%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]=&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"[n]=&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> by<br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29%3D%5Csum_i%28%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%3Ej%5D%7D-%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%3Cj%5D%7D%29%3D%7C%5C%7Bi%3Aa_i%3Ej%5C%7D%7C-%7C%5C%7Bi%3Aa_i%3Cj%5C%7D%7C.&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A(j)=&#92;sum_i(&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#62;j]}-&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#60;j]})=|&#92;{i:a_i&#62;j&#92;}|-|&#92;{i:a_i&#60;j&#92;}|.\" title=\"f_A(j)=&#92;sum_i(&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#62;j]}-&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#60;j]})=|&#92;{i:a_i&#62;j&#92;}|-|&#92;{i:a_i&#60;j&#92;}|.\" class=\"latex\" /><br />\nThen it follows immediately from the definitions that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28b_j%29%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)&#62;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(b_j)&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" />, which is equivalent to the statement that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_B%28a_j%29%3C0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_B(a_j)&#60;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_B(a_j)&#60;0\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>If the &#8220;beats&#8221; tournament is quasirandom, then we would expect that for almost every pair of dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2CB&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A,B\" title=\"A,B\" class=\"latex\" /> the remaining dice are split into four parts of roughly equal sizes, according to whether they beat <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and whether they beat <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />. So for a typical pair of dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2CB&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A,B\" title=\"A,B\" class=\"latex\" /> we would like to show that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28c_j%29%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(c_j)&#62;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(c_j)&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" /> for roughly half of all dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />, and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_B%28c_j%29%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_B(c_j)&#62;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_B(c_j)&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" /> for roughly half of all dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />, and that these two events have almost no correlation.</p>\n<p>It is critical here that the sums should be fixed. Otherwise, if we are told that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />, the most likely explanation is that the sum of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is a bit bigger than the sum of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />, and then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is significantly more likely to beat <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> is.</p>\n<p>Note that for every die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> we have<br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jf_A%28j%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%28%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%3Ej%5D%7D-%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%3Cj%5D%7D%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}(&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#62;j]}-&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#60;j]})\" title=\"&#92;sum_jf_A(j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}(&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#62;j]}-&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#60;j]})\" class=\"latex\" /><br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%3D%5Csum_i%28%28a_i-1%29-%28n-a_i%29%29%3D2%5Csum_ia_i-n%28n%2B1%29%3D0.&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"=&#92;sum_i((a_i-1)-(n-a_i))=2&#92;sum_ia_i-n(n+1)=0.\" title=\"=&#92;sum_i((a_i-1)-(n-a_i))=2&#92;sum_ia_i-n(n+1)=0.\" class=\"latex\" /><br />\nThat is, every die ties with the die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(1,2,&#92;dots,n)\" title=\"(1,2,&#92;dots,n)\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Now let me modify the functions <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A\" title=\"f_A\" class=\"latex\" /> to make them a bit easier to think about, though not quite as directly related to the &#8220;beats&#8221; relation (though everything can be suitably translated). Define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5C%7Bi%3Aa_i%5Cleq+j%5C%7D%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;{i:a_i&#92;leq j&#92;}|\" title=\"|&#92;{i:a_i&#92;leq j&#92;}|\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)\" title=\"h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29-j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)-j\" title=\"g_A(j)-j\" class=\"latex\" />. Note that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29%3D%28n-g_A%28j%29%29-g_A%28j-1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A(j)=(n-g_A(j))-g_A(j-1)\" title=\"f_A(j)=(n-g_A(j))-g_A(j-1)\" class=\"latex\" /> which would normally be approximately equal to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n-2g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n-2g_A(j)\" title=\"n-2g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>We are therefore interested in sums such as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" />. I would therefore like to get a picture of what a typical sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28g_A%281%29%2C%5Cdots%2Cg_A%28n%29%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(g_A(1),&#92;dots,g_A(n))\" title=\"(g_A(1),&#92;dots,g_A(n))\" class=\"latex\" /> looks like. I&#8217;m pretty sure that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> has mean <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />. I also think it is distributed approximately normally around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />. But I would also like to know about how <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j_1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j_1)\" title=\"g_A(j_1)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j_2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j_2)\" title=\"g_A(j_2)\" class=\"latex\" /> correlate, since this will help us get some idea of the variance of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" />, which, if everything in sight is roughly normal, will pin down the distribution. I&#8217;d also like to know about the covariance of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_B%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_B(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_B(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" />, or similar quantities anyway, but I don&#8217;t want to walk before I can fly.</p>\n<p>Anyhow, I had the good fortune to see Persi Diaconis a couple of days ago, and he assured me that the kind of thing I wanted to understand had been studied thoroughly by probabilists and comes under the name &#8220;constrained limit theorems&#8221;. I&#8217;ve subsequently Googled that phrase and found some fairly old papers written in the typical uncompromising style and level of generality of their day, which leaves me thinking that it may be simpler to work a few things out from scratch. The main purpose of this post is to set out some exercises that have that as their goal.</p>\n<h3>What is the average of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" />?</h3>\n<p>Suppose, then, that we have a random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />. Let&#8217;s begin by asking for a proper proof that the mean of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />. It clearly is if we choose a purely random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-tuple of elements of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" />, but what happens if we constrain the average to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(n+1)/2\" title=\"(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />? </p>\n<p>I don&#8217;t see an easy proof. In fact, I&#8217;m not sure it&#8217;s true, and here&#8217;s why. The average will always be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> if and only if the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1%5Cleq+j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1&#92;leq j\" title=\"a_1&#92;leq j\" class=\"latex\" /> is always equal to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j/n\" title=\"j/n\" class=\"latex\" />, and that is true if and only if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1\" title=\"a_1\" class=\"latex\" /> is uniformly distributed. (The distributions of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are of course identical, but &#8212; equally of course &#8212; not independent.) But do we expect <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1\" title=\"a_1\" class=\"latex\" /> to be uniformly distributed? No we don&#8217;t: if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1%3D%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1=(n+1)/2\" title=\"a_1=(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> that will surely make it easier for the global average to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(n+1)/2\" title=\"(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> than if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1%3Dn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1=n\" title=\"a_1=n\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>However, I would be surprised if it were not at least approximately true. Here is how I would suggest proving it. (I stress that I am <em>not</em> claiming that this is an unknown result, or something that would detain a professional probabilist for more than two minutes &#8212; that is why I used the word &#8220;exercise&#8221; above. But I hope these questions will be useful exercises.)</p>\n<p>The basic problem we want to solve is this: if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1,&#92;dots,a_n\" title=\"a_1,&#92;dots,a_n\" class=\"latex\" /> are chosen independently and uniformly from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" />, then what is the conditional probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1%3Dj&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1=j\" title=\"a_1=j\" class=\"latex\" /> given that the average of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> is exactly <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(n+1)/2\" title=\"(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />?</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s not the aim of this post to give solutions, but I will at least say why I think that the problems aren&#8217;t too hard. In this case, we can use Bayes&#8217;s theorem. Using well-known estimates for sums of independent random variables, we can give good approximations to the probability that the sum is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> and of the probability of that given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1%3Dj&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1=j\" title=\"a_1=j\" class=\"latex\" /> (which is just the probability that the sum of the remaining <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n-1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n-1\" title=\"n-1\" class=\"latex\" /> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" />s is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2-j%5C+&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2-j&#92; \" title=\"n(n+1)/2-j&#92; \" class=\"latex\" />). We also know that the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1%3Dj&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1=j\" title=\"a_1=j\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/n\" title=\"1/n\" class=\"latex\" />. So we have all the information we need. I haven&#8217;t done the calculation, but my guess is that the tendency for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1\" title=\"a_1\" class=\"latex\" /> to be closer to the middle than to the extremes is not very pronounced.</p>\n<p>In fact, here&#8217;s a rough argument for that. If we choose <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> uniformly from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" />, then the variance is about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E2%2F12&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^2/12\" title=\"n^2/12\" class=\"latex\" />. So the variance of the sum of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> (in the fully independent case) is about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E3%2F12&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^3/12\" title=\"n^3/12\" class=\"latex\" />, so the standard deviation is proportional to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{3/2}\" title=\"n^{3/2}\" class=\"latex\" />. But if that&#8217;s the case, then the probability that the sum equals <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2%2Bt&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2+t\" title=\"n(n+1)/2+t\" class=\"latex\" /> is roughly constant for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t%3DO%28n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t=O(n)\" title=\"t=O(n)\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>I think it should be possible to use similar reasoning to prove that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3Do%28%5Csqrt+n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m=o(&#92;sqrt n)\" title=\"m=o(&#92;sqrt n)\" class=\"latex\" />, then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_1,&#92;dots,a_m\" title=\"a_1,&#92;dots,a_m\" class=\"latex\" /> are approximately independent. (Of course, this would apply to any <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m\" title=\"m\" class=\"latex\" /> of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" />, if correct.)</p>\n<h3>How is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> distributed?</h3>\n<p>What is the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%2Bs&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j+s\" title=\"j+s\" class=\"latex\" /> of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />? Again, it seems to me that Bayes&#8217;s theorem and facts about sums of independent random variables are enough for this. We want the probability of the above event given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. By Bayes&#8217;s theorem, we can work this out if we know the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29%3Dj%2Bs&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)=j+s\" title=\"g_A(j)=j+s\" class=\"latex\" />, together with the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> and the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29%3Dj%2Bs&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)=j+s\" title=\"g_A(j)=j+s\" class=\"latex\" />, in both cases when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is chosen fully independently. The last two calculations are simple. The first one isn&#8217;t 100% simple, but it doesn&#8217;t look too bad. We have a sum of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%2Bs&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j+s\" title=\"j+s\" class=\"latex\" /> random variables that are uniform on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bj%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[j]\" title=\"[j]\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n-j-s&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n-j-s\" title=\"n-j-s\" class=\"latex\" /> that are uniform on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7Bj%2B1%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{j+1,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{j+1,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> and we want to know how likely it is that they add up to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. We could do this by conditioning on the possible values of the two sums, which then leaves us with sums of independent variables, and adding up all the results. It looks to me as though that calculation shouldn&#8217;t be too unpleasant. What I would recommend is to do the calculation on the assumption that the distributions are normal (in a suitable discrete sense) with whatever mean and variance they have to have, since that will yield an answer that is almost certainly correct. A rigorous proof can come later, and shouldn&#8217;t be too much harder.</p>\n<p>The answer I expect and hope for is that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is approximately normally distributed with mean <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> and a variance that would come out of the calculations.</p>\n<h3>What is the joint distribution of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j_1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j_1)\" title=\"g_A(j_1)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j_2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j_2)\" title=\"g_A(j_2)\" class=\"latex\" />?</h3>\n<p>This can in principle be done by exactly the same technique, except that now things get one step nastier because we have to condition on the sum of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> that are at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j_1\" title=\"j_1\" class=\"latex\" />, the sum of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> that are between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j_1%2B1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j_1+1\" title=\"j_1+1\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j_2\" title=\"j_2\" class=\"latex\" />, and the sum of the rest. So we end up with a double sum of products of three probabilities at the end instead of a single sum of products of two probabilities. The reason I haven&#8217;t done this is that I am quite busy with other things and the calculation will need a strong stomach. I&#8217;d be very happy if someone else did it. But if not, I will attempt it at some point over the next &#8230; well, I don&#8217;t want to commit myself too strongly, but <em>perhaps</em> the next week or two. At this stage I&#8217;m just interested in the heuristic approach &#8212; assume that probabilities one knows are roughly normal are in fact given by an exact formula of the form <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Ae%5E%7B-%5Clambda+%28x-%5Cmu%29%5E2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Ae^{-&#92;lambda (x-&#92;mu)^2}\" title=\"Ae^{-&#92;lambda (x-&#92;mu)^2}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>For some experimental evidence about this, see <a href=\"https://gowers.wordpress.com/2017/04/28/a-potential-new-polymath-project-intransitive-dice/#comment-169297\">a comment by Ian on the previous post</a>, which links to some nice visualizations. Ian, if you&#8217;re reading this, it would take you about another minute, I&#8217;d have thought, to choose a few random dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and plot the graphs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" />. It would be interesting to see such plots to get an idea of what a typical one looks like: roughly how often does it change sign, for example?</p>\n<h3>What is a heuristic argument for the &#8220;<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />&#8221; tournament being quasirandom?</h3>\n<p>I have much less to say here &#8212; in particular, I don&#8217;t have a satisfactory answer. But I haven&#8217;t spent serious time on it, and I think it should be possible to get one. </p>\n<p>One slight simplification is that we don&#8217;t have to think too hard about whether <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> when we are thinking about the three dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2C+B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A, B\" title=\"A, B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />. As I commented above, the tournament will be quasirandom (I think I&#8217;m right in saying) if for <em>almost every</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> the events &#8220;<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />&#8221; and &#8220;<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />&#8221; have probability roughly 1/2 each and are hardly correlated. </p>\n<p>A good starting point would be the first part. Is it true that almost every die beats approximately half the other dice? This question was also recommended by Bogdan Grechuk in a comment on the previous post. He suggested, as a preliminary question, the question of finding a good sufficient condition on a die for this to be the case. </p>\n<p>That I think is approachable too. Let&#8217;s fix some function <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A\" title=\"g_A\" class=\"latex\" /> without worrying too much about whether it comes from a die (but I have no objection to assuming that it is non-decreasing and that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28n%29%3Dn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(n)=n\" title=\"g_A(n)=n\" class=\"latex\" />, should that be helpful). Under what conditions can we be confident that the sum <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is greater than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> with probability roughly 1/2, where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%3D%28c_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cc_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C=(c_1,&#92;dots,c_n)\" title=\"C=(c_1,&#92;dots,c_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> <em>is</em> a random die?</p>\n<p>Assuming it&#8217;s correct that each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_j\" title=\"c_j\" class=\"latex\" /> is roughly uniform, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is going to average <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" />, which if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is a die will be close to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. But we need to know rather more than that in order to obtain the probability in question. </p>\n<p>But I think the Bayes approach may still work. We&#8217;d like to nail down the distribution of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jc_j%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jc_j=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jc_j=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. So we can look at <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5B%5Csum_jg_A%28c_j%29%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2%2Bt%7C%5Csum_jc_j%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)=n(n+1)/2+t|&#92;sum_jc_j=n(n+1)/2]\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[&#92;sum_jg_A(c_j)=n(n+1)/2+t|&#92;sum_jc_j=n(n+1)/2]\" class=\"latex\" />, where now the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_i\" title=\"c_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are chosen uniformly and independently. Calling that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5BX%7CY%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[X|Y]\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[X|Y]\" class=\"latex\" />, we find that it&#8217;s going to be fairly easy to estimate the probabilities of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" />. However, it doesn&#8217;t seem to be notably easier to calculate <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5BY%7CX%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[Y|X]\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[Y|X]\" class=\"latex\" /> than it is to calculate <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5BX%7CY%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[X|Y]\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[X|Y]\" class=\"latex\" />. But we have made at least one huge gain, which is that now the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_j\" title=\"c_j\" class=\"latex\" /> are independent, so I&#8217;d be very surprised if people don&#8217;t know how to estimate this probability. Indeed, the probability we really want to know is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5BX%5Cwedge+Y%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[X&#92;wedge Y]\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[X&#92;wedge Y]\" class=\"latex\" />. From that all else should follow. And I <em>think</em> that what we&#8217;d like is a nice condition on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A\" title=\"g_A\" class=\"latex\" /> that would tell us that the two events are approximately independent. </p>\n<p>I&#8217;d better stop here, but I hope I will have persuaded at least some people that there&#8217;s some reasonably low-hanging fruit around, at least for the time being.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 12 May 2017 11:04:15 p.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5BY%7CX%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn56@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-16-078_f1ec25117d8cfc46.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5BX%5Cwedge+Y%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-30-978_00040b36a01b3378.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694456},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"The fate of combinatorics at Strathclyde","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6454","description":"<p>I have just received an email from Sergey Kitaev, one of the three combinatorialists at Strathclyde. As in many universities, they belong not to the mathematics department but to the computer science department. Kitaev informs me that the administrators of that department, in their infinite wisdom, have decided that the future of the department is best served by axing discrete mathematics. I won&#8217;t write a long post about this, but instead refer you to <a href=\"https://cameroncounts.wordpress.com/2019/06/19/combinatorics-at-strathclyde/\">a post by Peter Cameron</a> that says everything I would want to say about the decision, and does so extremely cogently. I recommend that you read it if this kind of decision worries you.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 19 Jun 2019 22:07:49 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"ab705eaee42773fd891675a498742297","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694447},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"A quasirandomness implication","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6410","description":"<p>This is a bit of a niche post, since its target audience is people who are familiar with quasirandom graphs and like proofs of an analytic flavour. Very roughly, a quasirandom graph is one that behaves like a random graph of the same density. It turns out that there are many ways that one can interpret the phrase &#8220;behaves like a random graph&#8221; and, less obviously, that they are all in a certain sense equivalent. This realization dates back to seminal papers of Thomason, and of Chung, Graham and Wilson.</p>\n<p>I was lecturing on the topic recently, and proving that certain of the quasirandomness properties all implied each other. In some cases, the proofs are quite a bit easier if you assume that the graph is regular, and in the past I have sometimes made my life easier by dealing just with that case. But that had the unfortunate consequence that when I lectured on Szemer&#233;di&#8217;s regularity lemma, I couldn&#8217;t just say &#8220;Note that the condition on the regular pairs is just saying that they have quasirandomness property <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />&#8221; and have as a consequence all the other quasirandomness properties. So this year I was determined to deal with the general case, and determined to find clean proofs of all the implications. There is one that took me quite a bit of time, but I got there in the end. It is very likely to be out there in the literature somewhere, but I haven&#8217;t found it, so it seems suitable for a blog post. I can be sure of at least one interested reader, which is the future me when I find that I&#8217;ve forgotten the argument (except that actually I have now found quite a conceptual way of expressing it, so it&#8217;s just conceivable that it will stick around in the more accessible part of my long-term memory).<br />\n<span id=\"more-6410\"></span></p>\n<p>The implication in question, which I&#8217;ll state for bipartite graphs, concerns the following two properties. I&#8217;ll state them qualitatively first, and then give more precise versions. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"G\" title=\"G\" class=\"latex\" /> be a bipartite graph of density <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta\" title=\"&#92;delta\" class=\"latex\" /> with (finite) vertex sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p><strong>Property 1.</strong> If <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%5Csubset+X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A&#92;subset X\" title=\"A&#92;subset X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%5Csubset+Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B&#92;subset Y\" title=\"B&#92;subset Y\" class=\"latex\" />, then the number of edges between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> is roughly <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%7CA%7C%7CB%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta|A||B|\" title=\"&#92;delta|A||B|\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p><strong>Property 2.</strong> The number of 4-cycles (or more precisely ordered quadruples <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x_1%2Cy_1%2Cx_2%2Cy_2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x_1,y_1,x_2,y_2)\" title=\"(x_1,y_1,x_2,y_2)\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_iy_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_iy_j\" title=\"x_iy_j\" class=\"latex\" /> is an edge for all four choices of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i%2Cj&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i,j\" title=\"i,j\" class=\"latex\" />) is roughly <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%5E4%7CX%7C%5E2%7CY%7C%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta^4|X|^2|Y|^2\" title=\"&#92;delta^4|X|^2|Y|^2\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>A common way of expressing property 1 is to say that the density of the subgraph induced by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> is approximately <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> as long as the sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> are not too small. However, the following formulation leads to considerably tidier proofs if one wants to use analytic arguments. I think of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"G\" title=\"G\" class=\"latex\" /> as a function, so <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G%28x%2Cy%29%3D1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"G(x,y)=1\" title=\"G(x,y)=1\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=xy&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"xy\" title=\"xy\" class=\"latex\" /> is an edge of the graph and 0 otherwise. Then the condition is that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> has density <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> has density <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" />, then</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Cmathbb+E_%7Bx%2Cy%7DG%28x%2Cy%29A%28x%29B%28y%29-%5Cdelta%5Calpha%5Cbeta%7C%5Cleq+c_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;mathbb E_{x,y}G(x,y)A(x)B(y)-&#92;delta&#92;alpha&#92;beta|&#92;leq c_1\" title=\"|&#92;mathbb E_{x,y}G(x,y)A(x)B(y)-&#92;delta&#92;alpha&#92;beta|&#92;leq c_1\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>This condition is interesting when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_1\" title=\"c_1\" class=\"latex\" /> is small. It might seem more natural to write <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_1%5Calpha%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_1&#92;alpha&#92;beta\" title=\"c_1&#92;alpha&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> on the right-hand side, but then one has to add some condition such as that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%5Cgeq+c_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha,&#92;beta&#92;geq c_1\" title=\"&#92;alpha,&#92;beta&#92;geq c_1\" class=\"latex\" /> in order to obtain a condition that follows from the other conditions. If one simply leaves the right-hand side as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_1\" title=\"c_1\" class=\"latex\" /> (which may depend on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta\" title=\"&#92;delta\" class=\"latex\" />), then one obtains a condition that automatically gives a non-trivial statement when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> are large and a trivial one when they are small.</p>\n<p>As for Property 2, the most natural analytic way of expressing it is the inequality</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%5Cmathop%7B%5Cmathbb+E%7D_%7Bx_1%2Cx_2%5Cin+X%7D%5Cmathop%7B%5Cmathbb+E%7D_%7By_1%2Cy_2%5Cin+Y%7DG%28x_1%2Cy_1%29G%28x_1%2Cy_2%29G%28x_2%2Cy_1%29G%28x_2%2Cy_2%29%5Cleq%5Cdelta%5E4%281%2Bc_2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;displaystyle &#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{x_1,x_2&#92;in X}&#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{y_1,y_2&#92;in Y}G(x_1,y_1)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)G(x_2,y_2)&#92;leq&#92;delta^4(1+c_2)\" title=\"&#92;displaystyle &#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{x_1,x_2&#92;in X}&#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{y_1,y_2&#92;in Y}G(x_1,y_1)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)G(x_2,y_2)&#92;leq&#92;delta^4(1+c_2)\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>An easy Cauchy-Schwarz argument proves a lower bound of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%5E4&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta^4\" title=\"&#92;delta^4\" class=\"latex\" />, so this does indeed imply that the number of labelled 4-cycles is approximately <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%5E4%7CX%7C%5E2%7CY%7C%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta^4|X|^2|Y|^2\" title=\"&#92;delta^4|X|^2|Y|^2\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>The equivalence between the two statements is that if one holds for a sufficiently small <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_i\" title=\"c_i\" class=\"latex\" />, then the other holds for a <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_j\" title=\"c_j\" class=\"latex\" /> that is as small as you want.</p>\n<p>In fact, both implications are significantly easier in the regular case, but I found a satisfactory way of deducing the first from the second a few years ago and won&#8217;t repeat it here, as it requires a few lemmas and some calculation. But it is given as Theorem 5.3 in <a href=\"https://gowers.files.wordpress.com/2014/11/techniques2014notes.pdf\">these notes</a>, and the proof in question can be found by working backwards. (The particular point that is easier in the regular case is Corollary 5.2, because then the function <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g%27&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g&#039;\" title=\"g&#039;\" class=\"latex\" /> mentioned there and in Lemma 5.1 is identically zero.)</p>\n<p>What I want to concentrate on is deducing the second property from the first. Let me first give the proof in the regular case, which is very short and sweet. We do it by proving the contrapositive. So let&#8217;s assume that every vertex in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> has degree <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta+Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta Y\" title=\"&#92;delta Y\" class=\"latex\" />, that every vertex in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" /> has degree <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta+X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta X\" title=\"&#92;delta X\" class=\"latex\" />, and that</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%5Cmathop%7B%5Cmathbb+E%7D_%7Bx_1%2Cx_2%5Cin+X%7D%5Cmathop%7B%5Cmathbb+E%7D_%7By_1%2Cy_2%5Cin+Y%7DG%28x_1%2Cy_1%29G%28x_1%2Cy_2%29G%28x_2%2Cy_1%29G%28x_2%2Cy_2%29%3E%5Cdelta%5E4%281%2Bc_2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;displaystyle &#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{x_1,x_2&#92;in X}&#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{y_1,y_2&#92;in Y}G(x_1,y_1)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)G(x_2,y_2)&#62;&#92;delta^4(1+c_2)\" title=\"&#92;displaystyle &#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{x_1,x_2&#92;in X}&#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{y_1,y_2&#92;in Y}G(x_1,y_1)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)G(x_2,y_2)&#62;&#92;delta^4(1+c_2)\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>Since for each fixed <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_2%2Cy_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_2,y_2\" title=\"x_2,y_2\" class=\"latex\" />, the expectation over <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%2Cy_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_1,y_1\" title=\"x_1,y_1\" class=\"latex\" /> on the left-hand side is zero if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G%28x_2%2Cy_2%29%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"G(x_2,y_2)=0\" title=\"G(x_2,y_2)=0\" class=\"latex\" />, it follows that there exists some choice of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_2%2Cy_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_2,y_2\" title=\"x_2,y_2\" class=\"latex\" /> such that</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%5Cmathop%7B%5Cmathbb+E%7D_%7Bx_1%5Cin+X%7D%5Cmathop%7B%5Cmathbb+E%7D_%7By_1%5Cin+Y%7DG%28x_1%2Cy_1%29G%28x_1%2Cy_2%29G%28x_2%2Cy_1%29%3E%5Cdelta%5E3%281%2Bc_2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;displaystyle &#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{x_1&#92;in X}&#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{y_1&#92;in Y}G(x_1,y_1)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)&#62;&#92;delta^3(1+c_2)\" title=\"&#92;displaystyle &#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{x_1&#92;in X}&#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{y_1&#92;in Y}G(x_1,y_1)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)&#62;&#92;delta^3(1+c_2)\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>We now set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%5C%7Bx%3AG%28x%2Cy_2%29%3D1%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A=&#92;{x:G(x,y_2)=1&#92;}\" title=\"A=&#92;{x:G(x,y_2)=1&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%3D%5C%7By%3AG%28x_2%2Cy%29%3D1%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B=&#92;{y:G(x_2,y)=1&#92;}\" title=\"B=&#92;{y:G(x_2,y)=1&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />. Then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> both have density <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta\" title=\"&#92;delta\" class=\"latex\" /> (by the regularity assumption), and the above inequality tells us that</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E_%7Bx_1%2Cy_1%7DG%28x_1%2Cy_1%29A%28x_1%29B%28y_1%29-%5Cdelta%5E3%3Ec_2%5Cdelta%5E3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb E_{x_1,y_1}G(x_1,y_1)A(x_1)B(y_1)-&#92;delta^3&#62;c_2&#92;delta^3\" title=\"&#92;mathbb E_{x_1,y_1}G(x_1,y_1)A(x_1)B(y_1)-&#92;delta^3&#62;c_2&#92;delta^3\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>so we obtain the desired conclusion with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_1%3Dc_2%5Cdelta%5E3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_1=c_2&#92;delta^3\" title=\"c_1=c_2&#92;delta^3\" class=\"latex\" />. Or to put it another way, if we assume Property 1 with constant <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_1\" title=\"c_1\" class=\"latex\" />, then we obtain Property 2 with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_2%3D%5Cdelta%5E%7B-3%7Dc_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_2=&#92;delta^{-3}c_1\" title=\"c_2=&#92;delta^{-3}c_1\" class=\"latex\" /> (which in practice means that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_1\" title=\"c_1\" class=\"latex\" /> should be small compared with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%5E3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta^3\" title=\"&#92;delta^3\" class=\"latex\" /> in order to obtain a useful inequality from Property 2).</p>\n<p>The difficulty when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"G\" title=\"G\" class=\"latex\" /> is not regular is that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> may have densities larger than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta\" title=\"&#92;delta\" class=\"latex\" />, and then the inequality</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E_%7Bx_1%2Cy_1%7DG%28x_1%2Cy_1%29A%28x_1%29B%28y_1%29-%5Cdelta%5E3%3Ec_2%5Cdelta%5E3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb E_{x_1,y_1}G(x_1,y_1)A(x_1)B(y_1)-&#92;delta^3&#62;c_2&#92;delta^3\" title=\"&#92;mathbb E_{x_1,y_1}G(x_1,y_1)A(x_1)B(y_1)-&#92;delta^3&#62;c_2&#92;delta^3\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>no longer gives us what we need. The way I used to get round this was what I think of as the &#8220;disgusting&#8221; approach, which goes roughly as follows. Suppose that many vertices in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> have degree substantially larger than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%7CY%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta|Y|\" title=\"&#92;delta|Y|\" class=\"latex\" />, and let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> be the set of all such vertices. Then the number of edges between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" /> is too large, and we get the inequality we are looking for (with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%3DY&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B=Y\" title=\"B=Y\" class=\"latex\" />). We can say something similar about vertices in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" />, so either we are done or <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"G\" title=\"G\" class=\"latex\" /> is at least <em>approximately</em> regular, and in particular <em>almost</em> all neighbourhoods are of density not much greater than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta\" title=\"&#92;delta\" class=\"latex\" />. Then one runs an approximate version of the simple averaging argument above, arguing in an ugly way that the contribution to the average from &#8220;bad&#8221; choices <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x_2%2Cy_2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x_2,y_2)\" title=\"(x_2,y_2)\" class=\"latex\" /> is small enough that there must be at least one &#8220;good&#8221; choice.</p>\n<p>To obtain a cleaner proof, I&#8217;ll begin with a non-essential step, but one that I think clarifies what is going on and shows that it&#8217;s not just some calculation that magically gives the desired answer. It is to interpret the quantity</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdisplaystyle+%5Cmathop%7B%5Cmathbb+E%7D_%7Bx_1%2Cx_2%5Cin+X%7D%5Cmathop%7B%5Cmathbb+E%7D_%7By_1%2Cy_2%5Cin+Y%7DG%28x_1%2Cy_1%29G%28x_1%2Cy_2%29G%28x_2%2Cy_1%29G%28x_2%2Cy_2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;displaystyle &#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{x_1,x_2&#92;in X}&#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{y_1,y_2&#92;in Y}G(x_1,y_1)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)G(x_2,y_2)\" title=\"&#92;displaystyle &#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{x_1,x_2&#92;in X}&#92;mathop{&#92;mathbb E}_{y_1,y_2&#92;in Y}G(x_1,y_1)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)G(x_2,y_2)\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>as the probability that the four pairs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_iy_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_iy_j\" title=\"x_iy_j\" class=\"latex\" /> are all edges of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"G\" title=\"G\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%2Cx_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_1,x_2\" title=\"x_1,x_2\" class=\"latex\" /> are chosen independently at random from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y_1%2Cy_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y_1,y_2\" title=\"y_1,y_2\" class=\"latex\" /> are chosen independently at random from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" />. Then our hypothesis is that </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[\" class=\"latex\" />all <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_iy_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_iy_j\" title=\"x_iy_j\" class=\"latex\" /> are edges<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5D-%5Cdelta%5E4%3Ec_2%5Cdelta%5E4&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"]-&#92;delta^4&#62;c_2&#92;delta^4\" title=\"]-&#92;delta^4&#62;c_2&#92;delta^4\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>Let us now split up the left-hand side as follows. It is the sum of</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[\" class=\"latex\" />all <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_iy_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_iy_j\" title=\"x_iy_j\" class=\"latex\" /> are edges<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"]\" title=\"]\" class=\"latex\" /><br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=-%5Cdelta%5Cmathbb+P%5Bx_1y_2%2Cx_2y_1%2Cx_2y_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"-&#92;delta&#92;mathbb P[x_1y_2,x_2y_1,x_2y_2\" title=\"-&#92;delta&#92;mathbb P[x_1y_2,x_2y_1,x_2y_2\" class=\"latex\" /> are edges<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"]\" title=\"]\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>and</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%5Cmathbb+P%5Bx_1y_1%2Cx_1y_2%2Cx_2y_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta&#92;mathbb P[x_1y_1,x_1y_2,x_2y_1\" title=\"&#92;delta&#92;mathbb P[x_1y_1,x_1y_2,x_2y_1\" class=\"latex\" /> are edges<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"]\" title=\"]\" class=\"latex\" /><br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=-%5Cdelta%5E2%5Cmathbb+P%5Bx_1y_2%2Cx_2y_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"-&#92;delta^2&#92;mathbb P[x_1y_2,x_2y_1\" title=\"-&#92;delta^2&#92;mathbb P[x_1y_2,x_2y_1\" class=\"latex\" /> are edges<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"]\" title=\"]\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>where I have used the fact that the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1y_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_1y_2\" title=\"x_1y_2\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_2y_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_2y_1\" title=\"x_2y_1\" class=\"latex\" /> are both edges is exactly <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta^2\" title=\"&#92;delta^2\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>One or other of these two terms must be at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_2%5Cdelta%5E4%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_2&#92;delta^4/2\" title=\"c_2&#92;delta^4/2\" class=\"latex\" />. If it is the first, then averaging gives us <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_2%2Cy_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_2,y_2\" title=\"x_2,y_2\" class=\"latex\" /> such that</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E_%7Bx_1%2Cy_1%7D%28G%28x_1%2Cy_1%29-%5Cdelta%29G%28x_1%2Cy_2%29G%28x_2%2Cy_1%29%5Cgeq+c_2%5Cdelta%5E3%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb E_{x_1,y_1}(G(x_1,y_1)-&#92;delta)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)&#92;geq c_2&#92;delta^3/2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb E_{x_1,y_1}(G(x_1,y_1)-&#92;delta)G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)&#92;geq c_2&#92;delta^3/2\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>and now we can define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> just as in the regular case, obtaining the same result apart from an extra factor of 1/2. </p>\n<p>If it is the second, then averaging over <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%2Cy_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_1,y_1\" title=\"x_1,y_1\" class=\"latex\" /> this time and dividing by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;delta\" title=\"&#92;delta\" class=\"latex\" /> gives us some <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%2Cy_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_1,y_1\" title=\"x_1,y_1\" class=\"latex\" /> such that the inequality </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E_%7Bx_2%2Cy_2%7DG%28x_1%2Cy_2%29G%28x_2%2Cy_1%29%28G%28x_2%2Cy_2%29-%5Cdelta%29%5Cgeq+c_2%5Cdelta%5E3%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb E_{x_2,y_2}G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)(G(x_2,y_2)-&#92;delta)&#92;geq c_2&#92;delta^3/2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb E_{x_2,y_2}G(x_1,y_2)G(x_2,y_1)(G(x_2,y_2)-&#92;delta)&#92;geq c_2&#92;delta^3/2\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>So again we are done, this time with the roles of 1 and 2 reversed.</p>\n<p>I haven&#8217;t checked the details, but it is clear that one could run this argument for any subgraph <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=H&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"H\" title=\"H\" class=\"latex\" /> that occurs the &#8220;wrong&#8221; number of times. The extra factor one would need to divide by would be the number of edges you need to remove from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=H&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"H\" title=\"H\" class=\"latex\" /> to obtain a matching.</p>\n<p>Of course, the fact that Property 1 implies that all small subgraphs occur with roughly the right frequency is a very well known fact about quasirandom graphs, but it is usually proved using an almost regularity assumption, which I wanted to avoid.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 10 Nov 2018 17:34:17 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"163f1000018932e449cdc50e9d29ae89","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","destWidth":10,"destHeight":7,"sourceBytes":165,"destBytes":154,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn16@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-26-106_4ab5db98532a22ea.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn87@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-26-492_8f16f2228687f773.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn20@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-26-625_133bb69ff10adcdd.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn2@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-31-258_9607bd3e675f7ca6.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%5Csubset+X&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn36@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-19-648_11d6836c31658fd6.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%5Csubset+Y&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn56@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-24-317_edbf4c890a881697.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-709_4d3c0474cfeb94c8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-23-346_ea1814038d50c869.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%7CA%7C%7CB%7C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-
