.php?latex=%5Cdelta%5Cmathbb+P%5Bx_1y_1%2Cx_1y_2%2Cx_2y_1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn88@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-17-053_db345f8e258ebead.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=-%5Cdelta%5E2%5Cmathbb+P%5Bx_1y_2%2Cx_2y_1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn27@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-18-151_6f4a32cdc73d6420.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1y_2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn82@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-31-919_e5224f27f0926b3d.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_2y_1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn11@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-16-090_2b91cdfc05757402.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cdelta%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn80@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-22-382_3a64e7eb906a3221.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_2%5Cdelta%5E4%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn71@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-25-780_694a679d11b53b06.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E_%7Bx_1%2Cy_1%7D%28G%28x_1%2Cy_1%29-%5Cdelta%29G%28x_1%2Cy_2%29G%28x_2%2Cy_1%29%5Cgeq+c_2%5Cdelta%5E3%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-19-008_d9a099e4b2930d00.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E_%7Bx_2%2Cy_2%7DG%28x_1%2Cy_2%29G%28x_2%2Cy_1%29%28G%28x_2%2Cy_2%29-%5Cdelta%29%5Cgeq+c_2%5Cdelta%5E3%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn20@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-18-141_57814def1ea6e911.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=H&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-20-987_4b7a5fb9f585ac2c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694448},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Intransitive dice V: we want a local central limit theorem","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6289","description":"<p>It has become clear that what we need in order to finish off one of the problems about intransitive dice is a suitable version of the local central limit theorem. Roughly speaking, we need a version that is two-dimensional &#8212; that is, concerning a random walk on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" /> &#8212; and completely explicit &#8212; that is, giving precise bounds for error terms so that we can be sure that they get small fast enough. </p>\n<p>There is a recent paper that does this in the one-dimensional case, though it used an elementary argument, whereas I would prefer to use Fourier analysis. Here I&#8217;d like to begin the process of proving a two-dimensional result that is designed with our particular application in mind. If we are successful in doing that, then it would be natural to try to extract from the proof a more general statement, but that is not a priority just yet.</p>\n<p>As people often do, I&#8217;ll begin with a heuristic argument, and then I&#8217;ll discuss how we might try to sharpen it up to the point where it gives us good bounds for the probabilities of individual points of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" />. Much of this post is cut and pasted from comments on the previous post, since it should be more convenient to have it in one place.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6289\"></span></p>\n<h3>Using characteristic functions</h3>\n<p>The rough idea of the characteristic-functions approach, which I&#8217;ll specialize to the 2-dimensional case, is as follows. (Apologies to anyone who knows about this properly for anything idiotic I might accidentally write.) Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> be a random variable on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" /> and write <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28x%2Cy%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f(x,y)\" title=\"f(x,y)\" class=\"latex\" /> for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5B%28X%2CY%29%3D%28x%2Cy%29%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[(X,Y)=(x,y)]\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[(X,Y)=(x,y)]\" class=\"latex\" />. If we take <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> independent copies of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> and add them together, then the probability of being at <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x%2Cy%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x,y)\" title=\"(x,y)\" class=\"latex\" /> is</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%2A%5Cdots%2Af%28x%2Cy%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f*&#92;dots*f(x,y)\" title=\"f*&#92;dots*f(x,y)\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>where that denotes the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-fold convolution. </p>\n<p>Now let&#8217;s define the Fourier transform of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f\" title=\"f\" class=\"latex\" />, which probabilists call the characteristic function, in the usual way by</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bx%2Cy%7Df%28x%2Cy%29e%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+x%2B%5Cbeta+y%29%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Here <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> belong to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R%2F%5Cmathbb+Z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb R/&#92;mathbb Z\" title=\"&#92;mathbb R/&#92;mathbb Z\" class=\"latex\" />, but I&#8217;ll sometimes think of them as belonging to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B0%2C1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[0,1)\" title=\"[0,1)\" class=\"latex\" /> too.</p>\n<p>We have the convolution law that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cwidehat%7Bf%2Ag%7D%3D%5Chat+f%5Chat+g&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;widehat{f*g}=&#92;hat f&#92;hat g\" title=\"&#92;widehat{f*g}=&#92;hat f&#92;hat g\" class=\"latex\" /> and the inversion formula</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28x%2Cy%29%3D%5Cint%5Cint+%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29e%5E%7B-2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+x%2B%5Cbeta+y%29%7D%5C%2Cd%5Calpha%5C%2Cd%5Cbeta.&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f(x,y)=&#92;int&#92;int &#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)e^{-2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}&#92;,d&#92;alpha&#92;,d&#92;beta.\" title=\"f(x,y)=&#92;int&#92;int &#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)e^{-2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}&#92;,d&#92;alpha&#92;,d&#92;beta.\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>Putting these together, we find that if random variables <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X_i%2CY_i%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X_i,Y_i)\" title=\"(X_i,Y_i)\" class=\"latex\" /> are <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> independent copies of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" />, then the probability that their sum is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x%2Cy%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x,y)\" title=\"(x,y)\" class=\"latex\" /> is</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cint%5Cint+%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%5En+e%5E%7B-2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+x%2B%5Cbeta+y%29%7D%5C%2Cd%5Calpha%5C%2Cd%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;int&#92;int &#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)^n e^{-2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}&#92;,d&#92;alpha&#92;,d&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;int&#92;int &#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)^n e^{-2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}&#92;,d&#92;alpha&#92;,d&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>The very rough reason that we should now expect a Gaussian formula is that we consider a Taylor expansion of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f\" title=\"f\" class=\"latex\" />. We can assume for our application that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" /> have mean zero. From that one can argue that the coefficients of the linear terms in the Taylor expansion are zero. (I&#8217;ll give more details in a subsequent comment.) The constant term is 1, and the quadratic terms give us the covariance matrix of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" />. If we assume that we can approximate <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" title=\"f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" class=\"latex\" /> by an expression of the form <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" title=\"1-q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" class=\"latex\" /> for some suitable quadratic form in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" />, then the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />th power should be close to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cexp%28-nq%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;exp(-nq(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta))\" title=\"&#92;exp(-nq(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta))\" class=\"latex\" />, and then, since Fourier transforms (and inverse Fourier transforms) take Gaussians to Gaussians, when we invert this one, we should get a Gaussian-type formula for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28x%2Cy%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f(x,y)\" title=\"f(x,y)\" class=\"latex\" />. So far I&#8217;m glossing over the point that Gaussians are defined on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb R^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb R^2\" class=\"latex\" />, whereas <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> live in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb T\" title=\"&#92;mathbb T\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" /> live in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" />, but if most of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f^n\" title=\"&#92;hat f^n\" class=\"latex\" /> is supported in a small region around 0, then this turns out not to be too much of a problem.</p>\n<h3>The Taylor-expansion part</h3>\n<p>If we take the formula</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bx%2Cy%7Df%28x%2Cy%29e%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+x%2B%5Cbeta+y%29%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}\" class=\"latex\" /> </p>\n<p>and partially differentiate <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=r&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"r\" title=\"r\" class=\"latex\" /> times with respect to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"s\" title=\"s\" class=\"latex\" /> times with respect to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> we obtain the expression</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%282%5Cpi+i%29%5E%7Br%2Bs%7D%5Csum_%7Bx%2Cy%7Dx%5Ery%5Esf%28x%2Cy%29e%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+x%2B%5Cbeta+y%29%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(2&#92;pi i)^{r+s}&#92;sum_{x,y}x^ry^sf(x,y)e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}\" title=\"(2&#92;pi i)^{r+s}&#92;sum_{x,y}x^ry^sf(x,y)e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Setting <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%3D%5Cbeta%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha=&#92;beta=0\" title=\"&#92;alpha=&#92;beta=0\" class=\"latex\" /> turns this into <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%282%5Cpi+i%29%5E%7Br%2Bs%7D%5Cmathbb+E%28X%5ErY%5Es%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(2&#92;pi i)^{r+s}&#92;mathbb E(X^rY^s)\" title=\"(2&#92;pi i)^{r+s}&#92;mathbb E(X^rY^s)\" class=\"latex\" />. Also, for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> the absolute value of the partial derivative is at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%282%5Cpi%29%5E%7Br%2Bs%7D%5Cmathbb+E%28X%5ErY%5Es%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(2&#92;pi)^{r+s}&#92;mathbb E(X^rY^s)\" title=\"(2&#92;pi)^{r+s}&#92;mathbb E(X^rY^s)\" class=\"latex\" />. This allows us to get a very good handle on the Taylor expansion of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f\" title=\"&#92;hat f\" class=\"latex\" /> when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> are close to the origin.</p>\n<p>Recall that the two-dimensional Taylor expansion of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f\" title=\"&#92;hat f\" class=\"latex\" /> about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%280%2C0%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(0,0)\" title=\"(0,0)\" class=\"latex\" /> is given by the formula</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3D%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%2BD_1%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%5Calpha%2BD_2%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%5Cbeta%2B%5Cfrac+12D_%7B11%7D%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%5Calpha%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;hat f(0,0)+D_1&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;alpha+D_2&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;beta+&#92;frac 12D_{11}&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;alpha^2\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;hat f(0,0)+D_1&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;alpha+D_2&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;beta+&#92;frac 12D_{11}&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;alpha^2\" class=\"latex\" /><br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%2BD_%7B12%7D%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%5Calpha%5Cbeta%2B%5Cfrac+12+D_%7B22%7D%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%5Cbeta%5E2%2B%5Cmbox%7Berror+term%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"+D_{12}&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;alpha&#92;beta+&#92;frac 12 D_{22}&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;beta^2+&#92;mbox{error term}\" title=\"+D_{12}&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;alpha&#92;beta+&#92;frac 12 D_{22}&#92;hat f(0,0)&#92;beta^2+&#92;mbox{error term}\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1\" title=\"D_1\" class=\"latex\" /> is the partial derivative operator with respect to the first coordinate, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_%7B12%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_{12}\" title=\"D_{12}\" class=\"latex\" /> the mixed partial derivative, and so on.</p>\n<p>In our case, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bx%2Cy%7Df%28x%2Cy%29%3D1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(0,0)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)=1\" title=\"&#92;hat f(0,0)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)=1\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_1%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%3D2%5Cpi+i%5Cmathbb+EX%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_1&#92;hat f(0,0)=2&#92;pi i&#92;mathbb EX=0\" title=\"D_1&#92;hat f(0,0)=2&#92;pi i&#92;mathbb EX=0\" class=\"latex\" />, and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=D_2%5Chat+f%280%2C0%29%3D2%5Cpi+i%5Cmathbb+EY%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"D_2&#92;hat f(0,0)=2&#92;pi i&#92;mathbb EY=0\" title=\"D_2&#92;hat f(0,0)=2&#92;pi i&#92;mathbb EY=0\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>As in the one-dimensional case, the error term has an integral representation, namely</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_%7Bj%3D0%7D%5E3%5Cbinom+3j++%5Calpha%5Ej%5Cbeta%5E%7B3-j%7D%5Cint_0%5E1+%281-t%29%5E2+%28D_1%5EjD_2%5E%7B3-j%7D%5Chat+f%29%28t%5Calpha%2Ct%5Cbeta%29%5C%2Cdt&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_{j=0}^3&#92;binom 3j  &#92;alpha^j&#92;beta^{3-j}&#92;int_0^1 (1-t)^2 (D_1^jD_2^{3-j}&#92;hat f)(t&#92;alpha,t&#92;beta)&#92;,dt\" title=\"&#92;sum_{j=0}^3&#92;binom 3j  &#92;alpha^j&#92;beta^{3-j}&#92;int_0^1 (1-t)^2 (D_1^jD_2^{3-j}&#92;hat f)(t&#92;alpha,t&#92;beta)&#92;,dt\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>which has absolute value at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=8%5Cpi%5E3%5Csum_%7Bj%3D1%7D%5E3%5Cbinom+3j%7C%5Calpha%5Ej%5Cbeta%5E%7B3-j%7D%5Cmathbb+E+X%5EjY%5E%7B3-j%7D%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"8&#92;pi^3&#92;sum_{j=1}^3&#92;binom 3j|&#92;alpha^j&#92;beta^{3-j}&#92;mathbb E X^jY^{3-j}|\" title=\"8&#92;pi^3&#92;sum_{j=1}^3&#92;binom 3j|&#92;alpha^j&#92;beta^{3-j}&#92;mathbb E X^jY^{3-j}|\" class=\"latex\" />, which in turn is at most </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=8%5Cpi%5E3%5Csum_%7Bj%3D1%7D%5E3%5Cbinom+3j%7C%5Calpha%7C%5Ej%7C%5Cbeta%7C%5E%7B3-j%7D%5C%7CX%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%5Ej%5C%7CY%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%5E%7B3-j%7D%3D%28%7C%5Calpha%7C%5C%7CX%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%2B%7C%5Cbeta%7C%5C%7CY%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%29%5E3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"8&#92;pi^3&#92;sum_{j=1}^3&#92;binom 3j|&#92;alpha|^j|&#92;beta|^{3-j}&#92;|X&#92;|_&#92;infty^j&#92;|Y&#92;|_&#92;infty^{3-j}=(|&#92;alpha|&#92;|X&#92;|_&#92;infty+|&#92;beta|&#92;|Y&#92;|_&#92;infty)^3\" title=\"8&#92;pi^3&#92;sum_{j=1}^3&#92;binom 3j|&#92;alpha|^j|&#92;beta|^{3-j}&#92;|X&#92;|_&#92;infty^j&#92;|Y&#92;|_&#92;infty^{3-j}=(|&#92;alpha|&#92;|X&#92;|_&#92;infty+|&#92;beta|&#92;|Y&#92;|_&#92;infty)^3\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>When <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> is the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28h_A%28j%29%2Cj-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(h_A(j),j-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"(h_A(j),j-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" /> (where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is a fixed die and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> is chosen randomly from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" />), we have that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7CY%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%3D%28n-1%29%2F2%3Cn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;|Y&#92;|_&#92;infty=(n-1)/2&#60;n\" title=\"&#92;|Y&#92;|_&#92;infty=(n-1)/2&#60;n\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>With very slightly more effort we can get bounds for the moments of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" /> as well. For any particular <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> and a purely random sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29%5Cin+%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)&#92;in [n]^n\" title=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)&#92;in [n]^n\" class=\"latex\" />, the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7Ch_A%28j%29%7C%5Cgeq+t%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|h_A(j)|&#92;geq t&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"|h_A(j)|&#92;geq t&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" /> is bounded above by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7B-ct%5E2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e^{-ct^2}\" title=\"e^{-ct^2}\" class=\"latex\" /> for an absolute constant <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c&#62;0\" title=\"c&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" />. (Something like 1/8 will do.) So the probability that there exists such a <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> conditional on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> (which happens with probability about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/n\" title=\"1/n\" class=\"latex\" />) is at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Cn%5E2e%5E%7B-ct%5E2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Cn^2e^{-ct^2}\" title=\"Cn^2e^{-ct^2}\" class=\"latex\" />, and in particular is small when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t%3D100%5Csqrt%7B%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t=100&#92;sqrt{&#92;log n}\" title=\"t=100&#92;sqrt{&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" />. I think that with a bit more effort we could probably prove that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E_j+%7Ch_A%28j%29%7C%5E3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb E_j |h_A(j)|^3\" title=\"&#92;mathbb E_j |h_A(j)|^3\" class=\"latex\" /> is at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Cn%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Cn^{3/2}\" title=\"Cn^{3/2}\" class=\"latex\" />, which would allow us to improve the bound for the error term, but I think we can afford the logarithmic factor here, so I won&#8217;t worry about this. So we get an error of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%28%7C%5Calpha%7C%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D%2B%5Cbeta+n%29%5E3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C(|&#92;alpha|&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}+&#92;beta n)^3\" title=\"C(|&#92;alpha|&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}+&#92;beta n)^3\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>For this error to count as small, we want it to be small compared with the second moments. For the time being I&#8217;m just going to assume that the rough size of the second-moment contribution is around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%28%7C%5Calpha%7C%5Csqrt+n%2B%7C%5Cbeta%7Cn%29%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c(|&#92;alpha|&#92;sqrt n+|&#92;beta|n)^2\" title=\"c(|&#92;alpha|&#92;sqrt n+|&#92;beta|n)^2\" class=\"latex\" />. So for our error to be small, we want <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=o%281%2F%5Csqrt%7Bn%7D%28%5Clog+n%29%5E%7B3%2F2%7D%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"o(1/&#92;sqrt{n}(&#92;log n)^{3/2})\" title=\"o(1/&#92;sqrt{n}(&#92;log n)^{3/2})\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=o%281%2Fn%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"o(1/n)\" title=\"o(1/n)\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>That is giving us a rough idea of the domain in which we can say confidently that the terms up to the quadratic ones give a good approximation to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f\" title=\"&#92;hat f\" class=\"latex\" />, and hence that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f^n\" title=\"&#92;hat f^n\" class=\"latex\" /> is well approximated by a Gaussian.</p>\n<h3>The remaining part</h3>\n<p>Outside the domain, we have to do something different, and that something is fairly simple: we shall show that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f^n\" title=\"&#92;hat f^n\" class=\"latex\" /> is very small. This is equivalent to showing that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;hat f|\" title=\"|&#92;hat f|\" class=\"latex\" /> is bounded away from 1 by significantly more than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/n\" title=\"1/n\" class=\"latex\" />. This we do by looking more directly at the formula for the Fourier transform:</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bx%2Cy%7Df%28x%2Cy%29e%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+x%2B%5Cbeta+y%29%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y)}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>We would like this to have absolute value bounded away from 1 by significantly more than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1/n\" title=\"1/n\" class=\"latex\" /> except when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> is quite a bit smaller than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D%28%5Clog+n%29%5E%7B-3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1/2}(&#92;log n)^{-3/2}\" title=\"n^{-1/2}(&#92;log n)^{-3/2}\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> is quite a bit smaller than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1}\" title=\"n^{-1}\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>Now in our case <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f\" title=\"f\" class=\"latex\" /> is uniformly distributed on the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> points <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28h_A%28j%29%2Cj-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(h_A(j),j-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"(h_A(j),j-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" />. So we can write <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f\" title=\"&#92;hat f\" class=\"latex\" /> as</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3Dn%5E%7B-1%7D%5Csum_je%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+h_A%28j%29%2B%5Cbeta%28j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29%29%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=n^{-1}&#92;sum_je^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha h_A(j)+&#92;beta(j-(n+1)/2))}\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=n^{-1}&#92;sum_je^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha h_A(j)+&#92;beta(j-(n+1)/2))}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Here&#8217;s a possible way that we might try to bound that sum. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3Dn%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m=n/2\" title=\"m=n/2\" class=\"latex\" /> and let us split up the sum into pairs of terms with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%2Bm&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j+m\" title=\"j+m\" class=\"latex\" />, for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%5Cleq+m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j&#92;leq m\" title=\"j&#92;leq m\" class=\"latex\" />. So each pair of terms will take the form </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+h_A%28j%29%2B%5Cbeta%28j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29%29%7D%2Be%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+h_A%28j%2Bm%29%2B%5Cbeta%28j%2Bm-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29%29%7D.&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha h_A(j)+&#92;beta(j-(n+1)/2))}+e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha h_A(j+m)+&#92;beta(j+m-(n+1)/2))}.\" title=\"e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha h_A(j)+&#92;beta(j-(n+1)/2))}+e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha h_A(j+m)+&#92;beta(j+m-(n+1)/2))}.\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>The ratio of these two terms is</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha%28h_A%28j%29-h_A%28j%2Bm%29%29-%5Cbeta+m%29%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha(h_A(j)-h_A(j+m))-&#92;beta m)}\" title=\"e^{2&#92;pi i(&#92;alpha(h_A(j)-h_A(j+m))-&#92;beta m)}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>And if the ratio is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7Bi%5Ctheta%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e^{i&#92;theta}\" title=\"e^{i&#92;theta}\" class=\"latex\" />, then the modulus of the sum of the two terms is at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%281-c%5Ctheta%5E2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"2(1-c&#92;theta^2)\" title=\"2(1-c&#92;theta^2)\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>Now let us suppose that as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> varies, the differences <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29-h_A%28j%2Bm%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)-h_A(j+m)\" title=\"h_A(j)-h_A(j+m)\" class=\"latex\" /> are mostly reasonably well distributed in an interval between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=-%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"-&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"-&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" />, as seems very likely to be the case. Then the ratios above vary in a range from about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=-%5Calpha%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"-&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"-&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" />. But that should imply that the entire sum, when divided by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />, has modulus at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-c%5Calpha%5E2n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-c&#92;alpha^2n\" title=\"1-c&#92;alpha^2n\" class=\"latex\" />. (This analysis obviously isn&#8217;t correct when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> is bigger than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1/2}\" title=\"n^{-1/2}\" class=\"latex\" />, since the modulus can&#8217;t be negative, but once we&#8217;re in that regime, then it really is easy to establish the bounds we want.)</p>\n<p>If <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> is, say <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-2%2F3%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-2/3}\" title=\"n^{-2/3}\" class=\"latex\" />, then this gives us <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-cn%5E%7B-1%2F3%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-cn^{-1/3}\" title=\"1-cn^{-1/3}\" class=\"latex\" />, and raising that to the power <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> gives us <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7B-cn%5E%7B2%2F3%7D%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e^{-cn^{2/3}}\" title=\"e^{-cn^{2/3}}\" class=\"latex\" />, which is tiny. </p>\n<p>As a quick sanity check, note that for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281-c%5Calpha%5E2n%29%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(1-c&#92;alpha^2n)^n\" title=\"(1-c&#92;alpha^2n)^n\" class=\"latex\" /> not to be tiny we need <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> to be not much more than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1}\" title=\"n^{-1}\" class=\"latex\" />. This reflects the fact that a random walk of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> steps of typical size about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" /> will tend to be at a distance comparable to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> from the origin, and when you take the Fourier transform, you take the reciprocals of the distance scales.</p>\n<p>If <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> is quite a bit smaller than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1/2}\" title=\"n^{-1/2}\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> is not too much smaller than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1}\" title=\"n^{-1}\" class=\"latex\" />, then the numbers <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha+h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha h_A(j)\" title=\"&#92;alpha h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> are all small but the numbers <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta%28j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta(j-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"&#92;beta(j-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" /> vary quite a bit, so a similar argument can be used to show that in this case too the Fourier transform is not close enough to 1 for its <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />th power to be large. I won&#8217;t give details here.</p>\n<h3>What is left to do?</h3>\n<p>If the calculations above are not too wide of the mark, then the main thing that needs to be done is to show that for a typical die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> the numbers <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)\" title=\"h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> are reasonably uniform in a range of width around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" />, and more importantly that the numbers <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29-h_A%28j%2Bm%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)-h_A(j+m)\" title=\"h_A(j)-h_A(j+m)\" class=\"latex\" /> are not too constant: basically I&#8217;d like them to be pretty uniform too.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s possible that we might want to try a slightly different approach, which is to take the uniform distribution on the set of points <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28h_A%28j%29%2Cj-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(h_A(j),j-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"(h_A(j),j-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" />, convolve it once with itself, and argue that the resulting probability distribution is reasonably uniform in a rectangle of width around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> and height around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" />. By that I mean that a significant proportion of the points are hit around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt n\" title=\"&#92;sqrt n\" class=\"latex\" /> times each (because there are <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^2\" title=\"n^2\" class=\"latex\" /> sums and they lie in a rectangle of area <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{3/2}\" title=\"n^{3/2}\" class=\"latex\" />). But one way or another, I feel pretty confident that we will be able to bound this Fourier transform and get the local central limit theorem we need.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 30 May 2017 22:37:22 %3D100%5Csqrt%7B%5Clog+n%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-16-075_3d13ee47af94d122.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E_j+%7Ch_A%28j%29%7C%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn94@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-30-474_706b2f290fdb645b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Cn%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn37@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-30-168_21653b05a236a1a2.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%28%7C%5Calpha%7C%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D%2B%5Cbeta+n%29%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn8@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-21-320_79a2c6c7276ed2a1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%28%7C%5Calpha%7C%5Csqrt+n%2B%7C%5Cbeta%7Cn%29%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-18-106_8a968da45f10e390.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=o%281%2F%5Csqrt%7Bn%7D%28%5Clog+n%29%5E%7B3%2F2%7D%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn49@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-16-147_3dc244fe41753727.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=o%281%2Fn%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn8@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-18-109_659e2878761e0d90.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%7C&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn72@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-23-135_a7e4cc6fc692a8f3.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D%28%5Clog+n%29%5E%7B-3%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn40@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-24-978_78a74472ebd44b74.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn47@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-17-964_d320debba48ff241.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3Dn%5E%7B-1%7D%5Csum_je%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+h_A%28j%29%2B%5Cbeta%28j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29%29%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn59@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-17-278_d1604d03ca960e72.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m%3Dn%2F2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn86@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-28-423_2f11a7642d525873.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%2Bm&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn5@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-28-680_1a14c230d64e51d3.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%5Cleq+m&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn60@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-21-268_1dfd28e7d4341608.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+h_A%28j%29%2B%5Cbeta%28j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29%29%7D%2Be%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha+h_A%28j%2Bm%29%2B%5Cbeta%28j%2Bm-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29%29%7D.&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn65@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-31-097_6f28db40434dd93b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7B2%5Cpi+i%28%5Calpha%28h_A%28j%29-h_A%28j%2Bm%29%29-%5Cbeta+m%29%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn81@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-31-188_bb925e0146b82848.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7Bi%5Ctheta%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn48@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-23-045_fcb35d9ed54ecfec.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%281-c%5Ctheta%5E2%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-26-726_4e73a9faea953ee2.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29-h_A%28j%2Bm%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn49@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-28-224_c75c62363ca982f0.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=-%5Csqrt+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn19@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-16-152_4a05983736dc7ed2.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-26-179_e3bb74336ad8a642.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=-%5Calpha%5Csqrt+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn55@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-25-135_6f95699647caa451.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5Csqrt+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn14@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-31-997_f7fcc39e67033a9a.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-c%5Calpha%5E2n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn55@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-19-947_87e65d7ea8fba549.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn98@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-30-507_d7f01acd4e9acd42.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-2%2F3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn49@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-30-954_cecb410930070825.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-cn%5E%7B-1%2F3%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn44@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-16-091_767009cc8ee03cf1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7B-cn%5E%7B2%2F3%7D%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn12@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-24-685_903e6b1b722dfbdc.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281-c%5Calpha%5E2n%29%5En&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn39@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-18-161_badf5ab25d02fb30.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha+h_A%28j%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn53@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-31-729_0922303766b62805.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta%28j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-19-096_9285847a3367c1c9.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn70@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-28-281_8190dd11792b691e.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn67@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-26-274_1d3fc1ef2de7cf3f.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B3%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-20-023_385afbdbb3b43a29.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694452},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Additional thoughts on the Ted Hill paper","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6405","description":"<p>First, I&#8217;d like to thank the large number of commenters on my previous post for keeping the discussion surprisingly calm and respectful given the topic discussed. In that spirit, and to try to practise the scientific integrity that I claimed to care about, I want to acknowledge that my views about the paper have changed somewhat as a result of the discussion. My understanding of the story of what happened to the paper has changed even more now that some of those attacked in Ted Hill&#8217;s Quillette article have responded, but about that I only want to repeat what I said in one or two comments on the previous post: that my personal view is that one should not &#8220;unaccept&#8221; or &#8220;unpublish&#8221; a paper unless something was improper about the way it was accepted or published, and that that is also the view of the people who were alleged to have tried to suppress Ted Hill&#8217;s paper on political grounds. I would also remark that whatever happened at NYJM would not have happened if all decisions had to be taken collectively by the whole editorial board, which is the policy on several journals I have been on the board of. According to Igor Rivin, the policy at NYJM is very different: &#8220;No approval for the full board is required, or ever obtained. The approval of the Editor in Chief is not required.&#8221; I find this quite extraordinary: it would seem to be a basic safeguard that decisions should be taken by more than one person &#8212; ideally many more.</p>\n<p>To return to the paper, I now see that the selectivity hypothesis, which I said I found implausible, was actually quite reasonable. If you look carefully at my previous post, you will see that I actually started to realize that even when writing it, and it would have been more sensible to omit that criticism entirely, but by the time it occurred to me that ancient human females could well have been selective in a way that could (in a toy model) be reasonably approximated by Hill&#8217;s hypothesis, I had become too wedded to what I had already written &#8212; a basic writer&#8217;s mistake, made in this case partly because I had only a short window of time in which to write the post. I&#8217;m actually quite glad I left the criticism in, since I learnt quite a lot from the numerous comments that defended the hypothesis.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6405\"></span></p>\n<p>I had a similar experience with a second criticism: the idea of dividing the population up into two subpopulations. That still bothers me somewhat, since in reality we all have large numbers of genes that interact in complicated ways and it is not clear that a one-dimensional model will be appropriate for a high-dimensional feature space. But perhaps for a toy model intended to start a discussion that is all right.</p>\n<p>While I&#8217;m at it, some commenters on the previous post came away with the impression that I was against toy models. I agree with the following words, which appeared in a book that was published in 2002.</p>\n<blockquote><p>There are many ways of modelling a given physical situation and we must use a mixture of experience and further theoretical considerations to decide what a given model is likely to teach us about the world itself. When choosing a model, one priority is to make its behaviour correspond closely to the actual, observed behaviour of the world. However, other factors, such as simplicity and mathematical elegance, can often be more important. Indeed, there are very useful models with almost no resemblance to the world at all &#8230;</p></blockquote>\n<p>But that&#8217;s not surprising, since I was the author of the book.</p>\n<p>But there is a third feature of Hill&#8217;s model that I still find puzzling. Some people have tried to justify it to me, but I found that either I understood the justifications and found them unconvincing or I didn&#8217;t understand them. I don&#8217;t rule out the possibility that some of the ones I didn&#8217;t understand were reasonable defences of this aspect of the model, but let me lay out once again the difficulty I have.</p>\n<p>To do this I&#8217;ll briefly recall Hill&#8217;s model. You have two subpopulations <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" /> of, let us say, the males of a species. (It is not important for the model that they are male, but that is how Hill hopes the model will be applied.) The distribution of desirability of subpopulation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> is more spread out than that of subpopulation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />, so if the females of the species choose to reproduce only with males above a rather high percentile of desirability, they will pick a greater proportion of subpopulation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> than of subpopulation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>A quick aside is that what I have just written is more or less the entire actual content (as opposed to surrounding discussion) of Hill&#8217;s paper. Of course, he has to give a precise definition of &#8220;more spread out&#8221;, but it is very easy to come up with a definition that will give the desired conclusion after a one-line argument, and that is what he does. He also gives a continuous-time version of the process. But I&#8217;m not sure what adding a bit of mathematical window dressing really adds, since the argument in the previous paragraph is easy to understand and obviously correct. But of course without that window dressing the essay couldn&#8217;t hope to sell itself as a mathematics paper. </p>\n<p>The curious feature of the model, and the one that I still find hard to accept, is that Hill assumes, and absolutely needs to assume, that the only thing that can change is the sizes of the subpopulations and not the distributions of desirability within those populations. So if, for example, what makes a male desirable is height, and if the average heights in the two populations are the same, then even though females refuse to reproduce with anybody who isn&#8217;t unusually tall, the average height of males remains the same.</p>\n<p>The only way this strange consequence can work, as far as I can see, is if instead of there being a gene (or combination of genes) that makes men tall, there is a gene that has some complicated effect of which a side-effect is that the height of men is more variable, and moreover there aren&#8217;t other genes that simply cause tallness.</p>\n<p>It is hard to imagine what the complicated effect might be in the case of height, but it is not impossible to come up with speculations about mathematical ability. For example, maybe men have, as has been suggested, a tendency to be a bit further along the autism spectrum than women, which causes some of them to become very good at mathematics and others to lack the social skills to attract a mate. But even by the standards of evolutionary just-so stories, that is not a very good one. Our prehistoric ancestors were not doing higher mathematics, so we would need to think of some way that being on the spectrum could have caused a man <em>at that time</em> to become highly attractive to women. One has to go through such contortions to make the story work, when all along there is the much more straightforward possibility that there is some complex mix of genes that go towards making somebody intelligent, and that if prehistoric women went for intelligent men, then those genes would be selected for. But if that is what happened, then the proportion of less intelligent men would go down, and therefore the variability would go down.</p>\n<p>While writing this, I have realized that there is a crucial assumption of Hill&#8217;s, the importance of which I had not appreciated. It&#8217;s that the medians of his two subpopulations are the same. Suppose instead that the individuals in male population <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> are on average more desirable than the individuals in male population <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />. Then even if population <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> is <em>less</em> variable than population <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />, if females are selective, it may very well be that a far higher proportion of population <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> is chosen than of population <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />, and therefore a tendency for the variability of the combined population to decrease. In fact, we don&#8217;t even need to assume that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> is less variable than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />: if the population as a whole becomes dominated by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" />, it may well be less variable than the original combination of populations <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>So for Hill&#8217;s model to work, it needs a fairly strange and unintuitive combination of hypotheses. Therefore, if he proposes it as a potential explanation for greater variability amongst males, he needs to argue that this combination of hypotheses might actually have occurred for many important features. For example, if it is to explain greater variability for males in mathematics test scores, then he appears to need to argue (i) that there was a gene that made our prehistoric male ancestors more variable with respect to some property that at one end of the scale made them more desirable to females, (ii) that this gene had no effect on average levels of desirability, (iii) that today this curious property has as a side-effect greater variability in mathematics test scores, and (iv) this tendency to increase variability is not outweighed by reduction of variability due to selection of other genes that do affect average levels. (Although he explicitly says that he is not trying to explain any particular instance of greater variability amongst males, most of the references he gives concerning such variability are to do with intellectual ability, and if he can&#8217;t give a convincing story about that, then why have all those references?)</p>\n<p>Thus, what I object to is not the very idea of a toy model, but more that with this particular toy model I have to make a number of what seem to me to be highly implausible assumptions to get it to work. And I don&#8217;t mean the usual kind of entirely legitimate simplifying assumptions. Rather, I&#8217;m talking about artificial assumptions that seem to be there only to get the model to do what Hill wants it to do. If some of the hypotheses above that seem implausible to me have in fact been observed by biologists, it seems to me that Hill should have included references to the relevant literature in his copious bibliography.</p>\n<p>As with my previous post, I am not assuming that everything I&#8217;ve just written is right, and will be happy to be challenged on the points above. </p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 12 Sep 2018 23:01:10 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"a57c2b72999977917aba338bb322a066","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn95@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-714_d818176f450d5f05.webp","destWidth":13,"destHeight":11,"sourceBytes":185,"destBytes":188,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn95@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-714_d818176f450d5f05.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn83@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-25-754_96cbe7cc26534cc1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694448},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Time for Elsexit?","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6207","description":"<p>This post is principally addressed to academics in the UK, though some of it may apply to people in other countries too. The current deal that the universities have with Elsevier expires at the end of this year, and a new one has been negotiated between Elsevier and Jisc Collections, the body tasked with representing the UK universities. If you want, you can read <a href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/press-releases/research-and-journals/jisc-collections-and-elsevier-sign-landmark-uk-agreement,-securing-access-to-research-publications-and-initiating-open-science-collaboration\">a thoroughly misleading statement about it</a> on Elsevier&#8217;s website. On Jisc&#8217;s website is <a href=\"https://www.jisc-collections.ac.uk/News/New-Elsevier-2017-2021-ScienceDirect-agreement/\">a brief news item</a> with a link to further details that tells you almost nothing and then contains a further link entitled &#8220;Read the full description here&#8221;, which appears to be broken. On the page with that link can be found the statement</p>\n<blockquote><p>The ScienceDirect agreement provides access to around 1,850 full text scientific, technical and medical (STM) journals â€“ managed by renowned editors, written by respected authors and read by researchers from around the globe â€“ all available in one place: ScienceDirect. Elsevierâ€™s full text collection covers titles from the core scientific literature including high impact factor titles such as The Lancet, Cell and Tetrahedron.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Unless things have changed, this too is highly misleading, since up to now most Cell Press titles have <em>not</em> been part of the Big Deal but instead are part of a separate package. This point is worth stressing, since failure to appreciate it may cause some people to overestimate how much they rely on the Big Deal &#8212; in Cambridge at least, the Cell Press journals account for a significant percentage of our total downloads. (To be more precise, the top ten Elsevier journals accessed by Cambridge are, in order, Cell, Neuron, Current Biology, Molecular Cell, The Lancet, Developmental Cell, NeuroImage, Cell Stem Cell, Journal of Molecular Biology, and Earth and Planetary Science Letters. Of those, Cell, Neuron, Current Biology, Molecular Cell, Developmental Cell and Cell Stem Cell are Cell Press journals, and they account for over 10% of all our access to Elsevier journals.) </p>\n<p>Jisc has also put up a Q&#38;A, which can be found <a href=\"https://www.jisc.ac.uk/blog/jisc-collections-and-elsevier-agreement-questions-and-answers-28-nov-2016\">here</a>.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6207\"></span></p>\n<h3>Roughly how much do universities currently pay for access to ScienceDirect?</h3>\n<p>Just to remind you, here is what a number of universities were paying annually for their Elsevier subscriptions during the current deal. To be precise, these are the figures for 2014, obtained using FOI requests: they are likely to be a little higher for 2016.</p>\n<table style=\"width:450px;\">\n<tr>\n<td><strong>University</strong></td>\n<td><strong>Cost</strong></td>\n<td><strong>Enrolment</strong></td>\n<td><strong>Academic Staff</strong></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Birmingham</td>\n<td>Â£764,553</td>\n<td>31,070</td>\n<td>2355 + 440</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Bristol</td>\n<td>Â£808,840</td>\n<td>19,220</td>\n<td>2090 + 525</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Cambridge</td>\n<td>Â£1,161,571</td>\n<td>19,945</td>\n<td>4205 +  710</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Cardiff</td>\n<td>Â£720,533</td>\n<td>30,000</td>\n<td>2130 + 825</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>*Durham</td>\n<td>Â£461,020</td>\n<td>16,570</td>\n<td>1250 + 305</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>**Edinburgh</td>\n<td>Â£845,000</td>\n<td>31,323</td>\n<td>2945 + 540</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>*Exeter</td>\n<td>Â£234,126</td>\n<td>18,720</td>\n<td>1270 + 290</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Glasgow</td>\n<td>Â£686,104</td>\n<td>26,395</td>\n<td>2000 + 650</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Imperial College London</td>\n<td>Â£1,340,213</td>\n<td>16,000</td>\n<td>3295 + 535</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>King&#8217;s College London</td>\n<td>Â£655,054</td>\n<td>26,460</td>\n<td>2920 + 1190</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Leeds</td>\n<td>Â£847,429</td>\n<td>32,510</td>\n<td>2470 + 655</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Liverpool</td>\n<td>Â£659,796</td>\n<td>21,875</td>\n<td>1835 + 530</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Â§London School of Economics</td>\n<td>Â£146,117</td>\n<td>9,805</td>\n<td>755 + 825</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Manchester</td>\n<td>Â£1,257,407</td>\n<td>40,860</td>\n<td>3810 + 745</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Newcastle</td>\n<td>Â£974,930</td>\n<td>21,055</td>\n<td>2010 + 495</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Nottingham</td>\n<td>Â£903,076</td>\n<td>35,630</td>\n<td>2805 + 585</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Oxford</td>\n<td>Â£990,775</td>\n<td>25,595</td>\n<td>5190 + 775</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>* ***Queen Mary U of London</td>\n<td>Â£454,422</td>\n<td>14,860</td>\n<td>1495 + 565</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Queen&#8217;s U Belfast</td>\n<td>Â£584,020</td>\n<td>22,990</td>\n<td>1375 + 170</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Sheffield</td>\n<td>Â£562,277</td>\n<td>25,965</td>\n<td>2300 + 460</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Southampton</td>\n<td>Â£766,616</td>\n<td>24,135</td>\n<td>2065 + 655</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>University College London</td>\n<td>Â£1,381,380</td>\n<td>25,525</td>\n<td>4315 + 1185</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Warwick</td>\n<td>Â£631,851</td>\n<td>27,440</td>\n<td>1535 + 305</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>*York</td>\n<td>Â£400,445</td>\n<td>17,405</td>\n<td>1205 + 285</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n<p>*Joined the Russell Group two years ago.<br />\n**Information obtained by Sean Williams.<br />\n***Information obtained by Edward Hughes.<br />\nÂ§LSE subscribes to a package of subject collections rather than to the full Freedom Collection.</p>\n<p>These are figures for Russell Group universities: the total amount spent annually by all UK universities for access to ScienceDirect is around Â£40 million.</p>\n<p>An important additional factor is that since the last deal was struck with Elsevier, we have had <a href=\"https://www.acu.ac.uk/research-information-network/finch-report\">the Finch Report</a>, which has led to a policy of requiring publications in the UK to be open access. The big publishers (who lobbied hard when the report was being written) have responded by turning many of their journals into &#8220;hybrid&#8221; journals, that is, subscription journals where for an additional fee, usually in the region of Â£2000, you can pay to make your article freely readable to everybody. This has added significantly to the total bill. Cambridge, for example, has paid over Â£750,000 this year in article processing charges, from a grant provided for the purpose.</p>\n<h3>How were the negotiations conducted?</h3>\n<p>Jisc started preparing for these negotiations at least two years ago, for example going on fact-finding missions round the world to see what had happened in other countries. The negotiations began in earnest in 2016, and Jisc started out with some core aims, some of which they described as red lines and some as important aims. (I know this from a briefing meeting I attended in Cambridge &#8212; I think that similar meetings took place at other universities.) Some of these were as follows. </p>\n<ol>\n<li>No real-terms price increases.</li>\n<li>An offsetting agreement for article processing charges.</li>\n<li>No confidentiality clauses.</li>\n<li>A move away from basing price on &#8220;historic spend&#8221;.</li>\n<li>A three-year deal rather than a five-year deal.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Let me say a little about each of these. </p>\n<h4>No real-terms price increases</h4>\n<p>This seemed extraordinarily unambitious as a starting point for negotiations. The whole point of universities asking an organization like Jisc to negotiate on our behalf was supposed to be that they would be able to negotiate hard and that the threat of not coming to an agreement would be one that Elsevier would have to be genuinely worried about. Journal prices have gone up far more than inflation for decades, while the costs of dissemination have (or at the very least should have) gone down substantially. In addition, there are a number of subjects, mathematics and high-energy physics being two notable examples, where it is now common practice to claim priority for a result by posting a preprint, and in those subjects it is less and less common for people to look at the journal versions of articles because repositories such as arXiv are much more convenient, and the value that the publishers claim they add to articles is small to nonexistent. So Jisc should have been pressing for a substantial cut in prices: maintenance of the status quo is not appropriate when technology and reading habits are changing so rapidly. </p>\n<h4>Offsetting for APCs</h4>\n<p>An offsetting agreement means a deal where if somebody pays an article processing charge in order to make an article open access in an Elsevier journal, then that charge is subtracted from the Big Deal payment. There are arguments for and against this idea. The main argument for it is that it is a way of avoiding double dipping: the phenomenon where Elsevier effectively gets paid twice for the same article, since it rakes in the article processing charges but does not reduce the subscription cost of the Big Deal.</p>\n<p>In its defence, Elsevier makes the following two points. First, it has <a href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/company-information/policies/pricing#Dipping\">an explicit policy against double dipping</a>. In answer to the obvious accusation that they are receiving a lot of APCs and we are seeing no corresponding drop in Big Deal prices, they point out that the total volume of articles they publish is going up. This highlights a huge problem with Big Deals: if universities could say that they did not want the extra content then it might be OK, but as it is, all Elsevier has to do to adhere to its policy is found enough worthless journals that nobody reads to equal the volume of articles for which APCs are paid. </p>\n<p>But there is a second argument that carries more weight. It is that if one country has an offsetting agreement, then all other countries benefit (at least in theory) from lower subscription prices, so in total Elsevier has lost out. Or to put it another way, with an offsetting agreement, it basically becomes free for people in that country to publish an open access article with Elsevier, so they are effectively giving away that content.</p>\n<p>Against this are two arguments: that if somebody has to lose out, why should it not be Elsevier, and that in any case it would be entirely consistent with a no-double-dipping policy for Elsevier not to reduce its Big Deal subscriptions for the other countries. In the longer term, if lots of countries had offsetting agreements, this might cease to be sustainable, since nobody would need subscriptions any more, but since most countries are not following the UK&#8217;s lead in pursuing open access with article processing charges, this is unlikely to happen any time soon.</p>\n<p>Personally, I am not in favour of an offsetting agreement if it works on a per-article basis, since that may lead to pressure from universities for their academics to publish with Elsevier rather than with publishers that do not have offsetting agreements: that is, it gives an artificial advantage to Elsevier journals. What I would like to see is a big drop in the subscription price to allow for the fact that we are now paying a lot of APC money to Elsevier. That way, if other journals are better, they will get used, and there will be some semblance of a market.</p>\n<h4>No confidentiality clauses</h4>\n<p>It goes without saying that confidentiality clauses are one of the most obnoxious features of Elsevier contracts. And now that FOI requests have been successful in obtaining information about what universities pay for their subscriptions, they also seem rather pointless. In any case, Jisc was strongly against them, as they certainly should have been.</p>\n<p>Another remark is that if contracts are kept confidential, there is no way of assessing whether Elsevier is double dipping.</p>\n<h4>Historic spend</h4>\n<p>When we moved from looking at print copies of journals to looking at articles online, it suddenly ceased to be obvious on what basis we should be charged. Elsevier came up with the idea of not changing anything, so even if in practice with a big deal we get access to all the journals, nominally a university subscribes to a &#8220;Core Collection&#8221;, which is based on what it used to have print subscriptions to (they are allowed to change what is in the Core Collection, but they cannot reduce its size), and then the rest goes under the Orwellian name of the Freedom Collection. </p>\n<p>This system is manifestly unfair: for example, Cambridge, with its numerous college libraries, used to subscribe to several copies of certain journals and is now penalized for this. It also means that if a university starts to need journals less, there is no way for this to be reflected in the price it pays. </p>\n<p>Jisc recognised the problem, and came up with a rather mealy-mouthed formula about &#8220;moving away from historic spend&#8221;. Not abolishing the system and replacing it by a fairer one (which is hard to do as there will be losers as well as winners), but &#8220;moving away&#8221; from it in ways that they did not specify when we asked about it at the briefing meeting.</p>\n<h4>A three-year deal</h4>\n<p>At some point I was told (indirectly by Cambridge&#8217;s then head librarian) that the idea was to go for a three-year deal, so that we would not be locked in for too long. This I was very pleased to hear, as a lot can change in three years.</p>\n<h3>And what was the result?</h3>\n<p>For reasons I&#8217;ve given in the previous section, even if Jisc had succeeded in its aims, I would have been disappointed by the deal. But as it was, something very strange happened. We had been told of considerable ill feeling, including cancelled meetings because the deals that Elsevier was offering were so insultingly bad, and then suddenly in late September we learned that a deal had been reached. And then when the deal was announced it was all smiles and talk of &#8220;landmark deals&#8221; and &#8220;value for money&#8221;. </p>\n<p>So how did Jisc do, by their own criteria? Well, it is conceivable that they will end up achieving their first aim of not having any real-terms price increases: this will depend on whether Brexit causes enough inflation to cancel out such money-terms price increases as there may or may not be &#8212; I leave it to you to guess which. (In the interests of balance, I should also point out that the substantial drop in the pound means that what Elsevier receives has, in their terms, gone down. That said, currency fluctuations are a fact of life and over the last few years they have benefited a lot from a weak euro.) </p>\n<p>Jisc said that an offsetting agreement was not just an aspiration but a red line &#8212; a requirement of any deal they would be prepared to strike. However, there is no offsetting agreement.</p>\n<p>Jisc also said that they would insist on transparency, but when Elsevier insisted on confidentiality clauses, they meekly accepted this. (Their reasoning: Elsevier was not prepared to reach a deal without these clauses. But why didn&#8217;t an argument of exactly the same type apply to Jisc in the other direction?) It is for that reason that I have been a bit vague about prices above.</p>\n<p>As far as historic spend is concerned, I see on the Jisc statement the following words: &#8220;The agreement includes the ability for the consortium to migrate from historical print spend and reallocate costs should we so wish.&#8221; I have no information about whether any &#8220;migration&#8221; has started, but my guess would be that it hasn&#8217;t, since if there were to be moves in that direction, then there would surely need to be difficult negotiations between the universities about how to divide up the total bill, and there has been no sign of any such negotiations taking place.</p>\n<p>Finally, the deal is for five years and not for three years.</p>\n<p>So Jisc has not won any clear victories and has had several clear defeats. Now if you were in that position more than three months before the end of the existing deal, what would you do? Perhaps you would follow the course suggested by a Jisc representative at one of the briefing meetings, who said the following.</p>\n<blockquote><p>We know from analysis of the experiences of other consortia that Elsevier really do want to reach an agreement this year. They really hate to go over into the next year &#8230;</p>\n<p>A number of colleagues from other consortia have said they wished they had held on longer &#8230;</p>\n<p>If we can hold firm even briefly into 2017 that should have quite a profound impact on what we can achieve in these negotiations.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Of course, all that is just common sense. But this sensible negotiating strategy was mysteriously abandoned, on the grounds that it had become clear that the deal on offer was the best that Jisc was going to get. Again there is a curious lack of symmetry here: why didn&#8217;t Jisc make it clear that a better deal (for Jisc) was the best that Elsevier was going to get? At the very least, why didn&#8217;t Jisc at least try to extract further concessions from Elsevier by letting the negotiations continue until much closer to the expiry of the current deal? </p>\n<p>Jisc defended itself by saying that their job was simply to obtain the best deal they could to put before the universities, but no university was obliged to sign up to the deal. This is not a wholly satisfactory response, since (i) the whole point of using Jisc rather than negotiating individually was to exploit the extra bargaining power that should come from acting in concert and (ii) Elsevier have made it clear that they will not offer a better deal to any institution that opts out of the Jisc-negotiated one. (This is one of many parallels with Brexit &#8212; in this case with the fact that the EU cannot be seen to be giving the UK a better deal than it had in the EU.) </p>\n<p>A particularly irritating aspect of the situation was that I and some others had organized for an open letter to be sent to Jisc from many academics, urging them to bargain hard. We asked Jisc whether this would be helpful and they requested that we should delay sending it until after a particular meeting with Elsevier had taken place. And then the premature deal took us by surprise and the letter never got sent.</p>\n<h3>What is happening now?</h3>\n<p>Several universities have already accepted the deal, and the mood amongst heads of department in Cambridge appears to be that although it is not a good deal we do not have a realistic alternative to accepting it. This may be correct, but we appear to be rushing into a decision (in Cambridge it is due to be taken in a few days&#8217; time).
