We are talking about a lot of money: would it not be sensible to delay signing a contract until there has been a proper assessment of the consequences of rejecting a deal? </p>\n<p>For Cambridge, I personally would be in favour of cancelling the Big Deal and subscribing individually to a selection of the most important journals, even if this ended up costing more than what we pay at the moment. The reason is that we would have taken back control (those parallels again). At the moment the market is completely dysfunctional, since the price we pay bears virtually no relationship to demand. But if departments were given budgets and told they could choose whether to spend them on journal subscriptions or to use the money for other purposes, then they would be able to do a proper cost-benefit analysis and act on it. Then as more and more papers became freely available online, costs would start to go down. And if other universities did the same (as some notable universities such as Harvard already have), then Elsevier might start having to lower the list prices of their journals.</p>\n<p>If the deal is accepted, it should not be the end of the story. A large part of the reason that Elsevier and the other large publishers walk all over Jisc in these negotiations is that we lack a credible Plan B. (For mathematics there is one &#8212; just cancel the deal and read papers on the arXiv, as we do already &#8212; but many other subjects have not reached this stage.) We need to think about this, so that in future negotiations any threat to cancel the deal is itself credible. We also need to think about whether Jisc is the right body to be negotiating on our behalf, given what has happened this time. What I am hearing from many people, even those who think we should accept the deal, is full agreement that it is a bad one. Even if we accept it, the very least we can do is make clear that we are not happy with what we are accepting. It may not be very polite to those at Jisc who worked hard on our behalf, but we have paid a heavy price for politeness. </p>\n<p>If Elsevier will not give us a proper market, we can at least create mini-markets ourselves within universities: why not charge more from faculties that rely on ScienceDirect more heavily? Such is the culture of secrecy that I am not even allowed to tell you how the cost is shared out in Cambridge, but it does not appear to be based on need. </p>\n<p>I am often asked why I focus on Elsevier, but the truth is that I no longer do: Springer, Wiley, and Taylor and Francis are in many ways just as bad, and in some respects are even worse. (For example, while Elsevier now makes mathematics papers over four years old freely available, Springer has consistently refused to make any such move.) I am very reluctant to submit papers to any of these publishers &#8212; for example, now that <a href=\"http://eu.wiley.com/WileyCDA/PressRelease/pressReleaseId-123682.html\">the London Mathematical Society has switched from OUP to Wiley</a> I will not be sending papers to their journals. It will be depressing if we have to wait another five years to improve the situation with Elsevier, but in the meantime there are smaller, but still pretty big, Big Deals coming up with the other members of the big four. Because they are smaller, perhaps we are less reliant on their journals, and perhaps that would allow us to drive harder bargains.</p>\n<p>In any case, if you are unhappy with the way things are, please make your feelings known. Part of the problem is that the people who negotiate on our behalf are, quite reasonably, afraid of the reaction they would get if we lost access to important journals. It&#8217;s just a pity that they are not also afraid of the reaction if the deal they strike is significantly more expensive than it need have been. (We are in a classic game-theoretic situation where there is a wide range of prices at which it is worth it for Elsevier to provide the deal and not worth it for a university to cancel it, and Elsevier is very good at pushing the price to the top of this range.) Pressure should also be put on librarians to get organized with a proper Plan B so that we can survive for a reasonable length of time without Big Deal subscriptions. Just as with nuclear weapons, it is not necessary for such a Plan B ever to be put to use, but it needs to exist and be credible so that any threat to walk away from negotiations will be taken seriously. </p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 29 Nov 2016 14:45:40 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"eb70291234f6d8e60cce809539da75aa","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694457},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"How long should a lockdown-relaxation cycle last?","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6468","description":"<h2>The adaptive-triggering policy.</h2>\n<p>On page 12 of <a href=\"https://www.imperial.ac.uk/media/imperial-college/medicine/sph/ide/gida-fellowships/Imperial-College-COVID19-NPI-modelling-16-03-2020.pdf\">a document put out by Imperial College London</a>, which has been very widely read and commented on, and which has had a significant influence on UK policy concerning the coronavirus, there is a diagram that shows the possible impact of a strategy of alternating between measures that are serious enough to cause the number of cases to decline, and more relaxed measures that allow it to grow again. They call this <em>adaptive triggering</em>: when the number of cases needing intensive care reaches a certain level per week, the stronger measures are triggered, and when it declines to some other level (the numbers they give are 100 and 50, respectively), they are lifted. </p>\n<p>If such a policy were ever to be enacted, a very important question would be how to optimize the choice of the two triggers. I&#8217;ve tried to work this out, subject to certain simplifying assumptions (and it&#8217;s important to stress right at the outset that these assumptions are questionable, and therefore that any conclusion I come to should be treated with great caution). This post is to show the calculation I did. It leads to slightly counterintuitive results, so part of my reason for posting it publicly is as a sanity check: I know that if I post it here, then any flaws in my reasoning will be quickly picked up. And the contrapositive of that statement is that if the reasoning survives the harsh scrutiny of a typical reader of this blog, then I can feel fairly confident about it. Of course, it may also be that I have failed to model some aspect of the situation that would make a material difference to the conclusions I draw. I would be very interested in criticisms of that kind too. (Indeed, I make some myself in the post.) </p>\n<p>Before I get on to what the model is, I would like to make clear that I am not <em>advocating</em> this adaptive-triggering policy. Personally, what I would like to see is something more like what Tomas Pueyo calls <a href=\"https://medium.com/@tomaspueyo/coronavirus-the-hammer-and-the-dance-be9337092b56\">The Hammer and the Dance</a>: roughly speaking, you get the cases down to a trickle, and then you stop that trickle turning back into a flood by stamping down hard on local outbreaks using a lot of testing, contact tracing, isolation of potential infected people, etc. (This would need to be combined with other measures such as quarantine for people arriving from more affected countries etc.) But it still seems worth thinking about the adaptive-triggering policy, in case the hammer-and-dance policy doesn&#8217;t work (which could be for the simple reason that a government decides not to implement it).<br />\n<span id=\"more-6468\"></span></p>\n<h2>A very basic model.</h2>\n<p>Here was my first attempt at modelling the situation. I make the following assumptions. The numbers <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S%2C+T%2C+%5Clambda%2C+%5Cmu&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S, T, &#92;lambda, &#92;mu\" title=\"S, T, &#92;lambda, &#92;mu\" class=\"latex\" /> are positive constants.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Relaxation is triggered when the rate of infection is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" />.</li>\n<li>Lockdown (or similar) is triggered when the rate of infection is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" />.</li>\n<li>The rate of infection is of the form <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Ae%5E%7B%5Clambda+t%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Ae^{&#92;lambda t}\" title=\"Ae^{&#92;lambda t}\" class=\"latex\" /> during a relaxation phase.</li>\n<li>The rate of infection is of the form <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Be%5E%7B-%5Cmu+t%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Be^{-&#92;mu t}\" title=\"Be^{-&#92;mu t}\" class=\"latex\" /> during a lockdown phase.</li>\n<li>The rate of &#8220;damage&#8221; due to infection is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta\" title=\"&#92;theta\" class=\"latex\" /> times the infection rate.</li>\n<li>The rate of damage due to lockdown measures is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ceta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;eta\" title=\"&#92;eta\" class=\"latex\" /> while those measures are in force.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>For the moment I am not concerned with how realistic these assumptions are, but just with what their consequences are. What I would like to do is minimize the average damage by choosing <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> appropriately.</p>\n<p>I may as well give away one of the punchlines straight away, since no calculation is needed to explain it. The time it takes for the infection rate to increase from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> or to decrease from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" /> depends only on the ratio <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T%2FS&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T/S\" title=\"T/S\" class=\"latex\" />. Therefore, if we divide both <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" /> by 2, we decrease the damage due to the infection and have no effect on the damage due to the lockdown measures. Thus, for any fixed ratio <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T%2FS&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T/S\" title=\"T/S\" class=\"latex\" />, it is best to make both <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" /> as small as possible.</p>\n<p>This has the counterintuitive consequence that during one of the cycles one would be imposing lockdown measures that were doing far more damage than the damage done by the virus itself. However, I think something like that may actually be correct: unless the triggers are so low that the assumptions of the model completely break down (for example because local containment is, at least for a while, a realistic policy, so national lockdown is pointlessly damaging), there is nothing to be lost, and lives to be gained, by keeping them in the same proportion but decreasing them. </p>\n<p>Now let me do the calculation, so that we can think about how to optimize the ratio <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T%2FS&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T/S\" title=\"T/S\" class=\"latex\" /> for a fixed <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>The time taken for the infection rate to increase from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s%3D%5Clambda%5E%7B-1%7D%5Clog%28T%2FS%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"s=&#92;lambda^{-1}&#92;log(T/S)\" title=\"s=&#92;lambda^{-1}&#92;log(T/S)\" class=\"latex\" />, and during that time the number of infections is<br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cint_0%5EsSe%5E%7B%5Clambda+t%7Ddt%3D%5Clambda%5E%7B-1%7DS%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda+s%7D-1%29%3D%5Clambda%5E%7B-1%7D%28T-S%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;int_0^sSe^{&#92;lambda t}dt=&#92;lambda^{-1}S(e^{&#92;lambda s}-1)=&#92;lambda^{-1}(T-S)\" title=\"&#92;int_0^sSe^{&#92;lambda t}dt=&#92;lambda^{-1}S(e^{&#92;lambda s}-1)=&#92;lambda^{-1}(T-S)\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>By symmetry the number of infections during the lockdown phase is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmu%5E%7B-1%7D%28T-S%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mu^{-1}(T-S)\" title=\"&#92;mu^{-1}(T-S)\" class=\"latex\" /> (just run time backwards). So during a time <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda%5E%7B-1%7D%2B%5Cmu%5E%7B-1%7D%29%5Clog%28T%2FS%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;lambda^{-1}+&#92;mu^{-1})&#92;log(T/S)\" title=\"(&#92;lambda^{-1}+&#92;mu^{-1})&#92;log(T/S)\" class=\"latex\" /> the damage done by infections is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta%28%5Clambda%5E%7B-1%7D%2B%5Cmu%5E%7B-1%7D%29%28T-S%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta(&#92;lambda^{-1}+&#92;mu^{-1})(T-S)\" title=\"&#92;theta(&#92;lambda^{-1}+&#92;mu^{-1})(T-S)\" class=\"latex\" />, making the average damage <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta%28T-S%29%2F%28%5Clog+T-%5Clog+S%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta(T-S)/(&#92;log T-&#92;log S)\" title=\"&#92;theta(T-S)/(&#92;log T-&#92;log S)\" class=\"latex\" />. Meanwhile, the average damage done by lockdown measures over the whole cycle is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmu%5E%7B-1%7D%5Ceta%2F%28%5Clambda%5E%7B-1%7D%2B%5Cmu%5E%7B-1%7D%29%3D%5Ceta%5Clambda%2F%28%5Clambda%2B%5Cmu%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mu^{-1}&#92;eta/(&#92;lambda^{-1}+&#92;mu^{-1})=&#92;eta&#92;lambda/(&#92;lambda+&#92;mu)\" title=\"&#92;mu^{-1}&#92;eta/(&#92;lambda^{-1}+&#92;mu^{-1})=&#92;eta&#92;lambda/(&#92;lambda+&#92;mu)\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>Note that the lockdown damage doesn&#8217;t depend on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" />: it just depends on the proportion of time spent in lockdown, which depends only on the ratio between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda\" title=\"&#92;lambda\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmu&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mu\" title=\"&#92;mu\" class=\"latex\" />. So from the point of view of optimizing <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" />, we can simply forget about the damage caused by the lockdown measures. </p>\n<p>Returning, therefore, to the term <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta%28T-S%29%2F%28%5Clog+T-%5Clog+S%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta(T-S)/(&#92;log T-&#92;log S)\" title=\"&#92;theta(T-S)/(&#92;log T-&#92;log S)\" class=\"latex\" />, let us say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T%3D%281%2B%5Calpha%29S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T=(1+&#92;alpha)S\" title=\"T=(1+&#92;alpha)S\" class=\"latex\" />. Then the term simplifies to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta%5Calpha+S%2F%5Clog%281%2B%5Calpha%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta&#92;alpha S/&#92;log(1+&#92;alpha)\" title=\"&#92;theta&#92;alpha S/&#92;log(1+&#92;alpha)\" class=\"latex\" />. This increases with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" />, which leads to a second counterintuitive conclusion, which is that for fixed <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S\" title=\"S\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> should be as close as possible to 0. So if, for example, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda%3D2%5Cmu&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda=2&#92;mu\" title=\"&#92;lambda=2&#92;mu\" class=\"latex\" />, which tells us that the lockdown phases have to be twice as long as the relaxation phases, then it would be better to have cycles of two days of lockdown and one of relaxation than cycles of six weeks of lockdown and three weeks of relaxation.</p>\n<p>Can this be correct? It seems as though with very short cycles the lockdowns wouldn&#8217;t work, because for one day in three people would be out there infecting others. I haven&#8217;t yet got my head round this, but I think what has gone wrong is that the model of exponential growth followed instantly by exponential decay is too great a simplification of what actually happens. Indeed, data seem to suggest a curve that rounds off at the top rather than switching suddenly from one exponential to another &#8212; see for example Chart 9 from the Tomas Pueyo article linked to above. But I think it is correct to conclude that the length of a cycle should be at most of a similar order of magnitude to the &#8220;turnaround time&#8221; from exponential growth to exponential decay. That is, one should make the cycles as short as possible provided that they are on a timescale that is long enough for the assumption of exponential growth followed by exponential decay to be reasonably accurate. </p>\n<h2>What if we allow a cycle with more than two kinds of phases?</h2>\n<p>So far I have treated <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda\" title=\"&#92;lambda\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmu&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mu\" title=\"&#92;mu\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ceta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;eta\" title=\"&#92;eta\" class=\"latex\" /> as parameters that we have no control over at all. But in practice that is not the case. At any one time there is a suite of measures one can take &#8212; encouraging frequent handwashing, banning large gatherings, closing schools, encouraging working from home wherever possible, closing pubs, restaurants, theatres and cinemas, enforcing full lockdown &#8212; that have different effects on the rate of growth or decline in infection and cause different levels of damage. </p>\n<p>It seems worth taking this into account too, especially as there has been a common pattern of introducing more and more measures as the number of cases goes up. That feels like a sensible response &#8212; intuitively one would think that the cure should be kept proportionate &#8212; but is it?</p>\n<p>Let&#8217;s suppose we have a collection of possible sets of measures <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_1%2C%5Cdots%2CM_r&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"M_1,&#92;dots,M_r\" title=\"M_1,&#92;dots,M_r\" class=\"latex\" />. For ease of writing I shall call them measures rather than sets of measures, but in practice each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"M_i\" title=\"M_i\" class=\"latex\" /> is not just a single measure but a combination of measures such as the ones listed above. Associated with each measure <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"M_i\" title=\"M_i\" class=\"latex\" /> is a growth rate <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_i\" title=\"&#92;lambda_i\" class=\"latex\" /> (which is positive if the measures are not strong enough to stop the disease growing and negative if they are strong enough to cause it to decay) and a damage rate <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ceta_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;eta_i\" title=\"&#92;eta_i\" class=\"latex\" />. Suppose we apply <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"M_i\" title=\"M_i\" class=\"latex\" /> for time <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t_i\" title=\"t_i\" class=\"latex\" />. Then during that time the rate of infection will multiply by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%5E%7B%5Clambda_it_i%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e^{&#92;lambda_it_i}\" title=\"e^{&#92;lambda_it_i}\" class=\"latex\" />. So if we do this for each measure, then we will get back to the starting infection rate provided that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_1t_1%2B%5Cdots%2B%5Clambda_rt_r%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_1t_1+&#92;dots+&#92;lambda_rt_r=0\" title=\"&#92;lambda_1t_1+&#92;dots+&#92;lambda_rt_r=0\" class=\"latex\" />. (This is possible because some of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_i\" title=\"&#92;lambda_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are negative and some are positive.) </p>\n<p>There isn&#8217;t a particularly nice expression for the damage resulting from the disease during one of these cycles, but that does not mean that there is nothing to say. Suppose that the starting rate of infection is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S_0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S_0\" title=\"S_0\" class=\"latex\" /> and that the rate after the first <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" /> stages of the cycle is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S_i\" title=\"S_i\" class=\"latex\" />. Then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=S_i%3De%5E%7B%5Clambda_it_i%7DS_%7Bi-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"S_i=e^{&#92;lambda_it_i}S_{i-1}\" title=\"S_i=e^{&#92;lambda_it_i}S_{i-1}\" class=\"latex\" />. Also, by the calculation above, the damage done during the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" />th stage is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta%5Clambda_i%5E%7B-1%7D%28S_i-S_%7Bi-1%7D%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta&#92;lambda_i^{-1}(S_i-S_{i-1})\" title=\"&#92;theta&#92;lambda_i^{-1}(S_i-S_{i-1})\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<h3>In what order should the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"M_i\" title=\"M_i\" class=\"latex\" /> be applied?</h3>\n<p>This has an immediate consequence for the order in which the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"M_i\" title=\"M_i\" class=\"latex\" /> should be applied. Let me consider just the first two stages. The total damage caused by the disease during these two stages is  </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta%28%5Clambda_1%5E%7B-1%7D%28S_1-S_0%29%2B%5Clambda_2%5E%7B-1%7D%28S_2-S_1%29%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta(&#92;lambda_1^{-1}(S_1-S_0)+&#92;lambda_2^{-1}(S_2-S_1))\" title=\"&#92;theta(&#92;lambda_1^{-1}(S_1-S_0)+&#92;lambda_2^{-1}(S_2-S_1))\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%3D%5Ctheta+S_0%28%5Clambda_1%5E%7B-1%7D%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda_1t_1%7D-1%29%2B%5Clambda_2%5E%7B-1%7De%5E%7B%5Clambda_1t_1%7D%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda_2t_2%7D-1%29%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"=&#92;theta S_0(&#92;lambda_1^{-1}(e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}-1)+&#92;lambda_2^{-1}e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}(e^{&#92;lambda_2t_2}-1))\" title=\"=&#92;theta S_0(&#92;lambda_1^{-1}(e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}-1)+&#92;lambda_2^{-1}e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}(e^{&#92;lambda_2t_2}-1))\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>To make that easier to read, let&#8217;s forget the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta+S_0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta S_0\" title=\"&#92;theta S_0\" class=\"latex\" /> term (which we&#8217;re holding constant) and concentrate on the expression</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_1%5E%7B-1%7D%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda_1t_1%7D-1%29%2B%5Clambda_2%5E%7B-1%7De%5E%7B%5Clambda_1t_1%7D%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda_2t_2%7D-1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_1^{-1}(e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}-1)+&#92;lambda_2^{-1}e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}(e^{&#92;lambda_2t_2}-1)\" title=\"&#92;lambda_1^{-1}(e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}-1)+&#92;lambda_2^{-1}e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}(e^{&#92;lambda_2t_2}-1)\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>If we reorder stages 1 and 2, we can replace this damage by</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_2%5E%7B-1%7D%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda_2t_2%7D-1%29%2B%5Clambda_1%5E%7B-1%7De%5E%7B%5Clambda_2t_1%7D%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda_1t_2%7D-1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_2^{-1}(e^{&#92;lambda_2t_2}-1)+&#92;lambda_1^{-1}e^{&#92;lambda_2t_1}(e^{&#92;lambda_1t_2}-1)\" title=\"&#92;lambda_2^{-1}(e^{&#92;lambda_2t_2}-1)+&#92;lambda_1^{-1}e^{&#92;lambda_2t_1}(e^{&#92;lambda_1t_2}-1)\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>This is an improvement if the second number is smaller than the first. But the first minus the second is equal to</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda_2%5E%7B-1%7D-%5Clambda_1%5E%7B-1%7D%29%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda_1t_1%7D-1%29%28e%5E%7B%5Clambda_2t_2%7D-1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;lambda_2^{-1}-&#92;lambda_1^{-1})(e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}-1)(e^{&#92;lambda_2t_2}-1)\" title=\"(&#92;lambda_2^{-1}-&#92;lambda_1^{-1})(e^{&#92;lambda_1t_1}-1)(e^{&#92;lambda_2t_2}-1)\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>so the reordering is a good idea if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_1%3E%5Clambda_2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_1&#62;&#92;lambda_2\" title=\"&#92;lambda_1&#62;&#92;lambda_2\" class=\"latex\" />. This tells us that we should start with smaller <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_i\" title=\"&#92;lambda_i\" class=\"latex\" /> and work up to bigger ones. Of course, since we are applying the measures in a cycle, we cannot ensure that the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_i\" title=\"&#92;lambda_i\" class=\"latex\" /> form an increasing sequence, but we can say, for example, that if we first apply the measures that allow the disease to spread, and then the ones that get it to decay, then during the relaxation phase we should work from the least relaxed measures to the most relaxed ones (so the growth rate will keep increasing), and during the suppression phase we should start with the strictest measures and work down to the most relaxed ones.</p>\n<p>It might seem strange that during the relaxation phase the measures should get gradually more relaxed as the spread worsens. In fact, I think it <em>is</em> strange, but I think what that strangeness is telling us is that using several different measures during the relaxation phase is not a sensible thing to do.</p>\n<h3>Which sets of measures should be chosen?</h3>\n<p>The optimization problem I get if I try to balance the damage from the disease with the damage caused by the various control measures is fairly horrible, so I am going to simplify it a lot in the following way. The basic principle that there is nothing to be lost by dividing everything by 2 still applies when there are lots of measures, so I shall assume that a sensible government has taken that point on board to the point where the direct damage from the disease is insignificant compared with the damage caused by the measures. (Just to be clear, I certainly don&#8217;t mean that lives lost are insignificant, but I mean that the number of lives lost to the disease is significantly smaller than the number lost as an indirect result of the measures taken to control its spread.) Given this assumption, I am free to concentrate just on the damage due to the measures <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=M_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"M_i\" title=\"M_i\" class=\"latex\" />, so this is what I will try to minimize.</p>\n<p>The total damage across a full cycle is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_i%5Ceta_it_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_it_i\" title=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_it_i\" class=\"latex\" />, so the average damage, which is what matters here, is </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac%7B%5Ceta_1t_1%2B%5Ceta_2t_2%2B%5Cdots%2B%5Ceta_rt_r%7D%7Bt_1%2Bt_2%2B%5Cdots%2Bt_r%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;frac{&#92;eta_1t_1+&#92;eta_2t_2+&#92;dots+&#92;eta_rt_r}{t_1+t_2+&#92;dots+t_r}\" title=\"&#92;frac{&#92;eta_1t_1+&#92;eta_2t_2+&#92;dots+&#92;eta_rt_r}{t_1+t_2+&#92;dots+t_r}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>We don&#8217;t have complete freedom to choose, or else we&#8217;d obviously just choose the smallest <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ceta_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;eta_i\" title=\"&#92;eta_i\" class=\"latex\" /> and go with that. The constraint is that the growth rate of the virus has to end up where it began: this is the constraint that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_1t_1%2B%5Cdots%2B%5Clambda_rt_r%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_1t_1+&#92;dots+&#92;lambda_rt_r=0\" title=\"&#92;lambda_1t_1+&#92;dots+&#92;lambda_rt_r=0\" class=\"latex\" />, which we saw earlier.</p>\n<p>Suppose we can find <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cs_r&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"s_1,&#92;dots,s_r\" title=\"s_1,&#92;dots,s_r\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_is_i%3D%5Csum_i%5Clambda_is_i%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_is_i=&#92;sum_i&#92;lambda_is_i=0\" title=\"&#92;sum_is_i=&#92;sum_i&#92;lambda_is_i=0\" class=\"latex\" />, but <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_i%5Ceta_is_i%5Cne+0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_is_i&#92;ne 0\" title=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_is_i&#92;ne 0\" class=\"latex\" />. Then in particular we can find such <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cs_r&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"s_1,&#92;dots,s_r\" title=\"s_1,&#92;dots,s_r\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_i%5Ceta_is_i%3C0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_is_i&#60;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_is_i&#60;0\" class=\"latex\" />. If all the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t_i\" title=\"t_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are strictly positive, then we can also choose them in such a way that all the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_i%2Bs_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t_i+s_i\" title=\"t_i+s_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are still strictly positive. So if we replace each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t_i\" title=\"t_i\" class=\"latex\" /> by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_i-s_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t_i-s_i\" title=\"t_i-s_i\" class=\"latex\" />, then the numerator of the fraction decreases, the denominator stays the same, and the constraint is still satisfied. It follows that we had not optimized.</p>\n<p>Therefore, if the choice of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ct_r&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t_1,&#92;dots,t_r\" title=\"t_1,&#92;dots,t_r\" class=\"latex\" /> is optimal and all the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=t_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"t_i\" title=\"t_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are non-zero (and therefore strictly positive &#8212; we can&#8217;t run some measures for a negative amount of time) it is not possible to find <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=s_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cs_r&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"s_1,&#92;dots,s_r\" title=\"s_1,&#92;dots,s_r\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_is_i%3D%5Csum_i%5Clambda_is_i%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_is_i=&#92;sum_i&#92;lambda_is_i=0\" title=\"&#92;sum_is_i=&#92;sum_i&#92;lambda_is_i=0\" class=\"latex\" />, but <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_i%5Ceta_is_i%5Cne+0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_is_i&#92;ne 0\" title=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_is_i&#92;ne 0\" class=\"latex\" />. This is equivalent to the statement that the vector <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Ceta_1%2C%5Cdots%2C%5Ceta_r%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;eta_1,&#92;dots,&#92;eta_r)\" title=\"(&#92;eta_1,&#92;dots,&#92;eta_r)\" class=\"latex\" /> is a linear combination of the vectors <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281%2C1%2C%5Cdots%2C1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(1,1,&#92;dots,1)\" title=\"(1,1,&#92;dots,1)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda_1%2C%5Cdots%2C%5Clambda_r%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;lambda_1,&#92;dots,&#92;lambda_r)\" title=\"(&#92;lambda_1,&#92;dots,&#92;lambda_r)\" class=\"latex\" />. In other words, we can find <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csigma%2C%5Crho&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sigma,&#92;rho\" title=\"&#92;sigma,&#92;rho\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ceta_i%3D%5Csigma-%5Crho%5Clambda_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;eta_i=&#92;sigma-&#92;rho&#92;lambda_i\" title=\"&#92;eta_i=&#92;sigma-&#92;rho&#92;lambda_i\" class=\"latex\" /> for each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" />. I wrote it like that because the smaller <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_i\" title=\"&#92;lambda_i\" class=\"latex\" /> is, the larger the damage one expects the measures to cause. Thus, the points form a descending sequence. (We can assume this, since if one measure causes both more damage and a higher growth rate than another, then there can be no reason to choose it.) Thus, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Crho&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;rho\" title=\"&#92;rho\" class=\"latex\" /> will be positive, and since at least some <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda_i\" title=\"&#92;lambda_i\" class=\"latex\" /> are positive, and no measures will cause a <em>negative</em> amount of damage, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csigma&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sigma\" title=\"&#92;sigma\" class=\"latex\" /> is positive as well.</p>\n<p>The converse of this statement is true as well. If <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ceta_i%3D%5Csigma-%5Crho%5Clambda_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;eta_i=&#92;sigma-&#92;rho&#92;lambda_i\" title=\"&#92;eta_i=&#92;sigma-&#92;rho&#92;lambda_i\" class=\"latex\" /> for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" />, then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_i%5Ceta_it_i%3D%5Csigma%5Csum_it_i-%5Crho%5Csum_i%5Clambda_it_i%3D%5Csigma%5Csum_it_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_it_i=&#92;sigma&#92;sum_it_i-&#92;rho&#92;sum_i&#92;lambda_it_i=&#92;sigma&#92;sum_it_i\" title=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;eta_it_i=&#92;sigma&#92;sum_it_i-&#92;rho&#92;sum_i&#92;lambda_it_i=&#92;sigma&#92;sum_it_i\" class=\"latex\" />, from which it follows that the average damage across the cycle is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csigma&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sigma\" title=\"&#92;sigma\" class=\"latex\" />, regardless of which measures are taken for which lengths of time. </p>\n<p>This already shows that there is nothing to be gained from having more than one measure for the relaxation phase and one for the lockdown phase. There remains the question of how to choose the best pair of measures.</p>\n<p>To answer it, we can plot the points <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda_i%2C%5Ceta_i%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;lambda_i,&#92;eta_i)\" title=\"(&#92;lambda_i,&#92;eta_i)\" class=\"latex\" />. The relaxation points will appear to the right of the y-axis and the suppression points will appear to the left. If we choose one point from each side, then they lie in some line <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%3D%5Csigma-%5Crho+x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y=&#92;sigma-&#92;rho x\" title=\"y=&#92;sigma-&#92;rho x\" class=\"latex\" />, of which <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csigma&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sigma\" title=\"&#92;sigma\" class=\"latex\" /> is the intercept. Since <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csigma&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sigma\" title=\"&#92;sigma\" class=\"latex\" /> is the average damage, which we are trying to minimize, we see that our aim is to find a line segment joining a point on the left-hand side to a point on the right-hand side, and we want it to cross the y-axis as low as possible. </p>\n<p>It is not hard to check that the intercept of the line joining <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28-%5Cmu%2C%5Cxi%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(-&#92;mu,&#92;xi)\" title=\"(-&#92;mu,&#92;xi)\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda%2C%5Ceta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;lambda,&#92;eta)\" title=\"(&#92;lambda,&#92;eta)\" class=\"latex\" /> is at <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac%7B%5Cmu%5Cxi%2B%5Clambda%5Ceta%7D%7B%5Cmu%2B%5Clambda%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;frac{&#92;mu&#92;xi+&#92;lambda&#92;eta}{&#92;mu+&#92;lambda}\" title=\"&#92;frac{&#92;mu&#92;xi+&#92;lambda&#92;eta}{&#92;mu+&#92;lambda}\" class=\"latex\" />. So if we rename the points to the left of the y-axis <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28-%5Cmu_i%2C%5Cxi_i%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(-&#92;mu_i,&#92;xi_i)\" title=\"(-&#92;mu_i,&#92;xi_i)\" class=\"latex\" /> and the points to the right <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda_j%2C%5Ceta_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;lambda_j,&#92;eta_j)\" title=\"(&#92;lambda_j,&#92;eta_j)\" class=\"latex\" />, then we want to minimize <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac%7B%5Cmu_i%5Cxi_i%2B%5Clambda_j%5Ceta_j%7D%7B%5Cmu_i%2B%5Clambda_j%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;frac{&#92;mu_i&#92;xi_i+&#92;lambda_j&#92;eta_j}{&#92;mu_i+&#92;lambda_j}\" title=\"&#92;frac{&#92;mu_i&#92;xi_i+&#92;lambda_j&#92;eta_j}{&#92;mu_i+&#92;lambda_j}\" class=\"latex\" /> over all <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i%2Cj&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i,j\" title=\"i,j\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<h3>Can we describe the best choice in a less formal way?</h3>\n<p>It isn&#8217;t completely easy to convert this criterion into a rule of thumb for how best to choose two measures, one for the relaxation phase and one for the suppression phase, but we can draw a couple of conclusions from it.</p>\n<p>For example, suppose that for the suppression measures there is a choice between two measures, one of which works twice as quickly as the other but causes twice as much damage per unit time. Then the corresponding two points lie on a line with negative gradient that goes through the origin, and therefore lies below all points in the positive quadrant. From this it follows that the slower but less damaging measure is better. Another way of seeing that is that with the more severe measure the total damage during the lockdown phase stays the same, as does the total damage during the relaxation phase, but the length of the cycle is decreased, so the <em>average</em> damage is increased. </p>\n<p>Note that I am not saying that one should always go for less severe measures &#8212; I made the strong assumption there that the two points lay in a line through the origin. If we can choose a measure that causes damage at double the rate but acts three times as quickly as another measure, then it may turn out to be better than the less damaging but slower measure.</p>\n<p>However, it seems plausible that the set of points will exhibit a certain amount of convexity. That is because if you want to reduce the growth rate of infections, then at first there will be some low-hanging fruit &#8212; for example, it is not costly at all to run a public-information campaign to persuade people to wash their hands more frequently, and that can make quite a big difference &#8212; but the more you continue, the more difficult making a significant difference becomes, and you have to wheel out much more damaging measures such as school closures.</p>\n<p><em>If</em> the points were to lie on a convex curve (and I&#8217;m definitely not claiming this, but just saying that something like it could perhaps be true), then the best pair of points would be the ones that are nearest to the y-axis on either side. This would say that the best strategy is to alternate between a set of measures that allows the disease to grow rather slowly and a set of measures that causes it to decay slowly again. </p>\n<p>This last conclusion points up another defect in the model, which is the assumption that a given set of measures causes damage at a constant rate. For some measures, this is not very realistic: for example, even in normal times schools alternate between periods of being closed and periods of being open (though not necessarily to a coronavirus-dictated timetable of course), so one might expect the damage from schools being 100% closed to be more than twice the damage from schools being closed half the time. More generally, it might well be better to rotate between two or three measures that all cause roughly the same rate of damage, but in different ways, so as to spread out the damage and try to avoid reaching the point where the rate of one kind of damage goes up.</p>\n<h2>Summary of conclusions.</h2>\n<p>Again I want to stress that these conclusions are all quite tentative, and should certainly not be taken as a guide to policy without more thought and more sophisticated modelling. However, they do at least <em>suggest</em> that certain policies ought not to be ruled out without a good reason. </p>\n<p>If adaptive triggering is going to be applied, then the following are the policies that the above analysis suggests. First, here is a quick reminder that I use the word &#8220;measure&#8221; as shorthand for &#8220;set of measures&#8221;. So for example &#8220;Encourage social distancing and close all schools, pubs, restaurants, theatres, and cinemas&#8221; would be a possible measure.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>There is nothing to lose and plenty to gain by making the triggers (that is, the infection rates that cause one to switch from relaxation to suppression and back again) low. This has the consequence that the triggers should be set in such a way that the damage from the measures is significantly higher than the damage caused by the disease. This sounds paradoxical, but the alternative is to make the disease worse without making the cure any less bad, and there is no point in doing that.</li>\n<li>Within reason, the cycles should be kept short.</li>\n<li>There is no point in having more than one measure for the relaxation phase and one for the suppression phase.</li>\n<li>If you must have more than one measure for each phase, then during the relaxation phase the measures should get more relaxed each time they change, and during the suppression phase they should get less strict each time they change.</li>\n<li>Given enough information about their consequences, the optimal measures can be determined quite easily, but doing the calculation in practice, especially in the presence of significant uncertainties, could be quite delicate.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Point number 1 above seems to me to be quite a strong argument in favour of the hammer-and-dance approach. That is because the conclusion, which looks to me quite robust to changes in the model, is that the triggers should be set very low. But if they are set very low, then it is highly unlikely that the enormous damage caused by school closures, lockdowns etc. is the best approach for dealing with the cases that arise, since widespread testing and quarantining of people who test positive, contacts of those people, people who arrive from certain other countries, and so on, will probably be far less damaging, even if they are costly to do well. So I regard point number 1 as a sort of reductio ad absurdum of the adaptive-triggering approach.</p>\n<p>Point number 2 seems quite robust as well, but I think the model breaks down on small timescales (for reasons I haven&#8217;t properly understood), so one shouldn&#8217;t conclude from it that the cycles should be short on a timescale of days. That is what is meant by &#8220;within reason&#8221;. But they should be as short as possible provided that they are long enough for the dominant behaviour of the infection rate to be exponential growth and decay. (That does not imply that they should not be shorter than this &#8212; just that one cannot reach that conclusion without a more sophisticated model. But it seems highly likely that there is a minimum &#8220;reasonable&#8221; length for a cycle: this is something I&#8217;d be very interested to understand better.) </p>\n<p>Point number 3 was a clear consequence of the simple model (though it depended on taking 1 seriously enough that the damage from the disease could be ignored), but may well not be a sensible conclusion in reality, since the assumption that each measure causes damage at a rate that does not change over time is highly questionable, and dropping that assumption could make quite a big difference. Nevertheless, it is interesting to see what the consequences of that assumption are. </p>\n<p>Point number 4 seems to be another fairly robust conclusion. However, in the light of 3 one might hope that it would not need to be applied, except perhaps as part of a policy of &#8220;rotating&#8221; between various measures to spread the damage about more evenly.</p>\n<p>It seems at least possible that the optimal adaptive-triggering policy, if one had a number of choices of measures, would be to choose one set that causes the infections to grow slowly and another that causes them to shrink slowly &#8212; in other words to fine tune the measures so as to keep the infection rate roughly constant (and small). Such fine tuning would be very dangerous to attempt now, given how much uncertainty we are facing, but could become more realistic after a few cycles, when we would start to have more information about the effects of various measures.  </p>\n<p>One final point is that throughout this discussion I have been assuming that the triggers would be based on the current rate of infection. In practice of course, this is hard to measure, which is presumably why the Imperial College paper used demand for intensive care beds instead. However, with enough data about the effects of various measures on the rate of spread of the virus, one would be less reliant on direct measurements, and could instead make inferences about the likely rate of infection given data collected over the previous few weeks. This seems better than using demand for ICU beds as a trigger, since that demand reflects the infection rate from some time earlier.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 28 Mar 2020 =0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn4@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-18-100_0aab5206c1cf8d01.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Ceta_1%2C%5Cdots%2C%5Ceta_r%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn47@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-24-229_df954591963ae7c6.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281%2C1%2C%5Cdots%2C1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn7@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-22-014_5f5e75ce2cd4ead2.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda_1%2C%5Cdots%2C%5Clambda_r%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn67@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-18-379_ffcc2d8e490648b0.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csigma%2C%5Crho&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn72@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-23-916_17ff14ddc72a8b02.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ceta_i%3D%5Csigma-%5Crho%5Clambda_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn55@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-19-110_f438b1b888b50886.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Crho&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-19-283_25909bf8adc8431c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csigma&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn8@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-19-018_594aa67ccd1f7433.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_i%5Ceta_it_i%3D%5Csigma%5Csum_it_i-%5Crho%5Csum_i%5Clambda_it_i%3D%5Csigma%5Csum_it_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-20-201_766eb33c378a386b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda_i%2C%5Ceta_i%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn71@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-25-184_fc9af4b314bcbdcf.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%3D%5Csigma-%5Crho+x&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn14@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-27-985_c821305ba9e6eb73.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28-%5Cmu%2C%5Cxi%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn19@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-17-016_f597851a80487c37.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda%2C%5Ceta%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn41@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-30-979_5502ad244ff97281.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac%7B%5Cmu%5Cxi%2B%5Clambda%5Ceta%7D%7B%5Cmu%2B%5Clambda%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-20-124_eae93dc89c042ecd.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28-%5Cmu_i%2C%5Cxi_i%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn53@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-27-574_77c6a118543580ea.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Clambda_j%2C%5Ceta_j%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn34@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-32-148_1b80a3ba913263c7.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac%7B%5Cmu_i%5Cxi_i%2B%5Clambda_j%5Ceta_j%7D%7B%5Cmu_i%2B%5Clambda_j%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn16@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-18-969_d23382e5150e8f92.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i%2Cj&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-20-136_55c8bfb82857d15d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694451},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"How Craig Barton wishes heâ€™d taught maths","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6435","description":"<p>A couple of months ago, I can&#8217;t remember precisely how, I became aware of a book called How I Wish I&#8217;d Taught Maths, by Craig Barton, that seemed to be highly thought of. The basic idea was that Craig Barton is an experienced, and by the sound of things very good, maths teacher who used to take a number of aspects of teaching for granted, until he looked into the mathematics-education literature and came to realize that many of his cherished beliefs were completely wrong. Since I&#8217;ve always been interested in the question of how best to teach mathematics, both because of my own university teaching and because from time to time I like to pontificate about school-level teaching, I decided to order the book. More surprisingly, given my past history of buying books that I felt I ought to read, I read it from cover to cover, all 450 pages of it.</p>\n<p>As it happens, the book is ideally designed for people who <em>don&#8217;t</em> necessarily want to read it from cover to cover, because it is arranged as follows. At the top level it is divided into chapters. Each chapter starts with a small introduction and thereafter is divided into sections. And each section has precisely the same organization: it is divided into subsections entitled, &#8220;What I used to believe&#8221;, &#8220;Sources of inspiration&#8221;, &#8220;My takeaway&#8221;, and &#8220;What I do now&#8221;. These are reasonably self-explanatory, but just to spell it out, the first subsection sets out a plausible belief that Craig Barton used to have about good teaching practice, often ending with a rhetorical question such as &#8220;What could possibly be wrong with that?&#8221;, the second is a list of references (none of which I have yet followed up, but some of them look very interesting), the third is a discussion of what he learned from the references, and the last one is about how he put that into practice. Also, each chapter ends with a short subsection entitled &#8220;If I only remember three things &#8230;&#8221;, where he gives three sentences that sum up what he thinks is most important in the chapter.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6435\"></span></p>\n<p>One question I had in the back of my mind when reading the book was whether any of it applied to teaching at university level. I&#8217;m still not sure what I think about that. There is a reason to think not, because the focus of the book is very much on school-level teaching, and many of the challenges that arise do not have obvious analogues at university level. For example, he mentioned (on page 235) the following fascinating experiment, where people were asked to do the following multiple-choice question and then justify their answers.</p>\n<p><em>Which of these values could not represent a probability?</em></p>\n<p>A. 2/3 </p>\n<p>B. 0.72315</p>\n<p>C. 1.46</p>\n<p>D. 0.002</p>\n<p>Let me quote the book itself for a discussion of this question.</p>\n<blockquote><p>Surely the rule <em>probabilities must be less than or equal to 1</em> is about as straightforward as it gets in maths? But why, then, did 47% of the 5000+ students who answered this question get it wrong?</p>\n<p>A few students&#8217; explanations reveal all:</p>\n<p><em>I think B because it&#8217;s just a massive decimal and the rest look pretty legit. I also don&#8217;t see how a number that big could be correct.</em></p>\n<p><em>I think B because you wouldn&#8217;t see this in probability questions.</em></p>\n<p><em>I think D because you can&#8217;t have 0.002 as an answer because it is too low.</em></p>\n<p>If students are only used to meeting `nice-looking&#8217; probabilities during examples and practice questions, then it is little surprise they come a cropper when they encounter strange-looking answers.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Could one devise a university-level question that would catch a significant proportion of people out in a similar way? I&#8217;m not sure, but here&#8217;s an attempt.</p>\n<p><em>Which of the following is not a vector space with the obvious notions of addition and scalar multiplication?</em></p>\n<p>A. The set of all complex numbers.</p>\n<p>B. The set of all functions from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%280%2C1%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(0,1)\" title=\"(0,1)\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb R\" title=\"&#92;mathbb R\" class=\"latex\" /> that are twice differentiable.</p>\n<p>C. The set of all polynomials in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> with real coefficients that have <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2Bx%2B1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x^2+x+1\" title=\"x^2+x+1\" class=\"latex\" /> as a factor.</p>\n<p>D. The set of all triples <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a%2Cb%2Cc%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(a,b,c)\" title=\"(a,b,c)\" class=\"latex\" /> of integers.</p>\n<p>E. The set of all sequences <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cx_n%29%5Cin%5Cmathbb+R%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x_1,&#92;dots,x_n)&#92;in&#92;mathbb R^n\" title=\"(x_1,&#92;dots,x_n)&#92;in&#92;mathbb R^n\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%2B%5Cdots%2Bx_n%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_1+&#92;dots+x_n=0\" title=\"x_1+&#92;dots+x_n=0\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%2B2x_2%2B%5Cdots%2Bnx_n%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x_1+2x_2+&#92;dots+nx_n=0\" title=\"x_1+2x_2+&#92;dots+nx_n=0\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>I think at Cambridge almost everyone would get this question right (though I&#8217;d love to do the experiment). But Cambridge mathematics undergraduates have been selected specifically to study mathematics. Perhaps at a US university, before people have chosen their majors, people might be tempted to choose another option (such as B, because vector spaces are to do with algebra and not calculus), while not noting that the obvious scalars in D do not form a field. Or perhaps they wouldn&#8217;t like A because the scalar field is the same as the set of vectors (unless, that is, they thought that the obvious scalars were the real numbers).</p>\n<p>More generally, I feel that there are certain kinds of mistakes that are commonly made at school level that are much less common at university level simply because those who survive long enough to reach that stage have been trained not to make them. For example, at university level we become used to formal definitions. Once one is in the habit of using these, deciding whether a structure is a vector space is simply a question of seeing whether the definition of a vector space applies, rather than thinking &#8220;Hmm, does that look like the vector spaces I&#8217;ve met up to now?&#8221; We also become part of a culture where it is common to look at pathological, or at least slightly surprising, examples of concepts, and so on.</p>\n<p>Another reason I decided to read the book was that I have certain prejudices about the teaching of mathematics at school level and I was interested to know whether they would be reinforced by the book or challenged by it. This was a win-win situation, since it is always nice to have one&#8217;s prejudices confirmed, but also rather exhilarating to find out that something that seems obviously correct is in fact wrong.</p>\n<p>A prejudice that was strongly confirmed was the value of mathematical fluency. Barton says, and I agree with him (and suggested something like it in my book Mathematics, A Very Short Introduction) that it is often a good idea to teach fluency first and understanding later. More precisely, in order to decide whether it is a good idea, one should assess (i) how difficult it is to give an explanation of why some procedure works and (ii) how difficult it is to learn how to apply the procedure without understanding why it works.</p>\n<p>For instance, suppose you want to teach multiplication of negative numbers. The rule &#8220;If they have the same sign then the answer is positive, and if they have different signs then the answer is negative&#8221; is a short and straightforward rule, but explaining why -2 times -3 should equal 6 is not very straightforward. So if one begins with the explanation, there is a big risk of conveying the idea that multiplication of negative numbers is a difficult, complicated topic, whereas if one gives plenty of practice in applying the simple rules, then one gives one&#8217;s students fluency in an operation that comes up in many other contexts (such as, for instance, multiplying <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x-2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x-2)\" title=\"(x-2)\" class=\"latex\" /> by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x-3%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(x-3)\" title=\"(x-3)\" class=\"latex\" />), and one can try to justify the rule later, when they are comfortable with the rule itself. I remember enjoying the challenge of thinking about why the rule for dividing one fraction by another was correct, but that was long after I was happy with using the rule itself. I don&#8217;t remember being bothered by the lack of justification up to that point.</p>\n<p>As an example in the other direction, Barton gives that of solving linear equations. The danger here is that one can learn a procedure for solving equations such as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2x%2B3%3D17&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"2x+3=17\" title=\"2x+3=17\" class=\"latex\" />, get good at it, and then be completely stuck when faced with an equation such as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=4-2x%3D3x-11&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"4-2x=3x-11\" title=\"4-2x=3x-11\" class=\"latex\" />. Here a bit of understanding can greatly help. Barton advocates something called the balance method, where one imagines both sides of the equation on a balance, and one is required to make sure that balance is maintained the whole time. I think (but without too much confidence after reading this book) that I would go for something roughly equivalent, but not quite the same, which is to stress the rule <em>you can do the same thing to both sides of an equation</em> (worrying about things like squaring both sides or multiplying by zero later). Then the problem of solving linear equations would be reduced to a kind of puzzle: what can we do to both sides of this equation to make the whole thing look simpler? </p>\n<p>That last question is related to another fascinating nugget that is mentioned in the book. Barton gives an example of a question concerning a parallelogram ABCD, where the angle at A is 105 degrees. The line BC is extended to a point E, which is then joined by an additional line segment to D, and the angle CED is 30 degrees. The question is to prove that the triangle CED is isosceles.</p>\n<p>Apparently, this question is found hard, because one cannot achieve the goal in one step. Instead, one must observe that the angle of the parallelogram at C is also 105 degrees, from which it follows that the angle ECD is 75 degrees. And from that it follows that the angle EDC is 75 degrees as well, and the problem is solved.</p>\n<p>But the interesting thing is that if you change the question to the more open-ended question, &#8220;Fill in as many angles in this diagram as you can,&#8221; then many people who found the goal-oriented version too hard have no difficulty in filling out all the angles in the diagram and therefore noticing that the triangle CED is isosceles.</p>\n<p>The lesson I would draw from this with the equations question is that instead of asking for a solution to the equation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=4-2x%3D3x-11&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"4-2x=3x-11\" title=\"4-2x=3x-11\" class=\"latex\" />, it might be better to ask &#8220;See whether you can make the equation look simpler by doing something to both sides. If you manage, see if you can then make it even simpler. Keep going until you have made it as simple as you can.&#8221; This would of course come after they had already seen several examples of the kind of thing one can do to both sides of an equation.</p>\n<p>Barton isn&#8217;t content with just telling the reader that certain methods of teaching are better than others: he also tells us the theory behind them. Of particular importance, he claims, is the fact that we cannot hold very much in our short-term memory. This was music to my ears, as it has long been a belief of mine that the limited capacity of our short-term memory is a hugely important part of the answer to the question of why mathematics looks as it does, by which I mean why, out of all the well-formed mathematical statements one could produce, the ones we find interesting are those particular ones. I have even written about this (in an article entitled Mathematics, Memory and Mental Arithmetic, which unfortunately appeared in a book and is not available online, but I might try to do something about that at some point). </p>\n<p>This basic point informs a lot of the discussion in the book. Consider, for example, a question that asked you to find the perimeter of a rectangle that had side lengths 2/3 and 3/5. This could be a great question, but it is very important to ask it at the right point in the students&#8217; development. If you ask it before they are fluent at adding fractions and at working out perimeters of rectangles, then the amount they have to hold in their heads may well exceed their cognitive capacity: they need to store the fact that you have to add the two lengths, and multiply by 2, and put both fractions over a common denominator. It is to avoid this kind of strain that attaining fluency is so important: it literally makes it easier to think, and in particular to solve the kind of interesting problems we would all like them to be able to solve. Barton absolutely doesn&#8217;t dispute the value of interesting problems that mix different parts of mathematics &#8212; he just argues, very convincingly, that one has to be careful when to introduce them.</p>\n<p>An idea he discusses a lot, and that I think might perhaps have a role to play in university-level teaching, is what he calls diagnostic questions, and in particular low-stakes diagnostic tests. These typically take the form of a short multiple-choice quiz, and he tries very hard to create a classroom culture where people understand that the purpose of the quiz is not assessment &#8212; the quizzes do not &#8220;count&#8221; for anything &#8212; but a tool to help learning, and in particular to help diagnose problems with understanding.</p>\n<p>What makes these questions &#8220;diagnostic&#8221; is that they are carefully designed in such a way that if you have a certain misconception, then you will be drawn towards a certain wrong answer. That is, the wrong answers people give are informative for the teacher, rather than merely wrong. Here, for example, is a question that fails to be diagnostic followed by a modified version that succeeds. </p>\n<p><em>A triangle has one side of length 6 and two sides of length 5. What is its area?</em></p>\n<p>A. 8<br />\nB. 11<br />\nC. 12<br />\nD. 15<br />\nE. 20</p>\n<p>A. 6<br />\nB. 12<br />\nC. 15<br />\nD. 16<br />\nE. 24<br />\nF. 30</p>\n<p>With the second set of choices, each answer has a potential route that one can imagine somebody taking. To obtain the answer 6, one chops the triangle into two right-angled triangles, each of height 4 and base 3, calculates the area of one of them, and forgets to double it. The correct answer is 12. To obtain 15, one takes the formula &#8220;half the height times the base&#8221; but substitutes in 5 for the height. To obtain 16 one calculates the perimeter. To obtain the answer 24 one takes the height times the base. And to obtain the answer 30 one multiplies the two numbers 6 and 5 together (on the grounds that &#8220;to calculate the area you multiply the two numbers together&#8221;). Thus, wrong answers yield useful information. With the first set of answers, that just isn&#8217;t the case &#8212; they are much more likely to be the result of pure guesswork.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s worth mentioning that Terence Tao has created <a href=\"http://scherk.pbworks.com/w/page/14864181/FrontPage\">a number of multiple-choice quizzes</a> on university-level topics. He has also <a href=\"https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2008/12/14/on-multiple-choice-questions-in-mathematics/\">blogged about it here</a>. They are not exactly diagnostic in the sense Barton is talking about, but one could imagine trying to make them so.</p>\n<p>Barton uses these diagnostic tests to get a much clearer picture of what his class already understands, before he launches into the discussion of some new topic, than he would by simply asking questions to the class and getting answers from a few keen students. If he diagnoses a fairly serious collective misunderstanding, then he will spend time dealing with that, rather than pointlessly trying to build on shaky foundations.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;m jumping around a bit here, but a semi-counterintuitive idea that he advocates, which is apparently backed up by serious research, is what he calls pretesting. This means testing people on material that they have not yet been taught. As long as this is done carefully, so that it doesn&#8217;t put students off completely, this turns out to be very valuable, because it prepares the brain to be receptive to the idea that will help to solve that pesky problem. And indeed, after a moment of getting used to the idea, I found it not counterintuitive at all. In fact, it resonates very strongly with my experience as a research mathematician: I find reading other people&#8217;s papers very difficult as a rule, but if they can help me solve a problem I&#8217;m working on, a lot of that difficulty seems to melt away, because I know exactly what I want, and am looking out for the key idea that will give it to me.</p>\n<p>There&#8217;s a great section on the use of artificial &#8220;real-world&#8221; problems. I think he would agree with me about <a href=\"https://gowers.wordpress.com/2009/07/11/help-im-stuck-in-my-ivory-tower/\">Use of Maths A-level</a>. As someone he quotes says, &#8220;Students are constantly on their guard against being conned into being interested.&#8221; An example he discusses is </p>\n<p><em>Alan drinks 5/8 of a pint of beer. What fraction of his drink is left?</em></p>\n<p>If the entire point of the exercise is to gain fluency with subtracting fractions, then he advocates just cutting the crap and asking them to calculate 1-5/8, which I agree with 100%.</p>\n<p>If, on the other hand, it is intended as an exercise in stripping away the unnecessary real-world stuff and getting at the underlying mathematics, then he has interesting things to say (later in the book than this section) about the relationship between what he calls the surface structure and the deep structure. The former is to do with the elements of the question that present themselves directly to the student &#8212; in this case Alan and the beer &#8212; while the deep structure is more like the underlying mathematical question. To train people to uncover the deep structure, it is very important to give them pairs of questions with the same surface structure and different deep structures, and vice versa. Otherwise, they may learn a procedure that works for lots of similar examples and lets them down as soon as a new example comes along with a different deep structure.</p>\n<p>There is lots more in the book &#8212; obviously, given its length &#8212; but I hope this conveys some of its flavour. The only negative thing I can think of to say is that the word &#8220;flipping&#8221; is overused &#8212; the sentence &#8220;Teaching is flipping hard&#8221; occurs several times, when once would be enough for one book. But if you&#8217;re ready for a bit of jocularity of that kind, then I recommend it, as I found it highly thought provoking. I don&#8217;t yet know what the result of that provocation will be, but I&#8217;m pretty sure there will be one. </p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 22 Dec 2018 15:37:42 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%280%2C1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"4cde70d3a08813813addf518373246a5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn92@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-14-689_b6d046cb99be3482.webp","destWidth":34,"destHeight":18,"sourceBytes":306,"destBytes":436,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%280%2C1%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn92@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-14-689_b6d046cb99be3482.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn35@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-24-217_fa2553bf263bf18e.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-22-844_26bd04ed9e0cc047.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5E2%2Bx%2B1&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn28@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-16-083_ed7749e779987a3d.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a%2Cb%2Cc%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-16-080_f3bbf0793832adf4.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cx_n%29%5Cin%5Cmathbb+R%5En&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-16-110_8df2ef0e5e6da199.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%2B%5Cdots%2Bx_n%3D0&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn63@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-23-636_2a2ad7a0d5cd5bb2.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x_1%2B2x_2%2B%5Cdots%2Bnx_n%3D0&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn75@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-25-862_5bd79a2fafbbe9bb.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x-2%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn13@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-29-287_1c99917a6c7445b0.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28x-3%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn55@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-25-623_6cb9774a0c0ae392.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2x%2B3%3D17&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn5@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-16-063_da6b23075bb8ae3a.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=4-2x%3D3x-11&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn34@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-28-243_0ee40d764bca64a8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694447},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"A new journal in combinatorics","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6369","description":"<p>This post is to announce that a new journal, <a href=\"https://advances-in-combinatorics.scholasticahq.com/\">Advances in Combinatorics</a>, has just opened for submissions. I shall also say a little about the journal, about other new journals, about my own experiences of finding journals I am happy to submit to, and about whether we are any nearer a change to more sensible systems of dissemination and evaluation of scientific papers.</p>\n<h3>Advances in Combinatorics</h3>\n<p>Advances in Combinatorics is set up as a combinatorics journal for high-quality papers, principally in the less algebraic parts of combinatorics. It will be an arXiv overlay journal, so free to read, and it will not charge authors. Like its cousin Discrete Analysis (which has recently published its 50th paper) it will be run on the <a href=\"https://scholasticahq.com/\">Scholastica platform</a>. Its minimal costs are being paid for by <a href=\"http://library.queensu.ca/\">the library at Queen&#8217;s University in Ontario</a>, which is also providing administrative support. The journal will start with a small editorial board. Apart from me, it will consist of B&#233;la Bollob&#225;s, Reinhard Diestel, Dan Kral, Daniela K&#252;hn, James Oxley, Bruce Reed, Gabor Sarkozy, Asaf Shapira and Robin Thomas. Initially, Dan Kral  and I will be the managing editors, though I hope to find somebody to replace me in that role once the journal is established. While I am posting this, Dan is simultaneously announcing the journal at the SIAM conference in Discrete Mathematics, where he has just given a plenary lecture. The journal is also being announced by COAR, the <a href=\"https://www.coar-repositories.org/\">Confederation of Open Access Repositories</a>. This project aligned well with what they are trying to do, and it was their director, Kathleen Shearer, who put me in touch with the library at Queen&#8217;s.</p>\n<p>As with Discrete Analysis, all members of the editorial board will be expected to work: they won&#8217;t just be lending their names to give the journal bogus prestige. Each paper will be handled by one of the editors, who, after obtaining external opinions (when the paper warrants them) will make a recommendation to the rest of the board. All decisions will be made collectively. The job of the managing editors will be to make sure that this process runs smoothly, but when it comes to decisions, they will have no more say than any other editor.</p>\n<p>The rough level that the journal is aiming at is that of a top specialist journal such as Combinatorica.
