The reason for setting it up is that there is a gap in the market for an &#8220;ethical&#8221; combinatorics journal at that level &#8212; that is, one that is not published by one of the major commercial publishers, with all the well known problems that result. We are not trying to destroy the commercial combinatorial journals, but merely to give people the option of avoiding them if they would prefer to submit to a journal that is not complicit in a system that uses its monopoly power to ruthlessly squeeze library budgets.<span id=\"more-6369\"></span></p>\n<p>We are not the first ethical journal in combinatorics. Another example is <a href=\"http://www.combinatorics.org/\">The Electronic Journal of Combinatorics</a>, which was set up by Herb Wilf back in 1994. The main difference between EJC and Advances in Combinatorics is that we plan to set a higher bar for acceptance, even if it means that we accept only a small number of papers. (One of the great advantages of a fully electronic journal is that we do not have a fixed number of issues per year, so we will not have to change our standards artificially in order to fill issues or clear backlogs.) We thus hope that EJC and AIC will between them offer suitable potential homes for a wide range of combinatorics papers. And on the more algebraic side, one should also mention <a href=\"https://alco.centre-mersenne.org/journals/ALCO\">Algebraic Combinatorics</a>, which used to be the Springer journal The Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics (which officially continues with an entirely replaced editorial board &#8212; I don&#8217;t know whether it&#8217;s getting many submissions though), and also the <a href=\"http://ajc.maths.uq.edu.au/\">Australasian Journal of Combinatorics</a>.</p>\n<p>So if you&#8217;re a combinatorialist who is writing up a result that you think is pretty good, then please consider submitting it to us. What do we mean by &#8220;pretty good&#8221;? My personal view &#8212; that is, I am not speaking for the rest of the editorial board &#8212; is that the work in a good paper should have a clear reason for others to be interested in it (so not, for example, incremental progress in some pet project of the author) and should have something about it that makes it count as a significant achievement, such as solving a well-known problem, clearing a difficult technical hurdle, inventing a new and potentially useful technique, or giving a beautiful and memorable proof. </p>\n<h3>What other ethical journals are there?</h3>\n<p>Suppose that you want to submit an article to a journal that is free to read and does not charge authors. What are your options? I don&#8217;t have a full answer to this question, so I would very much welcome feedback from other people, especially in areas of mathematics far from my own, about what the options are for them. But a good starting point is to consult the list of current member journals in the <a href=\"https://freejournals.org/\">Free Journal Network</a>, which Advances in Combinatorics hopes to join in due course.</p>\n<p>Three notable journals not on that list are the following.</p>\n<ol>\n<li><a href=\"https://intlpress.com/site/pub/pages/journals/items/acta/_home/_main/index.html\">Acta Mathematica</a>. This is one of a tiny handful of the very top journals in mathematics. Last year it became fully open access without charging author fees. So for a <em>really</em> good paper it is a great option.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://annales.lebesgue.fr/index.php/AHL/\">Annales Henri Lebesgue</a>. This is a new journal that has not yet published any articles, but is open for submissions. Like Acta Mathematica, it covers all of mathematics. It aims for a very high standard, but it is not yet clear what that means in practice: I cannot say that it will be roughly at the level of Journal X. But perhaps it will turn out to be suitable for a very good paper that is just short of the level of Annals, Acta, or JAMS.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://msp.org/ant/2018/12-2/\">Algebra and Number Theory</a>. I am told that this is regarded as the top specialist journal in number theory. From a glance at the article titles, I don&#8217;t see much analytic number theory, but there are notable analytic number theorists on the editorial board, so perhaps I have just not looked hard enough.</li>\n</ol>\n<p><em>Added later: I learn from Beno&#238;t Kloeckner and Emmanuel Kowalski in the comments below that my information about Algebra and Number Theory was wrong, since articles in that journal are not free to read until they are five years old. However, it is published by <a href=\"https://msp.org/\">MSP</a>, which is a nonprofit organization, so as subscription journals go it is at the ethical end of the spectrum.</em></p>\n<p><em>Further update: I have heard from the editors of Annales Henri Lebesgue that they have had a number of strong submissions and expect the level of the journal to be at least as high as that of journals such as Advances in Mathematics, Mathematische Annalen and the Israel Journal of Mathematics, and perhaps even slightly higher.</em> </p>\n<h3>In what areas are ethical journals most needed?</h3>\n<p>I would very much like to hear from people who would prefer to avoid the commercially published journals, but can&#8217;t, because there are no ethical journals of a comparable standard in their area. I hope that combinatorialists will no longer have that problem. My impression is that there is a lack of suitable journals in analysis and I&#8217;m told that the same is true of logic. I&#8217;m not quite sure what the situation is in geometry or algebra. (In particular, I don&#8217;t know whether Algebra and Number Theory is also considered as the top specialist journal for algebraists.) Perhaps in some areas there are satisfactory choices for papers of some standards but not of others: that too would be interesting to know. Where do you think the gaps are? Let me know in the comments below.</p>\n<h3>Starting a new journal.</h3>\n<p>I want to make one point loud and clear, which is that the mechanics of starting a new, academic-run journal are now very easy. Basically, the only significant obstacle is getting together an editorial board with the right combination of reputation in the field and willingness to work. What&#8217;s more, unless the journal grows large, the work is quite manageable &#8212; all the more so if it is spread reasonably uniformly amongst the editorial board. Creating the journal itself can be done on one of a number of different platforms, either for no charge or for a very small charge. Some examples are the <a href=\"https://www.centre-mersenne.org/\">Mersenne platform</a>, which hosts the Annales Henri Lebesgue, the <a href=\"https://www.episciences.org/\">Episciences platform</a>, which hosts the <a href=\"https://epiga.episciences.org/\">Epijournal de G&#233;om&#233;trie Alg&#233;brique</a>, and Scholastica, which, as I mentioned above, hosts Discrete Analysis and Advances in Combinatorics. </p>\n<p>Of these, Scholastica charges a submission fee of $10 per article and the other two are free. There are a few additional costs &#8212; for example, Discrete Analysis pays a subscription to CrossRef in order to give DOIs to articles &#8212; but the total cost of running a new journal that isn&#8217;t too large is of the order of a few hundred dollars per year, as long as nobody is paid for what they do. (Discrete Analysis, like Advances in Combinatorics, gets very useful assistance from librarians, provided voluntarily, but even if they were paid the going rate, the total annual costs would be of the same order of magnitude as one &#8220;article processing charge&#8221; of the traditional publishers, which is typically around $1500 per article.) </p>\n<p>What&#8217;s more, those few hundred dollars are not an obstacle either. For example, I know of a fund that is ready to support at least one other journal of a similar size to Discrete Analysis, there are almost certainly other libraries that would be interested in following the enlightened example of Queen&#8217;s University Library and supporting a journal (if you are a librarian reading this, then I strongly recommend doing so, as it will be helping to weaken the hold of the system that is currently costing you orders of magnitude more money), and I know various people who know about other means of obtaining funding. So if you are interested in starting a journal and think you can put together a credible editorial board, then get in touch: I can offer advice, funding (if the proposal looks a good one), and contact with several other people who are knowledgeable and keen to help. </p>\n<h3>A few remarks about my own relationship with mathematical publishing.</h3>\n<p>My attitudes to journals and the journal system have evolved quite a lot in the last few years. The alert reader may have noticed that I&#8217;ve got a long way through this post before mentioning the E-word. I still think that Elsevier is the publisher that does most damage, and have stuck rigidly to my promise made over six years ago not to submit a paper to them or to do editorial or refereeing work. However, whereas then I thought of Springer as somehow more friendly to mathematics, thanks to its long tradition of publishing important textbooks and monographs, I now feel pretty uncomfortable about all the big four &#8212; Elsevier, Springer, Wiley, and Taylor and Francis &#8212; with Springer having got a whole lot worse after merging with Nature Macmillan. And in some respects Elsevier is better than Springer: for example, they make all mathematics papers over four years old freely available, while Springer refuses to do so. Admittedly this was basically a sop to mathematicians to keep us quiet, but as sops go it was a pretty good one, and I see now that Elsevier&#8217;s open archive, as they call it, includes some serious non-mathematical journals such as Cell. (See <a href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/open-science/open-access/open-archive\">their list of participating journals</a> for details.) </p>\n<p>I&#8217;m also not very comfortable with the society journals and university presses, since although they use their profits to benefit mathematics in various ways, they are fully complicit in the system of big deals, the harm of which outweighs those benefits.</p>\n<p>The result is that if I have a paper to submit, I tend to have a lot of trouble finding a suitable home for it, and I end up having to compromise on my principles to some extent (particularly if, as happened recently, I have a young coauthor from a country that uses journal rankings to evaluate academics). An obvious place to submit to would be Discrete Analysis, but I feel uncomfortable about that for a different reason, especially now that I have discovered that the facility that enables all the discussion of a paper to be hidden from selected editors does not allow me, as administrator of the website, to hide a paper from myself. (I won&#8217;t have this last problem with Advances in Combinatorics, since the librarians at Queens will have the administrator role on the system.)</p>\n<p>So my personal options are somewhat limited, but getting better. If I have willing coauthors, then I would now consider (if I had a suitable paper), Acta Mathematica, Annales Henri Lebesgue, Journal de l&#8217;&#201;cole Polytechnique, Discrete Analysis perhaps (but only if the other editors agreed to process my paper offline), Advances in Combinatorics, the Theory of Computing, Electronic Research Announcements in the Mathematical Sciences, the Electronic Journal of Combinatorics, and the Online Journal of Analytic Combinatorics. I also wouldn&#8217;t rule out Forum of Mathematics. A couple of journals to which I have an emotional attachment even if I don&#8217;t really approve of their practices are GAFA and Combinatorics, Probability and Computing. (The latter bothers me because it is a hybrid journal &#8212; that is, it charges subscriptions but also lets authors pay large APCs to make their articles open access, and I heard recently that if you choose the open access option, CUP retains copyright, so you&#8217;re not getting that much for your money. But I think not many authors choose this option. The former is also a hybrid journal, and is published by Springer.) Annals of Mathematics, if I&#8217;m lucky enough to have an Annals-worthy paper (though I think now I&#8217;d try Acta first), is not too bad &#8212; although its articles aren&#8217;t open access, their subscription costs are much more reasonable than most journals.</p>\n<p>That&#8217;s a list off the top of my head: if you think I&#8217;ve missed out a good option, then I&#8217;d be very happy to hear about it.</p>\n<p>As an editor, I have recently made the decision that I want to devote all my energies to promoting journals and &#8220;post-journal&#8221; systems that I fully approve of. So in order to make time for the work that will be involved in establishing Advances in Combinatorics, I have given notice to Forum of Mathematics and Mathematika, the two journals that took up the most of my time, that I will leave their editorial boards at the end of 2018. I feel quite sad about Forum of Mathematics, since I was involved in it from the start, and I really like the way it runs, with proper discussions amongst all the editors about the decisions we make. Also, I am less hostile (for reasons I&#8217;ve given in the past) to its APC model than most mathematicians. However, although I am less hostile, I could never say that I have positively liked it, and I came to the conclusion quite a while ago that, as many others have also said, it simply can&#8217;t be made to work satisfactorily: it will lead to just as bad market abuses as there are with the subscription system. In the UK it has been a disaster &#8212; government open-access mandates have led to universities paying as much as ever for subscriptions and then a whole lot extra for APCs. And there is a real worry that subscription big deals will be replaced by APC big deals, where a country pays a huge amount up front to a publisher in return for people from that country being able to publish with them. This, for example, is what Germany is pushing for. Fortunately, for the moment (if I understand correctly, though I don&#8217;t have good insider information on this) they are asking for the average fee per article to be much lower than Elsevier is prepared to accept: long may that impasse continue.</p>\n<p>So my leaving Forum of Mathematics is not a protest against it, but simply a practical step that will allow me to focus my energies where I think they can do the most good. I haven&#8217;t yet decided whether I ought to resign in protest from some other editorial boards of journals that don&#8217;t ask anything of me. Actually, even the practice of having a long list of names of editors, most of whom have zero involvement in the decisions of the journal, is one that bothers me. I recently heard of an Elsevier journal where almost all the editorial board would be happy to resign en masse and set up an ethical version, but the managing editor is strongly against. &#8220;But why don&#8217;t the rest of the board resign in that case?&#8221; I naively asked, to which the answer was, &#8220;Because he&#8217;s the one who does all the work!&#8221; From what I understood, this is literally true &#8212; the managing editor handles all the papers and makes all the decisions &#8212; but I&#8217;m not 100% sure about that. </p>\n<h3>Is there any point in starting new journals?</h3>\n<p>Probably major change, if it happens, will be the result of decisions made by major players such as government agencies, national negotiators, and so on. Compared with big events like the Elsevier negotiations in Germany, founding a new journal is a very small step. And even if all mathematicians gave up using the commercial publishers (not something I expect to see any time soon), that would have almost no direct effect, since mathematics journals are bundled together with journals in other subjects, which would continue with the current system.</p>\n<p>However, this is a familiar situation in politics. Big decisions are taken by people in positions of power, but what prompts them to make those decisions is often the result of changes in attitudes and behaviour of voters. And big behavioural changes do happen in academia. For example, as we all know, many people have got into the habit of posting all their work on the arXiv, and this accumulation of individual decisions has had the effect of completely changing the way dissemination works in some subjects, including mathematics, a change that has significantly weakened the hold that journals have &#8212; or would have if they weren&#8217;t bundled together with other journals. Who would ever subscribe at vast expense to a mathematics journal when almost all its content is available online in preprint form?</p>\n<p>So I see Advances in Combinatorics as a small step certainly, but a step that needs to be taken. I hope that it will demonstrate once again that starting a serious new journal is not that hard. I also hope that the current trickle of such journals will turn into a flood, that after the flood it will not be possible for people to argue that they are forced to submit articles to the commercial publishers, and that at some point, someone in a position of power will see what is going on, understand better the absurdities of the current system, and take a decision that benefits us all.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 04 Jun 2018 14:56:04 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"cdf48a52722c665303283387bfe39d7c","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694448},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Another journal flips","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6336","description":"<p>There is widespread (even if not universal) agreement that something is deeply wrong with the current system of academic publishing. The basic point, which has been made innumerable times by innumerable people, is that the really hard parts &#8212; the writing of papers, and the peer review and selection of the ones to publish &#8212; are done voluntarily by academics, and modern technology makes things like typesetting and dissemination extremely cheap. And yet publishers are making more money than ever before. They do this by insisting that we give them ownership of the content we produce (though many journals will publish papers even if you strike out the part of the contract that hands them this ownership &#8212; these days I never agree to give copyright to a publisher, and I urge you not to either), and by bundling their journals together so that libraries are forced into an all-or-nothing decision. (As another aside, I also urge libraries to look closely at what is happening in Germany, where they have gone for the &#8220;nothing&#8221; option with Elsevier and the world has not come to an end.)</p>\n<p>What can be done about this? There are many actions, none of which are likely to be sufficient to bring about major change on their own, but which in combination will help to get us to a tipping point. In no particular order, here are some of them. </p>\n<ol>\n<li>Create new journals that operate much more cheaply and wait for them to become established.</li>\n<li>Persuade libraries not to agree to Big Deals with the big publishers.</li>\n<li>Refuse to publish with, write for, or edit for, the big publishers.</li>\n<li>Make sure all your work is freely available online.</li>\n<li>Encourage journals that are supporting the big publishers to leave those publishers and set up in a cheaper and fairer way.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>Not all of these are easy things to do, but I&#8217;m delighted to report that a small group I belong to, set up by <a href=\"https://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/people/mc-wilson\">Mark Wilson</a>, has, after approaching a large number of maths journals, found one that was ready to &#8220;flip&#8221;: the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics has just announced that it will be leaving Springer. Or if you want to be more pedantic about it, a new journal will be starting, called <a href=\"http://algebraic-combinatorics.org/\">Algebraic Combinatorics</a> and published by <a href=\"http://www.mathdoc.fr/centre_mersenne\">The Mersenne Centre for Open Scientific Publishing</a>, and almost all the editors of the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics will resign from that journal and become editors of the new one, which will adhere to <a href=\"https://fairoa.org\">Fair Open Access Principles</a>.</p>\n<p>If you want to see change, then you should from now on regard Algebraic Combinatorics as the true continuation of the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics, and the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics as a zombie journal that happens to have a name that coincides with a former real journal. And of course, that means that if you are an algebraic combinatorialist with a paper that would have been suitable for the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics, you should understand that <em>the reputation of the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics is being transferred, along with the editorial board, to Algebraic Combinatorics, and you should therefore submit it to Algebraic Combinatorics</em>. This has worked with previous flips: the zombie journal rarely thrives afterwards and in some notable cases has ceased to publish after a couple of years or so.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6336\"></span></p>\n<p>The words of one of the editors of the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics, Hugh Thomas, are particularly telling, especially the first sentence: &#8220;There wasnâ€™t a particular crisis. It has been becoming more and more clear that commercial journal publishers are charging high subscription fees and high Article Processing Charges (APCs), profiting from the volunteer labour of the academic community, and adding little value. It is getting easier and easier to automate the things that they once took care of. The actual printing and distribution of paper copies is also much less important than it has been in the past; this is something which we have decided we can do without.&#8221;</p>\n<p>I mentioned earlier that we approached many journals. Although it is very exciting that one journal is flipping, I must also admit to disappointment at how low our strike rate has been so far. However, the words &#8220;so far&#8221; are important: many members of editorial boards were very sympathetic with our aims, and some journals were adopting a wait-and-see attitude, so if the flip of JACo is successful, we hope that it will encourage other journals. I should say that we weren&#8217;t just saying, &#8220;Why don&#8217;t you flip?&#8221; but we were also offering support, including financial support. The current situation is that we can almost certainly finance journals that are ready to flip to an &#8220;ultra-cheap&#8221; model (using a platform that charges either nothing or a very small fee per submission) and help with administrative support, and are working on financial support for more expensive models, but still far cheaper than the commercial publishers, where more elaborate services are offered.</p>\n<p>Understandably, the main editors tended to be a lot more cautious on average than the bulk of the editorial boards. I think many of them were worried that they might accidentally destroy their journals if they flipped them, and in the case of journals with long traditions, this is not something one would want to be remembered for. So again, the more we can support Algebraic Combinatorics, the more likely it is that this caution will be reduced and other journals will consider following. (If you are an editor of a journal we have not approached, please do get in touch to discuss what the possibilities are &#8212; we have put a lot of thought into it.) </p>\n<p>Another argument put forward by some editors is that to flip a journal risks damaging the reputation of the old version of the journal, and therefore, indirectly, the reputation of the papers published in it, some of which are by early-career researchers. So they did not want to flip in order to avoid damaging the careers of young mathematicians. If you are a young mathematician and would like to comment on whether you would be bothered by a journal flipping after you had published in it, we would be very interested to hear what you have to say.</p>\n<p>Against that background I&#8217;d like to congratulate the editors of the Journal of Algebraic Combinatorics for their courage and for the work they have put into this. (But that word &#8220;work&#8221; should not put off other editors: one of the aims of our small group was to provide support and expertise, including from Johann Rooryck, the editor of the Elsevier journal Lingua, which flipped to become Glossa, in order to make the transition as easy as possible.) I&#8217;d also like to make clear, to avoid any misunderstanding that might arise, that although I&#8217;ve been involved in a lot of discussion with Mark Wilson&#8217;s group and wrote to many editors of other journals, my role in this particular flip has been a minor one.</p>\n<p>And finally, let me repeat the main message of this post: please support the newly flipped journal, since the more successful it is, the greater the chance that other journals will follow, and the greater the chance that we will be able to move to a more sensible academic publishing system. </p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 27 Jul 2017 10:39:50 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"ed66bd408845be664eb718a12de83e1d","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694449},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Mathematical Research Reports: a â€œnewâ€ mathematics journal is launched","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6513","description":"<p>From time to time academic journals undergo an interesting process of fission. Typically as a result of some serious dissatisfaction, the editorial board resigns en masse to set up a new journal, the publishers of the original journal build a new editorial board from scratch, and the result is two journals, one inheriting the editors and collective memory of the original journal, and the other keeping the name and the publisher. Which is the &#8220;true&#8221; successor? In practice it tends to be the one with the editors, with its sibling surviving as a zombie journal that is the successor in name only. Perhaps there are examples that go the other way, and there may be examples where both journals go on to thrive, but I have not looked closely at the examples I know about. </p>\n<p>I&#8217;m mentioning this because recently I have been involved in a rather unusual example of this phenomenon. Most cases I know of are the result either of frustration with the practices of the big commercial publishers or of malpractice by an editor-in-chief. But this was an open access journal with no publication charges, and with an extremely efficient and impeccably behaved editor-in-chief. So what was the problem?</p>\n<p>The journal started out in 1995 as Electronic Research Announcements of the AMS, or ERA-AMS for short. It was still called that when I first joined the editorial board. Its editor-in-chief was Svetlana Katok, who did a great job, and there was a high-powered editorial board. As its name suggests, it specialized in shortish papers announcing results that would then appear with more details in significantly longer papers, so it was a little like Comptes Rendus in its aim. It would also accept short articles of a more traditional kind. </p>\n<p>It never published all that many papers, and in 2007, I think for that reason (but don&#8217;t remember for sure), the AMS decided to discontinue it. But Svetlana Katok had put a lot into the journal and managed to find another publisher, the American Institute of Mathematical Sciences, and the editorial board agreed to continue serving. The name of the journal was changed to Electronic Research Announcements in the Mathematical Sciences, and its abbreviation was slightly abbreviated from ERA-AMS to ERA-MS. </p>\n<p>In 2016, after 22 years, Svetlana Katok decided to step down, and Boris Hasselblatt took over. It was a good moment to try to revitalize the journal, so measures were taken such as designing a new and better website and making more effort to publicize the journal, in the hope of attracting more submissions (or more precisely, more submissions of a high enough quality that we would want to publish them). </p>\n<p>However, despite these measures, the numbers remained fairly low &#8212; around ten a year (with quite a bit of variation), and this, indirectly, caused the problem that led to the split. The editors would have liked to see more papers published, but were not worried about it to the point where we would have been prepared to sacrifice quality to achieve it: we were ready to accept that this was, at least for now, a small journal. But AIMS was not so happy. In an effort to remedy (as they saw it) the situation, they appointed a co-editor-in-chief, who in turn appointed a number of new editors, with a more applied focus, with the idea that by broadening the scope of the journal they would increase the number of papers published.</p>\n<p>That did not precipitate the resignations, but at that stage most of us did not know that the new editors had been appointed without any consultation even with Boris Hasselblatt. But then AIMS took things a step further. Until that point, the journal had adopted a practice that I strongly approve of, which was for the editor who handled a paper to make a recommendation to the rest of the editorial board, with other editors encouraged to comment on that recommendation. This practice helps to guard against &#8220;rogue&#8221; editors and against abuse of the system in general. It also helps to maintain consistent standards, and provides a gentle pressure on editors to do their job conscientiously &#8212; there&#8217;s nothing like knowing that you&#8217;re going to have to justify your decision to a bunch of mathematicians. </p>\n<p>But suddenly the publishers told us that this system had to change, and that from now on the editorial board would not have the opportunity to vet papers, and would continue to have no say in new editorial appointments. (Various justifications were given for this, including that it would make it harder to recruit editors if they thought they had to make judgments about papers not in their immediate area.) At that point, it was clear that the soul of the journal was about to be destroyed, so over a few days the entire board (from before the start of the changes) resigned, resolving to start afresh with a new name.</p>\n<p>That new name is <a href=\"https://mrr.centre-mersenne.org/\">Mathematical Research Reports</a>. We will continue to accept reports on longer work, as well as short articles. In addition we welcome short survey articles. We regard it as the continuation in spirit of ERA-MS. Another unusual feature of this particular split is that the other half, still published by AIMS, has also changed its name and is now called <a href=\"https://www.aimsciences.org/journal/A0000-0004\">Electronic Research Archive</a>.</p>\n<p>If, like me, you are always on the lookout for high-quality &#8220;ethical&#8221; journals (which I loosely define as free to read, free to publish in, and adopting high standards of editorial practice), then please add Mathematical Research Reports to your list. Have a look at the back catalogue of ERA-MS and ERA-AMS and you will get an idea of our standards. It would be wonderful if the unfortunate events of the last year or so were to be the catalyst that led to the journal finally becoming established in the way that it has deserved to be for a long time. </p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 20 May 2020 13:50:32 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"3d5e945f8800834043e0a0f686ca31be","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694447},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Voting tactically in the EU elections","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6447","description":"<p>This post is addressed at anyone who is voting in Great Britain in the forthcoming elections to the European Parliament and whose principal aim is to maximize the number of MEPs from Remain-supporting parties, where those are deemed to be the Liberal Democrats, the Greens, Change UK, Plaid Cymru and the Scottish National Party. If you have other priorities, then the general principles laid out here may be helpful, but the examples of how to apply them will not necessarily be appropriate to your particular concerns.</p>\n<h3>What is the voting system?</h3>\n<p>The system used is called the d&#8217;Hondt system. The country is divided into a number of regions, and from each region several MEPs will be elected. You get one vote, and it is for a party rather than a single candidate. Once the votes are in, there are a couple of ways of thinking about how they translate into results. One that I like is to imagine that the parties have the option of assigning their votes to their candidates as they wish, and once the assignments have been made, the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> candidates with the most votes get seats, where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> is the number of MEPs representing the given region.</p>\n<p>For example, if there are three parties for four places, and their vote shares are 50%, 30% and 20%, then the first party will give 25% to two candidates and both will be elected. If the second party tries a similar trick, it will only get one candidate through because the 20% that goes to the third party is greater than the 15% going to the two candidates from the second party. So the result is two candidates for the first party, one for the second and one for the third.</p>\n<p>If the vote shares had been 60%, 25% and 15%, then the first party could afford to split three ways and the result would be three seats for the first party and one for the second.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6447\"></span></p>\n<p>The way this is sometimes presented is as follows. Let&#8217;s go back to the first case. We take the three percentages, and for each one we write down the results of dividing it by 1, 2, 3, etc. That gives us the (approximate) numbers</p>\n<p>50%, 25%, 17%, 13%, 10%, &#8230;</p>\n<p>30%, 15%, 10%, 8%, 6%, &#8230;</p>\n<p>20%, 10%, 7%, 5%, 3%, &#8230;</p>\n<p>Looking at those numbers, we see that the biggest four are 50%, 25% from the top row, 30% from the second row, and 20% from the third row. So the first party gets two seats, the second party one and the third party one.</p>\n<h3>How does this affect how I should vote?</h3>\n<p>The answer to this question depends in peculiar ways on the polling in your region. Let&#8217;s take my region, Eastern England, as an example. This region gets seven MEPs, and the latest polls show these kinds of percentages.</p>\n<p>Brexit Party 40%<br />\nLiberal Democrats 17%<br />\nLabour 15%<br />\nGreens 10%<br />\nConservatives 9%<br />\nChange UK 4%<br />\nUKIP 2%</p>\n<p>If the percentages stay as they are, then the threshold for an MEP is 10%. The Brexit Party gets four MEPs, and the Lib Dems, Labour and the Greens one each. But because the Brexit Party, the Greens and the Conservatives are all close to the 10% threshold, small swings can make a difference to which two out of the fourth Brexit Party candidate, the Green candidate, or the Conservative candidate gets left out. On the other hand, it would take a much bigger swing &#8212; of 3% or so &#8212; to give the second Lib Dem candidate a chance of being elected. So if your main concern is to maximize the number of Remain-supporting MEPs, you should support the Greens.</p>\n<h3>Yes, but what if everybody were to do that?</h3>\n<p>In principle that is an annoying problem with the d&#8217;Hondt system. But don&#8217;t worry &#8212; it just isn&#8217;t going to happen. Systematic tactical voting is at best a marginal phenomenon, but fortunately in this region a marginal phenomenon may be all it takes to make sure that the Green candidate gets elected.</p>\n<h3>Aren&#8217;t you being defeatist? What about trying to get two Lib Dems and one Green through?</h3>\n<p>This might conceivably be possible, but it would be difficult, and a risky strategy, since going for that could lead to just one Remain-supporting MEP. One possibility would be for Remain-leaning Labour voters to say to themselves &#8220;Well, we&#8217;re basically guaranteed an MEP, and I&#8217;d much prefer a Remain MEP to either the Conservatives or the Brexit Party, so I&#8217;ll vote Green or Lib Dem instead.&#8221; If that started showing up in polls, then one would be able to do a better risk assessment. But for now it looks better to make sure that the Green candidate gets through.</p>\n<h3>I&#8217;m not from the Eastern region. Where can I find out how to vote in my region?</h3>\n<p>There is a website called <a href=\"https://remainvoter.com/\">remainvoter.com</a> that has done the analysis. The reason I am writing this post is that I have seen online that a lot of people are highly sceptical about their conclusions, so I wanted to explain the theory behind them (as far as I can guess it) so that you don&#8217;t have to take what they say on trust and can do the calculations for yourself. </p>\n<p>Just to check, I&#8217;ll look at another region and see whether I end up with a recommendation that agrees with that of remainvoter.com.</p>\n<p>In the South West, there are six MEPs. A recent poll shows the following percentages.</p>\n<p>Brexit Party 42%<br />\nLib Dem 20%<br />\nGreen Party 12%<br />\nConservatives 9%<br />\nLabour 8%<br />\nChange UK 4%<br />\nUKIP 3%</p>\n<p>Dividing the Brexit Party vote by 3 gives 14% and dividing the Lib Dem vote by 2 gives 10%. So as things stand there would be three Brexit Party MEPs, two Lib Dem MEPs and one Green Party MEP. </p>\n<p>This is a bit close for comfort, but the second Lib Dem candidate is in a more precarious position than the Green Party candidate, given that the Conservative candidate is on 9%. So it would make sense for a bit of Green Party support to transfer to the Lib Dems in order to be sure that the three Remain-supporting candidates that look like being elected in the south west really are.</p>\n<p>Interestingly, remainvoter.com recommend supporting the Greens on the grounds that one Lib Dem MEP is bound to be elected. I&#8217;m not sure I understand this, since it seems very unlikely that the Lib Dems and the Greens won&#8217;t get at least two seats between them, so they might as well aim for three. Perhaps someone can enlighten me on this point. It could be that remainvoter.com is looking at different polls from the ones I&#8217;m looking at.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;m slightly perturbed by that so I&#8217;ll pick another region and try the same exercise. Perhaps London would be a good one. Here we have the following percentages (plus a couple of smaller ones that won&#8217;t affect anything). </p>\n<p>Liberal Democrats 24% (12%, 8%)<br />\nBrexit Party 21% (10.5%, 7%)<br />\nLabour 19% (9.5%, 6.3%)<br />\nGreen Party 14% (7%)<br />\nConservatives 10%<br />\nChange UK 6%</p>\n<p>London has eight MEPs. Here I find it convenient to use the algorithm of dividing by 1,2,3 etc., which explains the percentages I&#8217;ve added in brackets. Taking the eight largest numbers we see that the current threshold to get an MEP is at 9.5%, so the Lib Dems get two, the Brexit party two, Labour two and the Greens and Conservatives one each. </p>\n<p>Here it doesn&#8217;t look obvious how to vote tactically. Clearly not Green, since the Greens are squarely in the middle of the range between the threshold and twice the threshold. Probably not Lib Dem either (unless things change quite a bit) since they&#8217;re unlikely to go up as far as 28.5%. But getting Change UK up to 9.5% also looks pretty hard to me. Perhaps the least difficult of these difficult options is for the Green Party to donate about 3% of the vote and the Lib Dems another 2% to Change UK, which would allow them to overtake Labour. But I don&#8217;t see it happening. </p>\n<p>And now to check my answer, so to speak. And it does indeed agree with the remainvoter.com recommendation. This looks to me like a case where if tactical voting were to be widely adopted, then it might just work to get another MEP, but if it were that widely adopted, one might have to start worrying about not overshooting and accidentally losing one of the other Remain MEPs. But that&#8217;s not likely to happen, and in fact I&#8217;d predict that in London Change UK will not get an MEP because not enough people will follow remainvoter.com&#8217;s recommendation.</p>\n<h3>This all seems horribly complicated. What should I do?</h3>\n<p>If you don&#8217;t want to bother to think about it, then just go to remainvoter.com and follow their recommendation. If you do want to think, then follow these simple (for a typical reader of this blog anyway) instructions.</p>\n<p>1. Google polls for your region. (For example, you can scroll down to near the bottom of <a href=\"https://www.bestforbritain.org/poll_largest_poll_so_far_shows_how_each_region_is_voting_ahead_of_thursday_s_euro_elections\">this page</a> to find one set of polls.) </p>\n<p>2. Find out how many MEPs your region gets. Let that number be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>3. For each percentage, divide it by 1, 2, 3 etc. until you reach a number that clearly won&#8217;t be in the top <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>4. See what percentage, out of all those numbers, is the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />th largest.</p>\n<p>5. Vote for a Remain party that is associated with a number that is close to the threshold if there is also a Brexit-supporting (or Brexit-fence-sitting) party with a number close to the threshold.</p>\n<p>One can refine point 5 as follows, to cover the case when more than one Remain-supporting party has a number near the threshold. Suppose, for the sake of example, that the Brexit party is polling at 32%, the Lib Dems at 22%, the Greens at 11%, Labour at 18% and the Conservatives at 12%, and others 5%, in a region that gets five MEPs. Then carrying out step 3, we get</p>\n<p>Brexit 32, 16, 10.6<br />\nLib Dems 22, 11<br />\nGreens 11<br />\nConservatives 12<br />\nLabour 18, 9</p>\n<p>So as things stand the Brexit Party gets two MEPs, the Lib Dems one, Labour one and the Conservatives one. If you&#8217;re a Remain supporter who wants to vote tactically, then you&#8217;ll want to push one of the Lib Dems and the Greens over 12% to defeat the Conservative candidate. To do that, you&#8217;ll need either to increase the Green vote from 11% to 12% or to increase the Lib Dem vote from 22% to 24%. The latter is probably harder, so you should probably support the Greens. </p>\n<h3>A final word</h3>\n<p>I&#8217;m not writing this as an expert, so don&#8217;t assume that everything I&#8217;ve written is correct, especially given that I came to a different conclusion from remainvoter.com in the South West. If you think I&#8217;ve slipped up, then please let me know in the comments, and if I agree with you I&#8217;ll make changes. But bear in mind the premise with which I started. Of course there may well be reasons for not voting tactically, such as caring about issues other than Brexit. But this post is about what to do if Brexit is your overriding concern. And one obvious last point: PLEASE ACTUALLY BOTHER TO VOTE! Just the percentage of people voting for Remain-supporting parties will have an impact, even if Farage gets more MEPs.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 21 May 2019 21:14:20 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"a41f697be22a2b073b278e4e70aa1a45","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","destWidth":10,"destHeight":7,"sourceBytes":165,"destBytes":154,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694447},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Worrying news from Turkey","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6425","description":"<p>One should of course be concerned when anybody is detained for spurious reasons, but when that person is a noted mathematician, the shock is greater. Six academics have recently been detained in Turkey, of whom one, <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bet%C3%BCl_Tanbay\">BetÃ¼l Tanbay</a>, is due to become vice president of the European Mathematical Society in January. I do not know of any petitions for their release, but if they are not released very quickly I hope that there will be a strong reaction. The EMS has issued the following statement.</p>\n<blockquote><p>The European Mathematical Society is outraged at the news that the Turkish police have detained, in Istanbul on the morning of 16th November 2018, Professor BetÃ¼l Tanbay, a member of the EMS Executive Committee. We are incredulous at the subsequent press release from the Istanbul Security Directorate accusing her of links to organized crime and attempts to topple the Turkish government.</p>\n<p>Professor Tanbay is a distinguished mathematician and a Vice President Elect of the European Mathematical Society, due to assume that role from January 2019. We have known her for many years as a talented scientist and teacher, a former President of the Turkish Mathematical Society, an open-minded citizen, and a true democrat. She may not hesitate to exercise her freedom of speech, a lawful right that any decent country guarantees its citizens, but it is preposterous to suggest that she could be involved in violent or criminal activities.</p>\n<p>We demand that Professor Tanbay is immediately freed from detention, and we call on the whole European research community to raise its voice against this shameful mistreatment of our colleague, so frighteningly reminiscent of our continent&#8217;s darkest times.</p></blockquote>\n<p><strong>Update.</strong>Â I have just seen <a href=\"https://twitter.com/aylajean/status/1063821952790482944\">this on Twitter:</a></p>\n<blockquote><p>Police freed 8 people, incl. professors Turgut Tarhanli and Betul Tanbay, while barring them from overseas travel, &#38; is still questioning 6 others</p></blockquote>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 16 Nov 2018 23:09:26 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"e199f4aa73f92e835ba3aae23e162fd3","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694447},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Two infinities that are surprisingly equal","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6359","description":"<p>It has been in the news recently &#8212; or rather, the small corner of the news that is of particular interest to mathematicians &#8212; that <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maryanthe_Malliaris\">Maryanthe Malliaris</a> and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saharon_Shelah\">Saharon Shelah</a> recently had an unexpected breakthrough when they stumbled on a proof that two infinities were equal that had been conjectured, and widely believed, to be distinct. Or rather, since both were strictly between the cardinality of the natural numbers and the cardinality of the reals, they were widely believed to be distinct in some models of set theory where the continuum hypothesis fails. </p>\n<p>A couple of days ago, John Baez was sufficiently irritated by <a href=\"https://www.quantamagazine.org/mathematicians-measure-infinities-find-theyre-equal-20170912/\">a Quanta article on this development </a> that he wrote a post on Google Plus in which he did <a href=\"https://plus.google.com/+johncbaez999/posts/KXnZmQZmNTy\">a much better job of explaining what was going on</a>. As a result of reading that, and following and participating in the ensuing discussion, I have got interested in the problem. In particular, as a complete non-expert, I am struck that a problem that looks purely combinatorial (though infinitary) should, according to Quanta, have a solution that involves highly non-trivial arguments in proof theory and model theory. It makes me wonder, again as a complete non-expert so probably very naively, whether there is a simpler purely combinatorial argument that the set theorists missed because they believed too strongly that the two infinities were different. </p>\n<p>I certainly haven&#8217;t found such an argument, but I thought it might be worth at least setting out the problem, in case it appeals to anyone, and giving a few preliminary thoughts about it. I&#8217;m not expecting much from this, but if there&#8217;s a small chance that it leads to a fruitful mathematical discussion, then it&#8217;s worth doing. As I said above, I am indebted to John Baez and to several commenters on his post for being able to write much of what I write in this post, as can easily be checked if you read that discussion as well.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6359\"></span></p>\n<h3>A few definitions and a statement of the result</h3>\n<p>The problem concerns the structure you obtain when you take the power set of the natural numbers and quotient out by the relation &#8220;has a finite symmetric difference with&#8221;. That is, we regard two sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> as equivalent if you can turn <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> into <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> by removing finitely many elements and adding finitely many other elements.</p>\n<p>It&#8217;s easy to check that this is an equivalence relation. We can also define a number of the usual set-theoretic operations. For example, writing <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]\" title=\"[A]\" class=\"latex\" /> for the equivalence class of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />, we can set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ccap%5BB%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]&#92;cap[B]\" title=\"[A]&#92;cap[B]\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5Ccap+B%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A&#92;cap B]\" title=\"[A&#92;cap B]\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ccup+%5BB%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]&#92;cup [B]\" title=\"[A]&#92;cup [B]\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5Ccup+B%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A&#92;cup B]\" title=\"[A&#92;cup B]\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ec&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]^c\" title=\"[A]^c\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5Ec%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A^c]\" title=\"[A^c]\" class=\"latex\" />, etc. It is easy to check that these operations are well-defined.</p>\n<p>What about the subset relation? That too has an obvious definition. We don&#8217;t want to say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Csubset%5BB%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]&#92;subset[B]\" title=\"[A]&#92;subset[B]\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%5Csubset+B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A&#92;subset B\" title=\"A&#92;subset B\" class=\"latex\" />, since that is not well-defined. However, we can define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <em>almost contained in</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if the set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%5Csetminus+B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A&#92;setminus B\" title=\"A&#92;setminus B\" class=\"latex\" /> is finite, and then say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Csubset%5BB%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]&#92;subset[B]\" title=\"[A]&#92;subset[B]\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is almost contained in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />. This <em>is</em> well-defined and it&#8217;s also easy to check that it is true if and only if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ccap%5BB%5D%3D%5BA%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]&#92;cap[B]=[A]\" title=\"[A]&#92;cap[B]=[A]\" class=\"latex\" />, which is the sort of thing we&#8217;d like to happen if our finite-fuzz set theory is to resemble normal set theory as closely as possible.</p>\n<p>I will use a non-standard piece of terminology and refer to an equivalence class of sets as an f-set, the &#8220;f&#8221; standing for &#8220;finite&#8221; or &#8220;fuzzy&#8221; (though these fuzzy sets are not to be confused with the usual definition of fuzzy sets, which I don&#8217;t know and probably never will know). I&#8217;ll also say things like &#8220;is f-contained in&#8221; (which means the same as &#8220;is almost contained in&#8221; except that it refers to the f-sets rather than to representatives of their equivalence classes). </p>\n<p>So far so good, but things start to get a bit less satisfactory when we consider infinite intersections and unions. How are we to define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbigcap_%7Bn%3D1%7D%5E%5Cinfty%5BA_n%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;bigcap_{n=1}^&#92;infty[A_n]\" title=\"&#92;bigcap_{n=1}^&#92;infty[A_n]\" class=\"latex\" />, for example?</p>\n<p>An obvious property we would like is that the intersection should be the largest f-set that is contained in all the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_n%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_n]\" title=\"[A_n]\" class=\"latex\" />. However, simple examples show that there doesn&#8217;t have to be a largest f-set contained in all the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_n%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_n]\" title=\"[A_n]\" class=\"latex\" />. Indeed, let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1%5Csupset+A_2%5Csupset%5Cdots&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_1&#92;supset A_2&#92;supset&#92;dots\" title=\"A_1&#92;supset A_2&#92;supset&#92;dots\" class=\"latex\" /> be an infinite sequence of subsets of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+N&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb N\" title=\"&#92;mathbb N\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n%5Csetminus+A_%7Bn%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" title=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> is infinite for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />. Then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is almost contained in every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n\" title=\"A_n\" class=\"latex\" /> if and only if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%5Csetminus+A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A&#92;setminus A_n\" title=\"A&#92;setminus A_n\" class=\"latex\" /> is finite for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />. Given any such set, we can find for each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> an element <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_n\" title=\"b_n\" class=\"latex\" /> of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n%5Csetminus+A_%7Bn%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" title=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> that is not contained in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> (since <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n%5Csetminus+A_%7Bn%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" title=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> is infinite but <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%5Csetminus+A_%7Bn%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" title=\"A&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> is finite). Then the set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%3DA%5Ccup%5C%7Bb_1%2Cb_2%2C%5Cdots%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B=A&#92;cup&#92;{b_1,b_2,&#92;dots&#92;}\" title=\"B=A&#92;cup&#92;{b_1,b_2,&#92;dots&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> is also almost contained in every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n\" title=\"A_n\" class=\"latex\" />, and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]\" title=\"[A]\" class=\"latex\" /> is properly contained in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BB%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[B]\" title=\"[B]\" class=\"latex\" /> (in the obvious sense).</p>\n<p>OK, we don&#8217;t seem to have a satisfactory definition of infinite intersections, but we could at least hope for a satisfactory definition of &#8220;has an empty intersection&#8221;. And indeed, there is an obvious one. Given a collection of f-sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Cgamma%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;gamma]\" title=\"[A_&#92;gamma]\" class=\"latex\" />, we say that its intersection is empty if the only f-set that is f-contained in every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Cgamma%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;gamma]\" title=\"[A_&#92;gamma]\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B%5Cemptyset%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[&#92;emptyset]\" title=\"[&#92;emptyset]\" class=\"latex\" />. (Note that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B%5Cemptyset%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[&#92;emptyset]\" title=\"[&#92;emptyset]\" class=\"latex\" /> is the equivalence class of the empty set, which consists of all finite subsets of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+N&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb N\" title=\"&#92;mathbb N\" class=\"latex\" />.) In terms of the sets rather than their equivalence classes, this is saying that there is no infinite set that is almost contained in every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_%5Cgamma&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_&#92;gamma\" title=\"A_&#92;gamma\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>An important concept that appears in many places in mathematics, but particularly in set theory, is the <em>finite-intersection property</em>. A collection <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathcal+A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathcal A\" title=\"&#92;mathcal A\" class=\"latex\" /> of subsets of a set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> is said to have this property if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1%5Ccap%5Cdots%5Ccap+A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_1&#92;cap&#92;dots&#92;cap A_n\" title=\"A_1&#92;cap&#92;dots&#92;cap A_n\" class=\"latex\" /> is non-empty whenever <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1%2C%5Cdots%2CA_n%5Cin%5Cmathcal+A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_1,&#92;dots,A_n&#92;in&#92;mathcal A\" title=\"A_1,&#92;dots,A_n&#92;in&#92;mathcal A\" class=\"latex\" />. This definition carries over to f-sets with no problem at all, since finite f-intersections were easy to define.</p>\n<p>Let&#8217;s ask ourselves a little question here: can we find a collection of f-sets with the finite-intersection property but with an empty intersection? That is, no <em>finite</em> intersection is empty, but the intersection of <em>all</em> the f-sets <em>is</em> empty. </p>\n<p>That should be pretty easy. For sets, there are very simple examples like <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n%3D%5C%7Bn%2Cn%2B1%2C%5Cdots%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n=&#92;{n,n+1,&#92;dots&#92;}\" title=\"A_n=&#92;{n,n+1,&#92;dots&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> &#8212; finitely many of those have a non-empty intersection, but there is no set that&#8217;s contained in all of them. </p>\n<p>Unfortunately, all those sets are the same if we turn them into f-sets. But there is an obvious way of adjusting the example: we just take sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1%5Csupset+A_2%5Csupset%5Cdots&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_1&#92;supset A_2&#92;supset&#92;dots\" title=\"A_1&#92;supset A_2&#92;supset&#92;dots\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n%5Csetminus+A_%7Bn%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" title=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> is infinite for each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbigcap_%7Bn%3D1%7D%5E%5Cinfty+A_n%3D%5Cemptyset&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;bigcap_{n=1}^&#92;infty A_n=&#92;emptyset\" title=\"&#92;bigcap_{n=1}^&#92;infty A_n=&#92;emptyset\" class=\"latex\" />. That ought to do the job once we turn each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n\" title=\"A_n\" class=\"latex\" /> into its equivalence class <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_n%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_n]\" title=\"[A_n]\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>Except that it <em>doesn&#8217;t</em> do the job. In fact, we&#8217;ve already observed that we can just pick a set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B%3D%5C%7Bb_1%2Cb_2%2C%5Cdots%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B=&#92;{b_1,b_2,&#92;dots&#92;}\" title=\"B=&#92;{b_1,b_2,&#92;dots&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_n%5Cin+A_n%5Csetminus+A_%7Bn%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_n&#92;in A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" title=\"b_n&#92;in A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> and then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BB%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[B]\" title=\"[B]\" class=\"latex\" /> will be a non-empty f-intersection of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n\" title=\"A_n\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>However, here&#8217;s an example that does work. We&#8217;ll take all f-sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]\" title=\"[A]\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> has density 1. (This means that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D%7CA%5Ccap%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1}|A&#92;cap&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}|\" title=\"n^{-1}|A&#92;cap&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}|\" class=\"latex\" /> tends<br />\nto 1 as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> tends to infinity.) Since the intersection of any two sets of density 1 has density 1 (a simple exercise), this collection of f-sets has the finite-intersection property. I claim that any f-set contained in all these f-sets must be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B%5Cemptyset%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[&#92;emptyset]\" title=\"[&#92;emptyset]\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>Indeed, let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> be an infinite set and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28b_1%2Cb_2%2C%5Cdots%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(b_1,b_2,&#92;dots)\" title=\"(b_1,b_2,&#92;dots)\" class=\"latex\" /> the enumeration of its elements in increasing order. We can pick a subsequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28c_1%2Cc_2%2C%5Cdots%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(c_1,c_2,&#92;dots)\" title=\"(c_1,c_2,&#92;dots)\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_n%5Cgeq+2%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_n&#92;geq 2^n\" title=\"c_n&#92;geq 2^n\" class=\"latex\" /> for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />, and the corresponding subset <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> is an infinite subset of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> with density zero. Therefore, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+N%5Csetminus+C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb N&#92;setminus C\" title=\"&#92;mathbb N&#92;setminus C\" class=\"latex\" /> is a set of density 1 that does not almost contain <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>The number of f-sets we took there in order to achieve an f-empty intersection was huge: the cardinality of the continuum. (That&#8217;s another easy exercise.) Did we really need that many? This innocent question leads straight to a definition that is needed in order to understand what Malliaris and Shelah did. </p>\n<p><strong>Definition.</strong> The cardinal <strong>p</strong> is the smallest cardinality of a collection <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> of f-sets such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> has the finite-intersection property but also <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> has an empty f-intersection.</p>\n<p>It is simple to prove that this cardinal is uncountable, but it is also known not to be as big as the cardinality of the continuum (where again this means that there are models of set theory &#8212; necessarily ones where CH fails &#8212; for which it is strictly smaller). So it is a rather nice intermediate cardinal, which partially explains its interest to set theorists. </p>\n<p>The cardinal <strong>p</strong> is one of the two infinities that Malliaris and Shelah proved were the same. The other one is closely related. Define a <em>tower</em> to be a collection of f-sets that does not contain <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B%5Cemptyset%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[&#92;emptyset]\" title=\"[&#92;emptyset]\" class=\"latex\" /> and is totally ordered by inclusion. Note that a tower <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> trivially satisfies the finite-intersection property: if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_1%5D%2C%5Cdots%2C%5BA_n%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_1],&#92;dots,[A_n]\" title=\"[A_1],&#92;dots,[A_n]\" class=\"latex\" /> belong to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" />, then the smallest of the f-sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_i%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_i]\" title=\"[A_i]\" class=\"latex\" /> is the f-intersection and it isn&#8217;t f-empty. So let&#8217;s make another definition.</p>\n<p><strong>Definition.</strong> The cardinal <strong>t</strong> is the smallest cardinality of a tower <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> that has an empty f-intersection.</p>\n<p>Since a tower has the finite-intersection property, we are asking for something strictly stronger before, so strictly harder to obtain. It follows that <strong>t</strong> is at least as large as <strong>p</strong>.</p>\n<p>And now we have the obvious question: is the inequality strict? As I have said, it was widely believed that it was, and a big surprise when Malliaris and Shelah proved that the two infinities were in fact equal. </p>\n<p>What does this actually say? It says that if you can find a bunch <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> of f-sets with the finite-intersection property and an empty f-intersection, then you can find a totally ordered example <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> that has at most the cardinality of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<h3>Why is the problem hard?</h3>\n<p>I don&#8217;t have a sophisticated answer to this that would explain why it is hard to experts in set theory. I just want to think about why it might be hard to prove the statement using a naive approach.</p>\n<p>An immediate indication that things might be difficult is that it isn&#8217;t terribly easy to give <em>any</em> example of a tower with an empty f-intersection, let alone one with small cardinality.</p>\n<p>An indication of the problem we face was already present when I gave a failed attempt to construct a system of sets with the finite-intersection property and empty intersection. I took a nested sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_1%5D%5Csupset%5BA_2%5D%5Csupset&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_1]&#92;supset[A_2]&#92;supset\" title=\"[A_1]&#92;supset[A_2]&#92;supset\" class=\"latex\" /> such that the sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n\" title=\"A_n\" class=\"latex\" /> had empty intersection, but that didn&#8217;t work because I could pick an element from each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n%5Csetminus+A_%7Bn%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" title=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> and put those together to make a non-empty f-intersection. (I&#8217;m using &#8220;f-intersection&#8221; to mean any f-set f-contained in all the given f-sets. In general, we can&#8217;t choose a largest one, so it&#8217;s far from unique. The usual terminology would be to say that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is almost contained in every set from a collection of sets, then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is a <em>pseudointersection</em> of that collection. But I&#8217;m trying to express as much as possible in terms of f-sets.) </p>\n<p>Anyone who is familiar with ordinal hierarchies will see that there is an obvious thing we could do here. We could start as above, and then when we find the annoying f-intersection we simply add it to the tower and call it <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Comega%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;omega]\" title=\"[A_&#92;omega]\" class=\"latex\" />. And then inside <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Comega%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;omega]\" title=\"[A_&#92;omega]\" class=\"latex\" /> we can find another nested decreasing sequence of sets and call those <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%7B%5Comega%2B1%7D%5D%2C+%5BA_%7B%5Comega%2B2%7D%5D%2C%5Cdots&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_{&#92;omega+1}], [A_{&#92;omega+2}],&#92;dots\" title=\"[A_{&#92;omega+1}], [A_{&#92;omega+2}],&#92;dots\" class=\"latex\" /> and so on. Those will also have a non-empty f-intersection, which we could call <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%7B2%5Comega%7D%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_{2&#92;omega}]\" title=\"[A_{2&#92;omega}]\" class=\"latex\" />, and so on. </p>\n<p>Let&#8217;s use this idea to prove that there do exist towers with empty f-intersections. I shall build a collection of non-empty f-sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Calpha%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;alpha]\" title=\"[A_&#92;alpha]\" class=\"latex\" /> by transfinite induction. If I have already built <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Calpha%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;alpha]\" title=\"[A_&#92;alpha]\" class=\"latex\" />, I let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%7B%5Calpha%2B1%7D%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_{&#92;alpha+1}]\" title=\"[A_{&#92;alpha+1}]\" class=\"latex\" /> be any non-empty f-set that is strictly f-contained in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Calpha%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;alpha]\" title=\"[A_&#92;alpha]\" class=\"latex\" />. That tells me how to build my sets at successor ordinals. If <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> is a limit ordinal, then I&#8217;ll take <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_&#92;alpha\" title=\"A_&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> to be a non-empty f-intersection of all the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Cbeta%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;beta]\" title=\"[A_&#92;beta]\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta%3C%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta&#60;&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;beta&#60;&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>But how am I so sure that such an f-intersection exists? I&#8217;m not, but if it doesn&#8217;t exist, then I&#8217;m very happy, as that means that the f-sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Cbeta%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;beta]\" title=\"[A_&#92;beta]\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta%3C%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta&#60;&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;beta&#60;&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> form a tower with empty f-intersection.</p>\n<p>Since all the f-sets in this tower are distinct, the process has to terminate at some point, and that implies that a tower with empty f-intersection must exist.</p>\n<p>For a lot of ordinal constructions like this, one can show that the process terminates at the first uncountable ordinal, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Comega_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;omega_1\" title=\"&#92;omega_1\" class=\"latex\" />. To set theorists, this has extremely small cardinality &#8212; by definition, the smallest one after the cardinality of the natural numbers. In some models of set theory, there will be a dizzying array of cardinals between this and the cardinality of the continuum.</p>\n<p>In our case it is not too hard to prove that the process doesn&#8217;t terminate <em>before</em> we get to the first uncountable ordinal. Indeed, if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> is a countable limit ordinal, then we can take an increasing sequence of ordinals <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha_n\" title=\"&#92;alpha_n\" class=\"latex\" /> that tend to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" />, pick an element <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_n\" title=\"b_n\" class=\"latex\" /> from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_%7B%5Calpha_n%7D%5Csetminus+A_%7B%5Calpha_%7Bn%2B1%7D%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_{&#92;alpha_n}&#92;setminus A_{&#92;alpha_{n+1}}\" title=\"A_{&#92;alpha_n}&#92;setminus A_{&#92;alpha_{n+1}}\" class=\"latex\" />, and define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_&#92;alpha\" title=\"A_&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7Bb_1%2Cb_2%2C%5Cdots%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{b_1,b_2,&#92;dots&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{b_1,b_2,&#92;dots&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>However, there doesn&#8217;t seem to be any obvious argument to say that the f-sets <img
