src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Calpha%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;alpha]\" title=\"[A_&#92;alpha]\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%3C%5Comega_1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha&#60;&#92;omega_1\" title=\"&#92;alpha&#60;&#92;omega_1\" class=\"latex\" /> have an empty f-intersection, even if we make some effort to keep our sets small (for example, by defining <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_%7B%5Calpha%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_{&#92;alpha+1}\" title=\"A_{&#92;alpha+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> to consist of every other element of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_&#92;alpha\" title=\"A_&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" />). In fact, we sort of know that there won&#8217;t be such an argument, because if there were, then it would show that there was a tower whose cardinality was that of the first uncountable ordinal. That would prove that <strong>t</strong> had this cardinality, and since <strong>p</strong> is uncountable (that is easy to check) we would immediately know that <strong>p</strong> and <strong>t</strong> were equal.</p>\n<p>So that&#8217;s already an indication that something subtle is going on that you need to be a proper set theorist to understand properly. </p>\n<p>But do we need to understand these funny cardinalities to solve the problem? We don&#8217;t need to know what they are &#8212; just to prove that they are the same. Perhaps that can still be done in a naive way.</p>\n<p>So here&#8217;s a very naive idea. Let&#8217;s take a set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> of f-sets with the finite intersection property and empty f-intersection, and let&#8217;s try to build a tower <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> with empty intersection using only sets from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />. This would certainly be sufficient for showing that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> has cardinality at most that of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />, and if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> has minimal cardinality it would show that <strong>p</strong>=<strong>t</strong>. </p>\n<p>There&#8217;s almost no chance that this will work, but let&#8217;s at least see where it goes wrong, or runs into a brick wall. </p>\n<p>At first things go swimmingly. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Cin+F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]&#92;in F\" title=\"[A]&#92;in F\" class=\"latex\" />. Then there must exist an f-set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%27%5D%27%5Cin+F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A&#039;]&#039;&#92;in F\" title=\"[A&#039;]&#039;&#92;in F\" class=\"latex\" /> that does not f-contain <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]\" title=\"[A]\" class=\"latex\" />, since otherwise <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]\" title=\"[A]\" class=\"latex\" /> itself would be a non-empty f-intersection for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />. But then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ccap+%5BA%27%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]&#92;cap [A&#039;]\" title=\"[A]&#92;cap [A&#039;]\" class=\"latex\" /> is a proper f-subset of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A]\" title=\"[A]\" class=\"latex\" />, and by the finite-intersection property it is not f-empty.</p>\n<p>By iterating this argument, we can therefore obtain a nested sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_1%5D%5Csupset%5BA_2%5D%5Csupset&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_1]&#92;supset[A_2]&#92;supset\" title=\"[A_1]&#92;supset[A_2]&#92;supset\" class=\"latex\" /> of f-sets in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>The next thing we&#8217;d like to do is create <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_%5Comega%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_&#92;omega]\" title=\"[A_&#92;omega]\" class=\"latex\" />. And this, unsurprisingly, is where the brick wall is. Consider, for example, the case where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> consists of all sets of density 1. What if we stupidly chose <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n\" title=\"A_n\" class=\"latex\" /> in such a way that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmin+A_n%5Cgeq+2%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;min A_n&#92;geq 2^n\" title=\"&#92;min A_n&#92;geq 2^n\" class=\"latex\" /> for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />? Then our diagonal procedure &#8212; picking an element from each set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_n%5Csetminus+A_%7Bn%2B1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" title=\"A_n&#92;setminus A_{n+1}\" class=\"latex\" /> &#8212; would yield a set of density zero. Of course, we could go for a different diagonal procedure. We would need to prove that for this particular <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> and any nested sequence we can always find an f-intersection that belongs to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />. That&#8217;s equivalent to saying that for any sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1%5Csupset+A_2%5Csupset&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A_1&#92;supset A_2&#92;supset\" title=\"A_1&#92;supset A_2&#92;supset\" class=\"latex\" /> of dense sets we can find a set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%5Csetminus+A_n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A&#92;setminus A_n\" title=\"A&#92;setminus A_n\" class=\"latex\" /> is finite for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> has density 1. </p>\n<p>That&#8217;s a fairly simple (but not trivial) exercise I think, but when I tried to write a proof straight down I failed &#8212; it&#8217;s more like a pen-and-paper job until you get the construction right. But here&#8217;s the real question I&#8217;d like to know the answer to right at this moment. It splits into two questions actually.</p>\n<p><strong>Question 1.</strong> <em>Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> be a collection of f-sets with the finite-intersection property and no non-empty f-intersection. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_1%5D%5Csupset%5BA_2%5D%5Csupset%5Cdots&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[A_1]&#92;supset[A_2]&#92;supset&#92;dots\" title=\"[A_1]&#92;supset[A_2]&#92;supset&#92;dots\" class=\"latex\" /> be a nested sequence of elements of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />. Must this sequence have an f-intersection that belongs to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />?</em></p>\n<p><strong>Question 2.</strong> <em>If, as seems likely, the answer to Question 1 is no, must it at least be the case that there exists a nested sequence in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> with an f-intersection that also belongs to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />?</em></p>\n<p>If the answer to Question 2 turned out to be yes, it would naturally lead to the following further question.</p>\n<p><strong>Question 3.</strong> <em>If the answer to Question 2 is yes, then how far can we go with it? For example, must <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> contain a nested transfinite sequence of uncountable length?</em></p>\n<p>Unfortunately, even a positive answer to Question 3 would not be enough for us, for reasons I&#8217;ve already given. It might be the case that we can indeed build nice big towers in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />, but that the arguments stop working once we reach the first uncountable ordinal. Indeed, it might well be known that there are sets <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> with the finite-intersection property and no non-empty f-intersection that do not contain towers that are bigger than this. If that&#8217;s the case, it would give at least one serious reason for the problem being hard. It would tell us that we can&#8217;t prove the equality by just finding a suitable tower inside <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />: instead, we&#8217;d need to do something more indirect, constructing a tower <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> and some non-obvious injection from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=T&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"T\" title=\"T\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" />. (It would be non-obvious because it would not preserve the subset relation.) </p>\n<p>Another way the problem might be difficult is if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> does contain a tower with no non-empty f-intersection, but we can&#8217;t extend an arbitrary tower in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=F&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"F\" title=\"F\" class=\"latex\" /> to a tower with this property. Perhaps if we started off building our tower the wrong way, it would lead us down a path that had a dead end long before the tower was big enough, even though good paths and good towers did exist.</p>\n<p>But these are just pure speculations on my part. I&#8217;m sure the answers to many of my questions are known. If so, I&#8217;ll be interested to hear about it, and to understand better why Malliaris and Shelah had to use big tools and a much less obvious argument than the kind of thing I was trying to do above.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 19 Sep 2017 09:29:01 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"b1fe680cfcfb89c2a222a6c30a02e883","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-709_4d3c0474cfeb94c8.webp","destWidth":12,"destHeight":11,"sourceBytes":178,"destBytes":172,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-709_4d3c0474cfeb94c8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-23-346_ea1814038d50c869.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-19-058_f836c79e20a75af1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ccap%5BB%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn43@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-18-111_9494c3e8f0a6d446.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5Ccap+B%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn56@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-16-114_1e5b2ad4c003df11.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ccup+%5BB%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn7@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-20-129_aed328102b7d0a13.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5Ccup+B%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn7@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-26-527_78a4434ff1b0cab2.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ec&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-17-126_8f0cb0a3ce243c96.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5Ec%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn12@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-25-372_627ed1dcafe1134c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Csubset%5BB%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https p.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA%5D%5Ccap+%5BA%27%5D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn48@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-19-918_4339f21158631a47.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmin+A_n%5Cgeq+2%5En&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-21-110_4b9b15ccdc994bb8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A_1%5Csupset+A_2%5Csupset&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn22@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-30-136_8bf0d99002640fe7.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5BA_1%5D%5Csupset%5BA_2%5D%5Csupset%5Cdots&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn98@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-30-019_0fbdb607e1582a82.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694451},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Call for nominations for the 2018 Chern Medal","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6205","description":"<p><em>This is a guest post by Caroline Series.</em></p>\n<p>The Chern Medal is a relatively new prize, awarded once every four years jointly by the IMU and the Chern Medal Foundation (CMF) to an individual whose accomplishments warrant the highest level of recognition for outstanding achievements in the field of mathematics.  Funded by the CMF, the Medalist receives a cash prize of US$ 250,000.  In addition, each Medalist may nominate one or more organizations to receive funding totalling US$ 250,000, for the support of research, education, or other outreach programs in the field of mathematics. </p>\n<p>Professor Chern devoted his life to mathematics, both in active research and education, and in nurturing the field whenever the opportunity arose. He obtained fundamental results in all the major aspects of modern geometry and founded the area of global differential geometry. Chern exhibited keen aesthetic tastes in his selection of problems, and the breadth of his work deepened the connections of geometry with different areas of mathematics. He was also generous during his lifetime in his personal support of the field.</p>\n<p>Nominations should be sent to the Prize Committee Chair:  Caroline Series, email: chair(at)chern18.mathunion.org  by 31st December 2016. Further details and nomination guidelines for this and the other IMU prizes can be found <a href=\"http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/\">here</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 14 Nov 2016 10:00:50 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"669eb347f85cfb5686115ad37d5b8293","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694455},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Intransitive dice VI: sketch proof of the main conjecture for the balanced-sequences model","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6318","description":"<p>I have now completed <a href=\"https://gowers.files.wordpress.com/2017/07/polymath131.pdf\">a draft of a write-up</a> of a proof of the following statement. Recall that a <em>random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die</em> (in the balanced-sequences model) is a sequence of length <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> of integers between 1 and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> that add up to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />, chosen uniformly from all such sequences. A die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" title=\"(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> <em>beats</em> a die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" title=\"(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> if the number of pairs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28i%2Cj%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(i,j)\" title=\"(i,j)\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Eb_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i&#62;b_j\" title=\"a_i&#62;b_j\" class=\"latex\" /> exceeds the number of pairs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28i%2Cj%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(i,j)\" title=\"(i,j)\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Cb_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i&#60;b_j\" title=\"a_i&#60;b_j\" class=\"latex\" />. If the two numbers are the same, we say that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> <em>ties with</em> <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p><strong>Theorem.</strong> <em>Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%2CB&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A,B\" title=\"A,B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> be random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice. Then the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac+12%2Bo%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;frac 12+o(1)\" title=\"&#92;frac 12+o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />.</em></p>\n<p>In this post I want to give a fairly detailed sketch of the proof, which will I hope make it clearer what is going on in the write-up.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6318\"></span></p>\n<p>The first step is to show that the theorem is equivalent to the following statement.</p>\n<p><strong>Theorem.</strong> <em>Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> be a random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die. Then with probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-o%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-o(1)\" title=\"1-o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />, the proportion of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac+12%2Bo%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;frac 12+o(1)\" title=\"&#92;frac 12+o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />.</em></p>\n<p>We had two proofs of this statement in earlier posts and comments on this blog. In the write-up I have used a very nice short proof supplied by Luke Pebody. There is no need to repeat it here, since there isn&#8217;t much to say that will make it any easier to understand than it already is. I will, however, mention once again an example that illustrates quite well what this statement does and doesn&#8217;t say. The example is of a tournament (that is, complete graph where every edge is given a direction) where every vertex beats half the other vertices (meaning that half the edges at the vertex go in and half go out) but the tournament does not look at all random. One just takes an odd integer <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> and puts arrows out from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%2By&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x+y\" title=\"x+y\" class=\"latex\" /> mod <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5Cin%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2C%28n-1%29%2F2%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y&#92;in&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,(n-1)/2&#92;}\" title=\"y&#92;in&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,(n-1)/2&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />, and arrows into <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5Cin%5C%7B%28n%2B1%29%2F2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn-1%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y&#92;in&#92;{(n+1)/2,&#92;dots,n-1&#92;}\" title=\"y&#92;in&#92;{(n+1)/2,&#92;dots,n-1&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />. It is not hard to check that the probability that there is an arrow from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"z\" title=\"z\" class=\"latex\" /> given that there are arrows from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" /> to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"z\" title=\"z\" class=\"latex\" /> is approximately 1/2, and this turns out to be a general phenomenon.</p>\n<p>So how do we prove that almost all <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice beat approximately half the other <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice?</p>\n<p>The first step is to recast the problem as one about sums of independent random variables. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" /> stand for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> as usual. Given a sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29%5Cin%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)&#92;in[n]^n\" title=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)&#92;in[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" /> we define a function <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%3A%5Bn%5D%5Cto%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A:[n]&#92;to[n]\" title=\"f_A:[n]&#92;to[n]\" class=\"latex\" /> by setting <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A(j)\" title=\"f_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be the number of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Cj&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i&#60;j\" title=\"a_i&#60;j\" class=\"latex\" /> plus half the number of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%3Dj&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i=j\" title=\"a_i=j\" class=\"latex\" />. We also define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29-%28j-1%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A(j)-(j-1/2)\" title=\"f_A(j)-(j-1/2)\" class=\"latex\" />. It is not hard to verify that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29%3C0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)&#60;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)&#60;0\" class=\"latex\" />, ties with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)=0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)=0\" class=\"latex\" />, and loses to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)&#62;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>So our question now becomes the following. Suppose we choose a random sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28b_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cb_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" title=\"(b_1,&#92;dots,b_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> with the property that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jb_j%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jb_j=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jb_j=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. What is the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jg_A%28b_j%29%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)&#62;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jg_A(b_j)&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" />? (Of course, the answer depends on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />, and most of the work of the proof comes in showing that a &#8220;typical&#8221; <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> has properties that ensure that the probability is about 1/2.)</p>\n<p>It is convenient to rephrase the problem slightly, replacing <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_j\" title=\"b_j\" class=\"latex\" /> by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=b_j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"b_j-(n+1)/2\" title=\"b_j-(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. We can then ask it as follows. Suppose we choose a sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28V_1%2C%5Cdots%2CV_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(V_1,&#92;dots,V_n)\" title=\"(V_1,&#92;dots,V_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> elements of the set <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B-%28n-1%29%2F2%2C-%28n-1%29%2F2%2B1%2C%5Cdots%2C%28n-1%29%2F2%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{-(n-1)/2,-(n-1)/2+1,&#92;dots,(n-1)/2&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{-(n-1)/2,-(n-1)/2+1,&#92;dots,(n-1)/2&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />, where the terms of the sequence are independent and uniformly distributed. For each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=U_j%3Dg_A%28V_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"U_j=g_A(V_j)\" title=\"U_j=g_A(V_j)\" class=\"latex\" />. What is the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jU_j%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jU_j&#62;0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jU_j&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" /> given that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jV_j%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jV_j=0\" title=\"&#92;sum_jV_j=0\" class=\"latex\" />?</p>\n<p>This is a question about the distribution of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_j%28U_j%2CV_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_j(U_j,V_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_j(U_j,V_j)\" class=\"latex\" />, where the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U_j%2CV_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U_j,V_j)\" title=\"(U_j,V_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> are i.i.d. random variables taking values in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" /> (at least if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> is odd &#8212; a small modification is needed if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> is even). Everything we know about probability would lead us to expect that this distribution is approximately Gaussian, and since it has mean <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%280%2C0%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(0,0)\" title=\"(0,0)\" class=\"latex\" />, it ought to be the case that if we sum up the probabilities that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_j%28U_j%2CV_j%29%3D%28x%2C0%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_j(U_j,V_j)=(x,0)\" title=\"&#92;sum_j(U_j,V_j)=(x,0)\" class=\"latex\" /> over positive <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" />, we should get roughly the same as if we sum them up over negative <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" />. Also, it is highly plausible that the probability of getting <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%280%2C0%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(0,0)\" title=\"(0,0)\" class=\"latex\" /> will be a lot smaller than either of these two sums.</p>\n<p>So there we have a heuristic argument for why the second theorem, and hence the first, ought to be true.</p>\n<p>There are several theorems in the literature that initially seemed as though they should be helpful. And indeed they <em>were</em> helpful, but we were unable to apply them directly, and had instead to develop our own modifications of their proofs.</p>\n<p>The obvious theorem to mention is the central limit theorem. But this is not strong enough for two reasons. The first is that it tells you about the probability that a sum of random variables will lie in some rectangular region of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb R^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb R^2\" class=\"latex\" /> of size comparable to the standard deviation. It will not tell you the probability of belonging to some subset of the y-axis (even for discrete random variables). Another problem is that the central limit on its own does not give information about the rate of convergence to a Gaussian, whereas here we require one.</p>\n<p>The second problem is dealt with for many applications by <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berry%E2%80%93Esseen_theorem\">the Berry-Esseen theorem</a>, but not the first.</p>\n<p>The first problem is dealt with for many applications by <em>local</em> central limit theorems, <a href=\"https://terrytao.wordpress.com/tag/local-limit-theorems/\">about which Terence Tao has blogged in the past</a>. These tell you not just about the probability of landing in a region, but about the probability of actually equalling some given value, with estimates that are precise enough to give, in many situations, the kind of information that we seek here.</p>\n<p>What we did not find, however, was precisely the theorem we were looking for: a statement that would be local and 2-dimensional and would give information about the rate of convergence that was sufficiently strong that we would be able to obtain good enough convergence after only <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> steps. (I use the word &#8220;step&#8221; here because we can think of a sum of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> independent copies of a 2D random variable as an <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-step random walk.) It was not even clear in advance what such a theorem should say, since we did not know what properties we would be able to prove about the random variables <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U_i%2CV_i%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U_i,V_i)\" title=\"(U_i,V_i)\" class=\"latex\" /> when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> was &#8220;typical&#8221;. That is, we knew that not every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> worked, so the structure of the proof (probably) had to be as follows.</p>\n<p>1. Prove that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> has certain properties with probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-o%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-o(1)\" title=\"1-o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>2. Using these properties, deduce that the sum <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_%7Bi%3D1%7D%5En%28U_i%2CV_i%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_{i=1}^n(U_i,V_i)\" title=\"&#92;sum_{i=1}^n(U_i,V_i)\" class=\"latex\" /> converges very well after <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> steps to a Gaussian.</p>\n<p>3. Conclude that the heuristic argument is indeed correct.</p>\n<p>The key properties that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> needed to have were the following two. First, there needed to be a bound on the higher moments of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=U&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"U\" title=\"U\" class=\"latex\" />. This we achieved in a slightly wasteful way &#8212; but the cost was a log factor that we could afford &#8212; by arguing that with high probability no value of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> has magnitude greater than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=6%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"6&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" title=\"6&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" />. To prove this the steps were as follows.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> be a random element of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" />. Then the probability that there exists <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29%5Cgeq+6%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)&#92;geq 6&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" title=\"g_A(j)&#92;geq 6&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" /> is at most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-k%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-k}\" title=\"n^{-k}\" class=\"latex\" /> (for some <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"k\" title=\"k\" class=\"latex\" /> such as 10).</li>\n<li>The probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_ia_i%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_ia_i=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> is at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=cn%5E%7B-3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"cn^{-3/2}\" title=\"cn^{-3/2}\" class=\"latex\" /> for some absolute constant <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c&#62;0\" title=\"c&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" />.</li>\n<li>It follows that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> is a random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die, then with probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-o%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-o(1)\" title=\"1-o(1)\" class=\"latex\" /> we have <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7Cg_A%28j%29%7C%5Cleq+6%5Csqrt%7Bn%5Clog+n%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|g_A(j)|&#92;leq 6&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" title=\"|g_A(j)|&#92;leq 6&#92;sqrt{n&#92;log n}\" class=\"latex\" /> for every <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>The proofs of the first two statements are standard probabilistic estimates about sums of independent random variables.</p>\n<p>The second property that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> needed to have is more difficult to obtain. There is a standard Fourier-analytic approach to proving central limit theorems, and in order to get good convergence it turns out that what one wants is for a certain Fourier transform to be sufficiently well bounded away from 1. More precisely, we define the <em>characteristic function</em> of the random variable <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28U%2CV%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(U,V)\" title=\"(U,V)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3D%5Cmathbb+E+e%28%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bx%2Cy%7Df%28x%2Cy%29e%28%5Calpha+x%2B%5Cbeta+y%29%2C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;mathbb E e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)e(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y),\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=&#92;mathbb E e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)=&#92;sum_{x,y}f(x,y)e(&#92;alpha x+&#92;beta y),\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%28x%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e(x)\" title=\"e(x)\" class=\"latex\" /> is shorthand for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cexp%282%5Cpi+ix%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;exp(2&#92;pi ix)\" title=\"&#92;exp(2&#92;pi ix)\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f%28x%2Cy%29%3D%5Cmathbb+P%5B%28U%2CV%29%3D%28x%2Cy%29%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f(x,y)=&#92;mathbb P[(U,V)=(x,y)]\" title=\"f(x,y)=&#92;mathbb P[(U,V)=(x,y)]\" class=\"latex\" />, and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> range over <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+T%3D%5Cmathbb+R%2F%5Cmathbb+Z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb T=&#92;mathbb R/&#92;mathbb Z\" title=\"&#92;mathbb T=&#92;mathbb R/&#92;mathbb Z\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>I&#8217;ll come later to why it is good for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" class=\"latex\" /> not to be too close to 1. But for now I want to concentrate on how one proves a statement like this, since that is perhaps the least standard part of the argument.</p>\n<p>To get an idea, let us first think what it would take for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|\" title=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|\" class=\"latex\" /> to be very close to 1. This condition basically tells us that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V\" title=\"&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V\" class=\"latex\" /> is highly concentrated mod 1: indeed, if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V\" title=\"&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V\" class=\"latex\" /> is highly concentrated, then <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%28%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)\" title=\"e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)\" class=\"latex\" /> takes approximately the same value almost all the time, so the average is roughly equal to that value, which has modulus 1; conversely, if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V\" title=\"&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V\" class=\"latex\" /> is not highly concentrated mod 1, then there is plenty of cancellation between the different values of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%28%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)\" title=\"e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)\" class=\"latex\" /> and the result is that the average has modulus appreciably smaller than 1.</p>\n<p>So the task is to prove that the values of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V\" title=\"&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V\" class=\"latex\" /> are reasonably well spread about mod 1. Note that this is saying that the values of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha+g_A%28j%29%2B%5Cbeta%28j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha g_A(j)+&#92;beta(j-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"&#92;alpha g_A(j)+&#92;beta(j-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" /> are reasonably spread about. </p>\n<p>The way we prove this is roughly as follows. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%3E0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha&#62;0\" title=\"&#92;alpha&#62;0\" class=\"latex\" />, let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m\" title=\"m\" class=\"latex\" /> be of order of magnitude <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5E%7B-2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha^{-2}\" title=\"&#92;alpha^{-2}\" class=\"latex\" />, and consider the values of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A\" title=\"g_A\" class=\"latex\" /> at the four points <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%2C+j%2Bm%2C+j%2B2m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j, j+m, j+2m\" title=\"j, j+m, j+2m\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%2B3m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j+3m\" title=\"j+3m\" class=\"latex\" />. Then a typical order of magnitude of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29-g_A%28j%2Bm%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)-g_A(j+m)\" title=\"g_A(j)-g_A(j+m)\" class=\"latex\" /> is around <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csqrt+m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sqrt m\" title=\"&#92;sqrt m\" class=\"latex\" />, and one can prove without too much trouble (here the Berry-Esseen theorem was helpful to keep the proof short) that the probability that </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7Cg_A%28j%29-g_A%28j%2Bm%29-g_A%28j%2B2m%29%2Bg_A%283m%29%7C%5Cgeq+c%5Csqrt+m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|g_A(j)-g_A(j+m)-g_A(j+2m)+g_A(3m)|&#92;geq c&#92;sqrt m\" title=\"|g_A(j)-g_A(j+m)-g_A(j+2m)+g_A(3m)|&#92;geq c&#92;sqrt m\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>is at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c\" title=\"c\" class=\"latex\" />, for some positive absolute constant <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c\" title=\"c\" class=\"latex\" />. It follows by Markov&#8217;s inequality that with positive probability one has the above inequality for many values of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>That&#8217;s not quite good enough, since we want a probability that&#8217;s very close to 1. This we obtain by chopping up <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" /> into intervals of length <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=4m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"4m\" title=\"4m\" class=\"latex\" /> and applying the above argument in each interval. (While writing this I&#8217;m coming to think that I could just as easily have gone for progressions of length 3, not that it matters much.) Then in each interval there is a reasonable probability of getting the above inequality to hold many times, from which one can prove that with very high probability it holds many times. </p>\n<p>But since <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m\" title=\"m\" class=\"latex\" /> is of order <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5E%7B-2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha^{-2}\" title=\"&#92;alpha^{-2}\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5Csqrt+m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt m\" title=\"&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt m\" class=\"latex\" /> is of order 1, which gives that the values <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=e%28g_A%28j%29%29%2C+e%28g_A%28j%2Bm%29%29%2C+e%28g_A%28j%2B2m%29%2C+e%28g_A%28j%2B3m%29%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"e(g_A(j)), e(g_A(j+m)), e(g_A(j+2m), e(g_A(j+3m))\" title=\"e(g_A(j)), e(g_A(j+m)), e(g_A(j+2m), e(g_A(j+3m))\" class=\"latex\" /> are far from constant whenever the above inequality holds. So by averaging we end up with a good upper bound for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|\" title=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>The alert reader will have noticed that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5Cll+n%5E%7B-1%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha&#92;ll n^{-1/2}\" title=\"&#92;alpha&#92;ll n^{-1/2}\" class=\"latex\" />, then the above argument doesn&#8217;t work, because we can&#8217;t choose <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m\" title=\"m\" class=\"latex\" /> to be bigger than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />. In that case, however, we just do the best we can: we choose <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=m&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"m\" title=\"m\" class=\"latex\" /> to be of order <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%2F%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n/&#92;log n\" title=\"n/&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" />, the logarithmic factor being there because we need to operate in many different intervals in order to get the probability to be high. We will get many quadruples where </p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%7Cg_A%28j%29-g_A%28j%2Bm%29-g_A%28j%2B2m%29%2Bg_A%283m%29%7C%5Cgeq+c%5Calpha%5Csqrt+m%3Dc%27%5Calpha%5Csqrt%7Bn%2F%5Clog+n%7D%2C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha|g_A(j)-g_A(j+m)-g_A(j+2m)+g_A(3m)|&#92;geq c&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt m=c&#039;&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt{n/&#92;log n},\" title=\"&#92;alpha|g_A(j)-g_A(j+m)-g_A(j+2m)+g_A(3m)|&#92;geq c&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt m=c&#039;&#92;alpha&#92;sqrt{n/&#92;log n},\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>and this translates into a lower bound for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-%7C%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|\" title=\"1-|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|\" class=\"latex\" /> of order <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5E2n%2F%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha^2n/&#92;log n\" title=\"&#92;alpha^2n/&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" />, basically because <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-%5Ccos%5Ctheta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-&#92;cos&#92;theta\" title=\"1-&#92;cos&#92;theta\" class=\"latex\" /> has order <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta^2\" title=\"&#92;theta^2\" class=\"latex\" /> for small <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Ctheta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;theta\" title=\"&#92;theta\" class=\"latex\" />. This is a good bound for us as long as we can use it to prove that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%7C%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|^n\" title=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|^n\" class=\"latex\" /> is bounded above by a large negative power of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />. For that we need <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5E2n%2F%5Clog+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha^2n/&#92;log n\" title=\"&#92;alpha^2n/&#92;log n\" class=\"latex\" /> to be at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%5Clog+n%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C&#92;log n/n\" title=\"C&#92;log n/n\" class=\"latex\" /> (since <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281-C%5Clog+n%2Fn%29%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(1-C&#92;log n/n)^n\" title=\"(1-C&#92;log n/n)^n\" class=\"latex\" /> is about <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cexp%28-C%5Clog+n%29%3Dn%5E%7B-C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;exp(-C&#92;log n)=n^{-C}\" title=\"&#92;exp(-C&#92;log n)=n^{-C}\" class=\"latex\" />), so we are in good shape provided that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%5Cgg%5Clog+n%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha&#92;gg&#92;log n/n\" title=\"&#92;alpha&#92;gg&#92;log n/n\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>The alert reader will also have noticed that the probabilities for different intervals are not independent: for example, if some <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=f_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"f_A(j)\" title=\"f_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> is equal to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />, then beyond that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> depends linearly on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" />. However, except when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j\" title=\"j\" class=\"latex\" /> is very large, this is extremely unlikely, and it is basically the only thing that can go wrong. To make this rigorous we formulated a concentration inequality that states, roughly speaking, that if you have a bunch of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"k\" title=\"k\" class=\"latex\" /> events, and almost always (that is, always, unless some very unlikely event occurs) the probability that the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" />th event holds given that all the previous events hold is at least <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c\" title=\"c\" class=\"latex\" />, then the probability that fewer than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=ck%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"ck/2\" title=\"ck/2\" class=\"latex\" /> of the events hold is exponentially small in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=k&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"k\" title=\"k\" class=\"latex\" />. The proof of the concentration inequality is a standard exponential-moment argument, with a small extra step to show that the low-probability events don&#8217;t mess things up too much.</p>\n<p>Incidentally, the idea of splitting up the interval in this way came from <a href=\"https://mathoverflow.net/questions/272544/the-mean-square-distance-of-a-random-walk-from-the-origin\">an answer by Serguei Popov to a Mathoverflow question I asked</a>, when I got slightly stuck trying to prove a lower bound for the second moment of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=U&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"U\" title=\"U\" class=\"latex\" />. I eventually didn&#8217;t use that bound, but the interval-splitting idea helped for the bound for the Fourier coefficient as well. </p>\n<p>So in this way we prove that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%7C%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|^n\" title=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|^n\" class=\"latex\" /> is very small if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Calpha%7C%5Cgg%5Clog+n%2Fn&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;alpha|&#92;gg&#92;log n/n\" title=\"|&#92;alpha|&#92;gg&#92;log n/n\" class=\"latex\" />. A simpler argument of a similar flavour shows that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%7C%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|^n\" title=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|^n\" class=\"latex\" /> is also very small if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Calpha%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;alpha|\" title=\"|&#92;alpha|\" class=\"latex\" /> is smaller than this and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Cbeta%7C%5Cgg+n%5E%7B-3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;beta|&#92;gg n^{-3/2}\" title=\"|&#92;beta|&#92;gg n^{-3/2}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Now let us return to the question of why we might like <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%7C%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|^n\" title=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|^n\" class=\"latex\" /> to be small. It follows from the inversion and convolution formulae in Fourier analysis. The convolution formula tells us that the characteristic function of the sum of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=U_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"U_i\" title=\"U_i\" class=\"latex\" /> (which are independent and each have characteristic function <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f\" title=\"&#92;hat f\" class=\"latex\" />) is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Chat+f%29%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;hat f)^n\" title=\"(&#92;hat f)^n\" class=\"latex\" />. And then the inversion formula tells us that</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+P%5B%28%5Csum_iU_i%2C%5Csum_iV_i%29%3D%28x%2Cy%29%5D%3D%5Cint_%7B%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%5Cin%5Cmathbb+T%5E2%7D%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%5Ene%28-%5Calpha+x-%5Cbeta+y%29%5Cmathop%7Bd%5Calpha%7D%5Cmathop%7Bd%5Cbeta%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb P[(&#92;sum_iU_i,&#92;sum_iV_i)=(x,y)]=&#92;int_{(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)&#92;in&#92;mathbb T^2}&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)^ne(-&#92;alpha x-&#92;beta y)&#92;mathop{d&#92;alpha}&#92;mathop{d&#92;beta}\" title=\"&#92;mathbb P[(&#92;sum_iU_i,&#92;sum_iV_i)=(x,y)]=&#92;int_{(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)&#92;in&#92;mathbb T^2}&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)^ne(-&#92;alpha x-&#92;beta y)&#92;mathop{d&#92;alpha}&#92;mathop{d&#92;beta}\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>What we have proved can be used to show that the contribution to the integral on the right-hand side from those pairs <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" title=\"(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" class=\"latex\" /> that lie outside a small rectangle (of width <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-1}\" title=\"n^{-1}\" class=\"latex\" /> in the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> direction and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-3%2F2%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n^{-3/2}\" title=\"n^{-3/2}\" class=\"latex\" /> in the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> direction, up to log factors) is negligible.</p>\n<p>All the above is true provided the random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> satisfies two properties (the bound on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7CU%5C%7C_%5Cinfty&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;|U&#92;|_&#92;infty\" title=\"&#92;|U&#92;|_&#92;infty\" class=\"latex\" /> and the bound on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%7C%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%7C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|\" title=\"|&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)|\" class=\"latex\" />), which it does with probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-o%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-o(1)\" title=\"1-o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>We now take a die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> with these properties and turn our attention to what happens inside this box. First, it is a standard fact about characteristic functions that their derivatives tell us about moments. Indeed,</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac%7B%5Cpartial%5E%7Br%2Bs%7D%7D%7B%5Cpartial%5Er%5Calpha%5Cpartial%5Es%5Cbeta%7D%5Cmathbb+E+e%28%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V%29%3D%282%5Cpi+i%29%5E%7Br%2Bs%7D%5Cmathbb+E+U%5ErV%5Es+e%28%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;frac{&#92;partial^{r+s}}{&#92;partial^r&#92;alpha&#92;partial^s&#92;beta}&#92;mathbb E e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)=(2&#92;pi i)^{r+s}&#92;mathbb E U^rV^s e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)\" title=\"&#92;frac{&#92;partial^{r+s}}{&#92;partial^r&#92;alpha&#92;partial^s&#92;beta}&#92;mathbb E e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)=(2&#92;pi i)^{r+s}&#92;mathbb E U^rV^s e(&#92;alpha U+&#92;beta V)\" class=\"latex\" />,</p>\n<p>and when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%3D%5Cbeta%3D0&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha=&#92;beta=0\" title=\"&#92;alpha=&#92;beta=0\" class=\"latex\" /> this is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E+U%5ErV%5Es&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb E U^rV^s\" title=\"&#92;mathbb E U^rV^s\" class=\"latex\" />. It therefore follows from the two-dimensional version of Taylor&#8217;s theorem that</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3D1-2%5Cpi%5E2%28%5Calpha%5E2%5Cmathbb+EU%5E2%2B2%5Calpha%5Cbeta%5Cmathbb+EUV%2B%5Cbeta%5E2%5Cmathbb+EV%5E2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=1-2&#92;pi^2(&#92;alpha^2&#92;mathbb EU^2+2&#92;alpha&#92;beta&#92;mathbb EUV+&#92;beta^2&#92;mathbb EV^2)\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)=1-2&#92;pi^2(&#92;alpha^2&#92;mathbb EU^2+2&#92;alpha&#92;beta&#92;mathbb EUV+&#92;beta^2&#92;mathbb EV^2)\" class=\"latex\" /></p>\n<p>plus a remainder term <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"R(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" title=\"R(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" class=\"latex\" /> that can be bounded above by a constant times <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%7C%5Calpha%7C%5C%7CU%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%2B%7C%5Cbeta%7C%5C%7CV%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%29%5E3&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(|&#92;alpha|&#92;|U&#92;|_&#92;infty+|&#92;beta|&#92;|V&#92;|_&#92;infty)^3\" title=\"(|&#92;alpha|&#92;|U&#92;|_&#92;infty+|&#92;beta|&#92;|V&#92;|_&#92;infty)^3\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Writing <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" title=\"Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" class=\"latex\" /> for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5Cpi%5E2%28%5Calpha%5E2%5Cmathbb+EU%5E2%2B2%5Calpha%5Cbeta%5Cmathbb+EUV%2B%5Cbeta%5E2%5Cmathbb+EV%5E2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"2&#92;pi^2(&#92;alpha^2&#92;mathbb EU^2+2&#92;alpha&#92;beta&#92;mathbb EUV+&#92;beta^2&#92;mathbb EV^2)\" title=\"2&#92;pi^2(&#92;alpha^2&#92;mathbb EU^2+2&#92;alpha&#92;beta&#92;mathbb EUV+&#92;beta^2&#92;mathbb EV^2)\" class=\"latex\" /> we have that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" /> is a positive semidefinite quadratic form in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" />. (In fact, it turns out to be positive definite.) Provided <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"R(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" title=\"R(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" class=\"latex\" /> is small enough, replacing it by zero does not have much effect on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)^n\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)^n\" class=\"latex\" />, and provided <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)^2\" title=\"Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)^2\" class=\"latex\" /> is small enough, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281-Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%29%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(1-Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta))^n\" title=\"(1-Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta))^n\" class=\"latex\" /> is well approximated by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cexp%28-Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;exp(-Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta))\" title=\"&#92;exp(-Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta))\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>It turns out, crucially, that the approximations just described are valid in a box that is much bigger than the box inside which <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" title=\"&#92;hat f(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta)\" class=\"latex\" /> has a chance of not being small. That implies that the Gaussian decays quickly (and is why we know that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" /> is positive definite).</p>\n<p>There is a bit of back-of-envelope calculation needed to check this, but the upshot is that the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Csum_iU_i%2C%5Csum_iV_i%29%3D%28x%2Cy%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;sum_iU_i,&#92;sum_iV_i)=(x,y)\" title=\"(&#92;sum_iU_i,&#92;sum_iV_i)=(x,y)\" class=\"latex\" /> is very well approximated, at least when <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" /> aren&#8217;t too big, by a formula of the form</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G%28x%2Cy%29%3D%5Cint%5Cexp%28-Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%29e%28-%5Calpha+x-%5Cbeta+y%29%5Cmathop%7Bd%5Calpha%7D%5Cmathop%7Bd%5Cbeta%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"G(x,y)=&#92;int&#92;exp(-Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta))e(-&#92;alpha x-&#92;beta y)&#92;mathop{d&#92;alpha}&#92;mathop{d&#92;beta}\" title=\"G(x,y)=&#92;int&#92;exp(-Q(&#92;alpha,&#92;beta))e(-&#92;alpha x-&#92;beta y)&#92;mathop{d&#92;alpha}&#92;mathop{d&#92;beta}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>But this is the formula for the Fourier transform of a Gaussian (at least if we let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;alpha\" title=\"&#92;alpha\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbeta&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;beta\" title=\"&#92;beta\" class=\"latex\" /> range over <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+R%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb R^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb R^2\" class=\"latex\" />, which makes very little difference to the integral because the Gaussian decays so quickly), so it is the   restriction to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+Z%5E2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" title=\"&#92;mathbb Z^2\" class=\"latex\" /> of a Gaussian, just as we wanted.</p>\n<p>When we sum over infinitely many values of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" />, uniform estimates are not good enough, but we can deal with that very directly by using simple measure concentration estimates to prove that the probability that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Csum_iU_i%2C%5Csum_iV_i%29%3D%28x%2Cy%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;sum_iU_i,&#92;sum_iV_i)=(x,y)\" title=\"(&#92;sum_iU_i,&#92;sum_iV_i)=(x,y)\" class=\"latex\" /> is very small outside a not too large box.</p>\n<p>That completes the sketch of the main ideas that go into showing that the heuristic argument is indeed correct.</p>\n<p>Any comments about the current draft would be very welcome, and if anyone feels like working on it directly rather than through me, that is certainly a possibility &#8212; just let me know. I will try to post soon on the following questions, since it would be very nice to be able to add answers to them.</p>\n<p>1. Is the more general quasirandomness conjecture false, as the experimental evidence suggests? (It is equivalent to the statement that if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> are two random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice, then with probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1-o%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1-o(1)\" title=\"1-o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />, the four possibilities for whether another die beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and whether it beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> each have probability <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac+14%2Bo%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;frac 14+o(1)\" title=\"&#92;frac 14+o(1)\" class=\"latex\" />.)</p>\n<p>2. What happens in the multiset model? Can the above method of proof be adapted to this case?</p>\n<p>3. The experimental evidence suggests that transitivity almost always occurs if we pick purely random sequences from <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" />. Can we prove this rigorously? (I think I basically have a proof of this, by showing that whether or not <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> almost always depends on whether <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> has a bigger sum than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" />. I&#8217;ll try to find time reasonably soon to add this to the draft.)</p>\n<p>Of course, other suggestions for follow-up questions will be very welcome, as will ideas about the first two questions above.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 25 Jul 2017 22:50:25
