2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-21-079_aefbebc6e56fd210.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-27-106_6ec6343638d2e658.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-1%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn47@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-17-964_d320debba48ff241.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5E%7B-3%2F2%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn40@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-17-111_f8772c243b9890a1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7CU%5C%7C_%5Cinfty&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn54@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-28-213_8535d866657f3b10.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac%7B%5Cpartial%5E%7Br%2Bs%7D%7D%7B%5Cpartial%5Er%5Calpha%5Cpartial%5Es%5Cbeta%7D%5Cmathbb+E+e%28%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V%29%3D%282%5Cpi+i%29%5E%7Br%2Bs%7D%5Cmathbb+E+U%5ErV%5Es+e%28%5Calpha+U%2B%5Cbeta+V%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn88@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-16-152_9dff41500d3ee94c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Calpha%3D%5Cbeta%3D0&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn55@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-22-321_f6e5607e472bd2a9.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmathbb+E+U%5ErV%5Es&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn57@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-29-998_0cbce62137b9dcdd.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%3D1-2%5Cpi%5E2%28%5Calpha%5E2%5Cmathbb+EU%5E2%2B2%5Calpha%5Cbeta%5Cmathbb+EUV%2B%5Cbeta%5E2%5Cmathbb+EV%5E2%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn8@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-25-363_3beb0656b4b84e45.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=R%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn24@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-21-036_1a3ae29357b9187b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%7C%5Calpha%7C%5C%7CU%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%2B%7C%5Cbeta%7C%5C%7CV%5C%7C_%5Cinfty%29%5E3&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn80@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-25-719_3636a5a123617cfa.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn43@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-17-945_825ebd3f6ba46263.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5Cpi%5E2%28%5Calpha%5E2%5Cmathbb+EU%5E2%2B2%5Calpha%5Cbeta%5Cmathbb+EUV%2B%5Cbeta%5E2%5Cmathbb+EV%5E2%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn40@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-21-111_4eeea56f20bbb124.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn83@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-25-754_96cbe7cc26534cc1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Chat+f%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%5En&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn22@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-31-532_a871bf04ba018335.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%5E2&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn96@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-25-269_80c6ec2314b64a1c.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281-Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%29%5En&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn95@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-27-243_a00c5c31f233c8a8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cexp%28-Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn84@2020_5/2020/08/24/23-28-24-471_c6a24ae9b7d10c2e.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Csum_iU_i%2C%5Csum_iV_i%29%3D%28x%2Cy%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn61@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-32-451_1d5dd180544a7ed4.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=G%28x%2Cy%29%3D%5Cint%5Cexp%28-Q%28%5Calpha%2C%5Cbeta%29%29e%28-%5Calpha+x-%5Cbeta+y%29%5Cmathop%7Bd%5Calpha%7D%5Cmathop%7Bd%5Cbeta%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn48@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-20-147_2b1744b1f4cee7a8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cfrac+14%2Bo%281%29&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn10@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-30-779_2216eef6be82cc17.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694456},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Has an uncomfortable truth been suppressed?","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6390","description":"<p><strong>Update to post, added 11th September.</strong> As expected, there is another side to the story discussed below. See <a href=\"https://math.uchicago.edu/~wilkinso/Statement.html\">this statement about the decision by the Mathematical Intelligencer</a> and <a href=\"https://www.math.uchicago.edu/~farb/statement\">this one about the decision taken by the New York Journal of Mathematics</a>.</p>\n<p><strong>Further update, added 15th September.</strong> <a href=\"http://www.tphill.net/DOCUMENTS/Hill_Statement.html\">The author has also made a statement.</a></p>\n<hr>\n<p>I was disturbed recently by reading about an incident in which a paper was accepted by the Mathematical Intelligencer and then rejected, after which it was accepted and published online by the New York Journal of Mathematics, where it lasted for three days before disappearing and being replaced by another paper of the same length. The reason for this bizarre sequence of events? The paper concerned the &#8220;variability hypothesis&#8221;, the idea, apparently backed up by a lot of evidence, that there is a strong tendency for traits that can be measured on a numerical scale to show more variability amongst males than amongst females. I do not know anything about the quality of this evidence, other than that there are many papers that claim to observe greater variation amongst males of one trait or another, so that if you want to make a claim along the lines of &#8220;you typically see more males both at the top and the bottom of the scale&#8221; then you can back it up with a long list of citations. </p>\n<p>You can see, or probably already know, where this is going: some people like to claim that the reason that women are underrepresented at the top of many fields is simply that the top (and bottom) people, for biological reasons, tend to be male. There is a whole narrative, much loved by many on the political right, that says that this is an uncomfortable truth that liberals find so difficult to accept that they will do anything to suppress it. There is also a counter-narrative that says that people on the far right keep on trying to push discredited claims about the genetic basis for intelligence, differences amongst various groups, and so on, in order to claim that disadvantaged groups are innately disadvantaged rather than disadvantaged by external circumstances.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6390\"></span></p>\n<p>I myself, as will be obvious, incline towards the liberal side, but I also care about scientific integrity, so I felt I couldn&#8217;t just assume that the paper in question had been rightly suppressed. I read <a href=\"https://quillette.com/2018/09/07/academic-activists-send-a-published-paper-down-the-memory-hole/\">an article by the author</a> that described the whole story (in Quillette, which rather specializes in this kind of story), and it sounded rather shocking, though one has to bear in mind that since the article is written by a disgruntled author, there is almost certainly another side to the story. In particular, he is at pains to stress that the paper is simply a mathematical theory to explain why one sex might evolve to become more variable than another, and not a claim that the theory applies to any given species or trait. In his words, &#8220;Darwin had also raised the question of why males in many species might have evolved to be more variable than females, and when I learned that the answer to his question remained elusive, I set out to look for a scientific explanation. My aim was not to prove or disprove that the hypothesis applies to human intelligence or to any other specific traits or species, but simply to discover a logical reason that could help explain how gender differences in variability might naturally arise in the same species.&#8221;</p>\n<p>So as I understood the situation, the paper made no claims whatsoever about the real world, but simply defined a mathematical model and proved that <em>in this model</em> there would be a tendency for greater variability to evolve in one sex. Suppressing such a paper appeared to make no sense at all, since one could always question whether the model was realistic. Furthermore, suppressing papers on this kind of topic simply plays into the hands of those who claim that liberals are against free speech, that science is not after all objective, and so on, claims that are widely believed and do a lot of damage. </p>\n<p>I was therefore prompted to look at <a href=\"https://arxiv.org/pdf/1703.04184.pdf\">the paper itself</a>, which is on the arXiv, and there I was met by a surprise. I was worried that I would find it convincing, but in fact I found it so unconvincing that I think it was a bad mistake by Mathematical Intelligencer and the New York Journal of Mathematics to accept it, but for reasons of mathematical quality rather than for any controversy that might arise from it. To put that point more directly, if somebody came up with a plausible model (I don&#8217;t insist that it should be clearly correct) and showed that subject to certain assumptions about males and females one would expect greater variability to evolve amongst males, then that might well be interesting enough to publish, and certainly shouldn&#8217;t be suppressed just because it might be uncomfortable, though for all sorts of reasons that I&#8217;ll discuss briefly later, I don&#8217;t think it would be as uncomfortable as all that. But this paper appears to me to fall well short of that standard.</p>\n<p>To justify this view, let me try to describe what the paper does. Its argument can be summarized as follows.</p>\n<p>1. Because in many species females have to spend a lot more time nurturing their offspring than males, they have more reason to be very careful when choosing a mate, since a bad choice will have more significant consequences.</p>\n<p>2. If one sex is more selective than the other, then the less selective sex will tend to become more variable.</p>\n<p>To make that work, one must of course define some kind of probabilistic model in which the words &#8220;selective&#8221; and &#8220;variable&#8221; have precise mathematical definitions. What might one expect these to be? If I hadn&#8217;t looked at the paper, I think I&#8217;d have gone for something like this. An individual <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> of one sex will try to choose as desirable a mate <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> as possible amongst potential mates that would be ready to accept <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> as a mate. To be more selective would simply mean to make more of an effort to optimize the mate, which one would model in some suitable probabilistic way. One feature of this model would presumably be that a less attractive individual would typically be able to attract less desirable mates.</p>\n<p>I won&#8217;t discuss how variability is defined, except to say that the definition is, as far as I can see, reasonable. (For normal distributions it agrees with standard deviation.) </p>\n<p>The definition of selectivity in the paper is extremely crude. The model is that individuals of one sex will mate with individuals of the other sex if and only if they are above a certain percentile in the desirability scale, a percentile that is the same for everybody. For instance, they might only be prepared to choose a mate who is in the top quarter, or the top two thirds. The higher the percentile they insist on, the more selective that sex is.</p>\n<p>When applied to humans, this model is ludicrously implausible. While it is true that some males have trouble finding a mate, the idea that some huge percentage of males are simply not desirable enough (as we shall see, the paper requires this percentage to be over 50) to have a chance of reproducing bears no relation to the world as we know it.</p>\n<p>I suppose it is just about possible that an assumption like this could be true of some species, or even of our cave-dwelling ancestors &#8212; perhaps men were prepared to shag pretty well anybody, but only some small percentage of particularly hunky men got their way with women &#8212; but that isn&#8217;t the end of what I find dubious about the paper. And even if we were to accept that something like that had been the case, it would be a huge further leap to assume that what made somebody desirable hundreds of thousands of years ago was significantly related to what makes somebody good at, say, mathematical research today.</p>\n<p>Here is one of the main theorems of the paper, with a sketch of the proof. Suppose you have two subpopulations <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" /> within one of the two sexes, with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> being of more varied attractiveness than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />. And suppose that the selectivity cutoff for the other sex is that you have to be in the top 40 percent attractiveness-wise. Then because <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> is more concentrated on the extremes than <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" />, a higher proportion of subpopulation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> will be in that percentile. (This can easily be made rigorous using the notion of variability in the paper.) By contrast, if the selectivity cutoff is that you have to be in the top 60 percent, then a higher proportion of subpopulation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" /> will be chosen.</p>\n<p>I think we are supposed to conclude that subpopulation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> is therefore favoured over subpopulation <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Q\" title=\"Q\" class=\"latex\" /> when the other sex is selective, and not otherwise, and therefore that variability amongst males tends to be selected for, because females tend to be more choosy about their mates. </p>\n<p>But there is something very odd about this. Those poor individuals at the bottom of population <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> aren&#8217;t going to reproduce, so won&#8217;t they die out and potentially cause population <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> to become <em>less</em> variable? Here&#8217;s what the paper has to say.</p>\n<blockquote><p>Thus, in this discrete-time setting, if one sex remains selective from each generation to the next, for example, then in each successive generation more variable subpopulations of the opposite sex will prevail over less variable subpopulations with comparable average desirability. Although the desirability distributions themselves may evolve, if greater variability prevails at each step, that suggests that over time the opposite sex will tend toward greater variability.</p></blockquote>\n<p>Well I&#8217;m afraid that to me it doesn&#8217;t suggest anything of the kind. If females have a higher cutoff than males, wouldn&#8217;t that suggest that males would have a much higher selection pressure to become more desirable than females? And wouldn&#8217;t the loss of all those undesirable males mean that there wasn&#8217;t much one could say about variability? Imagine for example if the individuals in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> were all either extremely fit or extremely unfit. Surely the variability would go right down if only the fit individuals got to reproduce. And if you&#8217;re worrying that the model would in fact show that males would tend to become far superior to females, as opposed to the usual claim that males are more spread out both at the top and at the bottom, let&#8217;s remember that males inherit traits from both their fathers and their mothers, as do females, an observation that, surprisingly, plays no role at all in the paper.</p>\n<p>What is the purpose of the strange idea of splitting into two subpopulations and then ignoring the fact that the distributions may evolve (and why just &#8220;may&#8221; &#8212; surely &#8220;will&#8221; would be more appropriate)? Perhaps the idea is that a typical gene (or combination of genes) gives rise not to qualities such as strength or intelligence, but to more obscure features that express themselves unpredictably &#8212; they don&#8217;t necessarily make you stronger, for instance, but they give you a bigger range of strength possibilities. But is there the slightest evidence for such a hypothesis? If not, then why not just consider the population as a whole? My guess is that you just don&#8217;t get the desired conclusion if you do that.</p>\n<p>I admit that I have not spent as long thinking about the paper as I would need to in order to be 100% confident of my criticisms. I am also far from expert in evolutionary biology and may therefore have committed some rookie errors in what I have written above. So I&#8217;m prepared to change my mind if somebody (perhaps the author?) can explain why the criticisms are invalid. But as it looks to me at the time of writing, the paper isn&#8217;t a convincing model, and even if one accepts the model, the conclusion drawn from the main theorem is not properly established. Apparently the paper had a very positive referee&#8217;s report. The only explanation I can think of for that is that it was written by somebody who worked in evolutionary biology, didn&#8217;t really understand mathematics, and was simply pleased to have what looked like a rigorous mathematical backing for their theories. But that is pure speculation on my part and could be wrong.</p>\n<p>I said earlier that I don&#8217;t think one should be so afraid of the genetic variability hypothesis that one feels obliged to dismiss all the literature that claims to have observed greater variability amongst males. For all I know it is seriously flawed, but I don&#8217;t want to have to rely on that in order to cling desperately to my liberal values.</p>\n<p>So let&#8217;s just suppose that it really is the case that amongst a large number of important traits, males and females have similar averages but males appear more at the extremes of the distribution. Would that help to explain the fact that, for example, the proportion of women decreases as one moves up the university hierarchy in mathematics, as Larry Summers once caused huge controversy by suggesting? (It&#8217;s worth looking him up on Wikipedia to read his exact words, which are more tentative than I had realized.) </p>\n<p>The theory might appear to fit the facts quite well: if men and women are both normally distributed with the same mean but men have a greater variance than women, then a randomly selected individual from the top <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> percent of the population will be more and more likely to be male the smaller <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> gets. That&#8217;s just simple mathematics.</p>\n<p>But it is nothing like enough reason to declare the theory correct. For one thing, it is just as easy to come up with an environmental theory that would make a similar prediction. Let us suppose that the way society is organized makes it harder for women to become successful mathematicians than for men. There are all sorts of reasons to believe that this is the case: relative lack of role models, an expectation that mathematics is a masculine pursuit, more disruption from family life (on average), distressing behaviour by certain male colleagues, and so on. Let&#8217;s suppose that the result of all these factors is that the distribution of whatever it takes for women to make a success of mathematics has a slightly lower mean than that for men, but roughly the same variance, with both distributions normal. Then again one finds by very basic mathematics that if one picks a random individual from the top <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> percent, that individual will be more and more likely to be male as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> gets smaller. But in this case, instead of throwing up our hands and saying that we can&#8217;t fight against biology, we will say that we should do everything we can to compensate for and eventually get rid of the disadvantages experienced by women. </p>\n<p>A second reason to be sceptical of the theory is that it depends on the idea that how good one is at mathematics is a question of raw brainpower. But that is a damaging myth that puts many people off doing mathematics who could have enjoyed it and thrived at it. I have often come across students who astound me with their ability to solve problems far more quickly than I can, (not all of them male). Some of them go on to be extremely successful mathematicians, but not all. And some who seem quite ordinary go on to do extraordinary things later on. It is clear that while an unusual level of raw brainpower, whatever that might be, often helps, it is far from necessary and far from sufficient for becoming a successful mathematician: it is part of a mix that includes dedication, hard work, enthusiasm, and often a big slice of luck. And as one gains in experience, one gains in brainpower &#8212; not raw any more, but who cares whether it is hardware or software? So <em>even if</em> it turned out that the genetic variability hypothesis was correct and could be applied to something called raw mathematical brainpower, a conclusion that would be very hard to establish convincingly (it&#8217;s certainly not enough to point out that males find it easier to visualize rotating 3D objects in their heads), that <em>still</em> wouldn&#8217;t imply that it is pointless to try to correct the underrepresentation of women amongst the higher ranks of mathematicians. When I was a child, almost all doctors and lawyers were men, and during my lifetime I have seen that change completely. The gender imbalance amongst mathematicians has changed more slowly, but there is no reason in principle that the pace couldn&#8217;t pick up substantially. I hope to live to see that happen.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 09 Sep 2018 21:25:58 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"d68206c847f4507916f5d85faa6b5a48","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-709_4d3c0474cfeb94c8.webp","destWidth":12,"destHeight":11,"sourceBytes":178,"destBytes":172,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn74@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-709_4d3c0474cfeb94c8.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-23-346_ea1814038d50c869.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn95@2020_1/2020/08/24/23-28-14-714_d818176f450d5f05.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Q&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn83@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-25-754_96cbe7cc26534cc1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-22-844_26bd04ed9e0cc047.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694448},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Taylor and Francis doing Trumpâ€™s dirty work for him","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6430","description":"<p>The following story arrived in my email inbox (and those of many others) this morning. Apparently a paper was submitted to the Taylor and Francis journal <em>Dynamical Systems</em>, and was accepted. The published version was prepared, and it had got to the stage where a DOI had been assigned. Then the authorS received a letter explaining that &#8220;following internal sanctions process checks&#8221; the article could not after all be published because one of them was based in Iran.</p>\n<p>I don&#8217;t know what the legal consequences would have been if Taylor and Francis had simply gone ahead and published, but my hunch is that they are being unduly cautious. I wonder if they turned down any papers by Russian authors after the invasion of Ukraine.</p>\n<p>This is not an isolated incident. An Iranian PhD student who applied for funding to go to a mathematics conference in Rome was told that &#8220;we are unable to provide financial support for Iranians due to administrative difficulties&#8221;. </p>\n<p>I&#8217;m not sure what one can do about this, but at the very least it should be generally known that it is happening.</p>\n<p><strong>Update.</strong> <a href=\"https://gowers.wordpress.com/2018/12/09/taylor-and-francis-doing-trumps-dirty-work-for-him/#comment-372824\">Taylor and Francis have now reversed their decision</a>. </p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 09 Dec 2018 12:59:36 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"","linkMd5":"245bb54369ad3e402585db614b8e1c24","bgimgJsdelivr":"","metaImg":"","author":"gowers","publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694447},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Timothy Chow starts Polymath12","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6221","description":"<p>This is a quick post to draw attention to the fact that a new and very interesting looking polymath project has just started, led by Timothy Chow. He is running it <a href=\"https://polymathprojects.org/2017/02/23/rotas-basis-conjecture-polymath-12/\">over at the Polymath blog</a>.</p>\n<p>The problem it will tackle is Rota&#8217;s basis conjecture, which is the following statement.</p>\n<p><strong>Conjecture.</strong> <em>For each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" /> let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B_i%3D%5C%7Be_%7Bi1%7D%2C%5Cdots%2Ce_%7Bin%7D%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B_i=&#92;{e_{i1},&#92;dots,e_{in}&#92;}\" title=\"B_i=&#92;{e_{i1},&#92;dots,e_{in}&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" /> be a basis of an <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-dimensional vector space <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"V\" title=\"V\" class=\"latex\" />. Then there are <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" /> disjoint bases of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=V&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"V\" title=\"V\" class=\"latex\" />, each containing one element from each <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B_i\" title=\"B_i\" class=\"latex\" />.</em></p>\n<p>Equivalently, if you have an <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5Ctimes+n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n&#92;times n\" title=\"n&#92;times n\" class=\"latex\" /> matrix where each row is a basis, then you can permute the entries of the rows so that each column is also a basis.</p>\n<p>This is one of those annoying problems that comes into the how-can-that-not-be-known category. Timothy Chow has a lot of interesting thoughts to get the project going, as well as explanations of why he thinks the time might be ripe for a solution.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 24 Feb 2017 16:40:19 +0000","feedId":7349,"bgimg":"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0","linkMd5":"01109e6538ffad5edc01628fca9df9e1","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn83@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-14-627_27aecac1d4d41bc2.webp","destWidth":5,"destHeight":12,"sourceBytes":154,"destBytes":146,"author":"gowers","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn83@2020_2/2020/08/24/23-28-14-627_27aecac1d4d41bc2.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B_i%3D%5C%7Be_%7Bi1%7D%2C%5Cdots%2Ce_%7Bin%7D%5C%7D&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn37@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-27-469_487f8256357a6217.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-14-638_6fa9c82685967b3b.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=V&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn23@2020_3/2020/08/24/23-28-22-147_6a40f8115db817f1.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B_i&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn61@2020_4/2020/08/24/23-28-29-586_783ba94eb5973018.webp","https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%5Ctimes+n&bg=ffffff&fg=333333&s=0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn87@2020_6/2020/08/24/23-28-21-928_5ac27f38c36acbef.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598311694453},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 07:28:14","title":"Intransitive dice III","link":"http://gowers.wordpress.com/?p=6251","description":"<p>I now feel more optimistic about the prospects for this project. I don&#8217;t know whether we&#8217;ll solve the problem, but I think there&#8217;s a chance. But it seems that there is after all enough appetite to make it an &#8220;official&#8221; Polymath project. Perhaps we could also have an understanding that the pace of the project will be a little slower than it has been for most other projects. I myself have various other mathematical projects on the boil, so can&#8217;t spend too much time on this one, but quite like the idea of giving it an occasional go when the mood takes me, and trying to make slow but steady progress. So I&#8217;ve created a polymath13 category, into which this post now fits. I&#8217;ve also retrospectively changed the category for the previous two posts. I don&#8217;t think we&#8217;ve got to the stage where a wiki will be particularly useful, but I don&#8217;t rule that out at some point in the future. </p>\n<p>In this post I want to expand on part of the previous one, to try to understand better what would need to be true for the quasirandomness assertion to be true. I&#8217;ll repeat a few simple definitions and simple facts needed to make the post more self-contained.<br />\n<span id=\"more-6251\"></span></p>\n<p>By an <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />&#8211;<em>sided</em> die I mean a sequence in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" /> (where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]\" title=\"[n]\" class=\"latex\" /> is shorthand for <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7B1%2C2%2C%5Cdots%2Cn%5C%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" title=\"&#92;{1,2,&#92;dots,n&#92;}\" class=\"latex\" />) that adds up to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n(n+1)/2\" title=\"n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" />. Given an <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided die <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A%3D%28a_1%2C%5Cdots%2Ca_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" title=\"A=(a_1,&#92;dots,a_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=j%5Cin%5Bn%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"j&#92;in[n]\" title=\"j&#92;in[n]\" class=\"latex\" />, I define <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)\" title=\"g_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be the number of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"i\" title=\"i\" class=\"latex\" /> such that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i%5Cleq+j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i&#92;leq j\" title=\"a_i&#92;leq j\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)\" title=\"h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> to be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=g_A%28j%29-j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"g_A(j)-j\" title=\"g_A(j)-j\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>We can write <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(j)\" title=\"h_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_i%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%5Cleq+j%5D%7D-j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq j]}-j\" title=\"&#92;sum_i&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq j]}-j\" class=\"latex\" />. Therefore, if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%3D%28c_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cc_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C=(c_1,&#92;dots,c_n)\" title=\"C=(c_1,&#92;dots,c_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> is another die, or even just an arbitrary sequence in <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Bn%5D%5En&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[n]^n\" title=\"[n]^n\" class=\"latex\" />, we have that<br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jh_A%28c_j%29%3D%5Csum_j%28%5Csum_i%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%5Cleq+c_j%5D%7D-c_j%29%3D%5Csum_%7Bi%2Cj%7D%5Cmathbf+1_%7B%5Ba_i%5Cleq+c_j%5D%7D+-+%5Csum_jc_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(c_j)=&#92;sum_j(&#92;sum_i&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq c_j]}-c_j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq c_j]} - &#92;sum_jc_j\" title=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(c_j)=&#92;sum_j(&#92;sum_i&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq c_j]}-c_j)=&#92;sum_{i,j}&#92;mathbf 1_{[a_i&#92;leq c_j]} - &#92;sum_jc_j\" class=\"latex\" />.<br />\nIf <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jc_j%3Dn%28n%2B1%29%2F2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jc_j=n(n+1)/2\" title=\"&#92;sum_jc_j=n(n+1)/2\" class=\"latex\" /> and no <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=a_i&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"a_i\" title=\"a_i\" class=\"latex\" /> is equal to any <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_j\" title=\"c_j\" class=\"latex\" />, then the sign of this sum therefore tells us whether <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> beats <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" />. For most <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" />, we don&#8217;t expect many ties, so the sign of the sum is a reasonable, but not perfect, proxy for which of the two dice wins. (With a slightly more complicated function we can avoid the problem of ties: I shall stick with the simpler one for ease of exposition, but would expect that if proofs could be got to work, then we would switch to the more complicated functions.) </p>\n<p>This motivates the following question. Let <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> be two random dice. Is it the case that with high probability the remaining dice <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C\" title=\"C\" class=\"latex\" /> are split into four sets of roughly equal size according to the signs of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A%28C%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A(C)\" title=\"h_A(C)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_B%28C%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_B(C)\" title=\"h_B(C)\" class=\"latex\" />? I expect the answer to this question to be the same as the answer to the original transitivity question, but I haven&#8217;t checked as carefully as I should that my cavalier approach to ties isn&#8217;t problematic.</p>\n<p>I propose the following way of tackling this question. We fix <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> and then choose a purely random sequence <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=C%3D%28c_1%2C%5Cdots%2Cc_n%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"C=(c_1,&#92;dots,c_n)\" title=\"C=(c_1,&#92;dots,c_n)\" class=\"latex\" /> (that is, with no constraint on the sum) and look at the 3D random variable<br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28%5Csum_jh_A%28c_j%29%2C%5Csum_jh_B%28c_j%29%2C%5Csum_j%28c_j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(&#92;sum_jh_A(c_j),&#92;sum_jh_B(c_j),&#92;sum_j(c_j-(n+1)/2))\" title=\"(&#92;sum_jh_A(c_j),&#92;sum_jh_B(c_j),&#92;sum_j(c_j-(n+1)/2))\" class=\"latex\" />.<br />\nEach coordinate separately is a sum of independent random variables with mean zero, so provided not too many of the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_A\" title=\"h_A\" class=\"latex\" /> or <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=h_B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"h_B\" title=\"h_B\" class=\"latex\" /> are zero, which for random <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=A&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"A\" title=\"A\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=B&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"B\" title=\"B\" class=\"latex\" /> is a reasonable assumption, we should get something that approximates a trivariate normal distribution.</p>\n<p>Therefore, we should expect that when we condition on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_j%28c_j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_j(c_j-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"&#92;sum_j(c_j-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" /> being zero, we will get something that approximates a bivariate normal distribution. Although that may not be completely straightforward to prove rigorously, tools such as the Berry-Esseen theorem ought to be helpful, and I&#8217;d be surprised if this was impossibly hard. But for now I&#8217;m aiming at a heuristic argument, so I want simply to assume it.</p>\n<p>What we want is for the signs of the first two coordinates to be approximately independent, which I think is equivalent to saying (assuming normality) that the first two coordinates themselves are approximately independent.</p>\n<p>However, what makes the question interesting is that the first two coordinates are definitely <em>not</em> independent without the conditioning: the random variables <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jh_A%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jh_A(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_jh_B%28c_j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_jh_B(c_j)\" title=\"&#92;sum_jh_B(c_j)\" class=\"latex\" /> are typically quite strongly correlated. (There are good reasons to expect this to be the case, and I&#8217;ve tested it computationally too.) Also, we expect correlations between these variables and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Csum_j%28c_j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;sum_j(c_j-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"&#92;sum_j(c_j-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" />. So what we are asking for is that all these correlations should disappear when we condition appropriately. More geometrically, there is a certain ellipsoid, and we want its intersection with a certain plane to be a circle.</p>\n<p>The main aim of this post is to make the last paragraph more precise. That is, I want to take three standard normal random variables <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X%2C+Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X, Y\" title=\"X, Y\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Z\" title=\"Z\" class=\"latex\" /> that are not independent, and understand precisely the circumstances that guarantee that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" /> become independent when we condition on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Z\" title=\"Z\" class=\"latex\" />. </p>\n<p>The joint distribution of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%2CZ%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y,Z)\" title=\"(X,Y,Z)\" class=\"latex\" /> is determined by the matrix of correlations. Let this matrix be split up as <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbegin%7Bpmatrix%7D%5CSigma_%7B11%7D%26%5CSigma_%7B12%7D%5C%5C+%5CSigma_%7B21%7D%26%5CSigma_%7B22%7D%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bpmatrix%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}&#92;Sigma_{11}&#38;&#92;Sigma_{12}&#92;&#92; &#92;Sigma_{21}&#38;&#92;Sigma_{22}&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" title=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}&#92;Sigma_{11}&#38;&#92;Sigma_{12}&#92;&#92; &#92;Sigma_{21}&#38;&#92;Sigma_{22}&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" class=\"latex\" />, where <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CSigma_%7B11%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;Sigma_{11}\" title=\"&#92;Sigma_{11}\" class=\"latex\" /> is the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5Ctimes+2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"2&#92;times 2\" title=\"2&#92;times 2\" class=\"latex\" /> covariance matrix of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CSigma_%7B12%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;Sigma_{12}\" title=\"&#92;Sigma_{12}\" class=\"latex\" /> is a <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=2%5Ctimes+1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"2&#92;times 1\" title=\"2&#92;times 1\" class=\"latex\" /> matrix, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CSigma_%7B21%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;Sigma_{21}\" title=\"&#92;Sigma_{21}\" class=\"latex\" /> is a <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=1%5Ctimes+2&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"1&#92;times 2\" title=\"1&#92;times 2\" class=\"latex\" /> matrix and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CSigma_%7B22%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;Sigma_{22}\" title=\"&#92;Sigma_{22}\" class=\"latex\" /> is the matrix <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%281%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(1)\" title=\"(1)\" class=\"latex\" />. A general result about conditioning joint normal distributions on a subset of the variables tells us, if I understand the result correctly, that the covariance matrix of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> when we condition on the value of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Z\" title=\"Z\" class=\"latex\" /> is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5CSigma_%7B11%7D-%5CSigma_%7B12%7D%5CSigma_%7B22%7D%5E%7B-1%7D%5CSigma_%7B21%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;Sigma_{11}-&#92;Sigma_{12}&#92;Sigma_{22}^{-1}&#92;Sigma_{21}\" title=\"&#92;Sigma_{11}-&#92;Sigma_{12}&#92;Sigma_{22}^{-1}&#92;Sigma_{21}\" class=\"latex\" />. (I got this <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multivariate_normal_distribution#Conditional_distributions\">from Wikipedia</a>. It seems to be quite tricky to prove, so I hope it really can be used as a black box.) So in our case if we have a covariance matrix <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbegin%7Bpmatrix%7D1%26%5Clambda%26%5Cmu%5C%5C+%5Clambda%261%26%5Cnu%5C%5C+%5Cmu%26%5Cnu%261%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bpmatrix%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}1&#38;&#92;lambda&#38;&#92;mu&#92;&#92; &#92;lambda&#38;1&#38;&#92;nu&#92;&#92; &#92;mu&#38;&#92;nu&#38;1&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" title=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}1&#38;&#92;lambda&#38;&#92;mu&#92;&#92; &#92;lambda&#38;1&#38;&#92;nu&#92;&#92; &#92;mu&#38;&#92;nu&#38;1&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" class=\"latex\" /> then the covariance matrix of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" /> conditioned on <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Z\" title=\"Z\" class=\"latex\" /> should be <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbegin%7Bpmatrix%7D1-%5Cmu%5E2%26%5Clambda-%5Cmu%5Cnu%5C%5C+%5Clambda-%5Cmu%5Cnu%261-%5Cnu%5E2%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bpmatrix%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}1-&#92;mu^2&#38;&#92;lambda-&#92;mu&#92;nu&#92;&#92; &#92;lambda-&#92;mu&#92;nu&#38;1-&#92;nu^2&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" title=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}1-&#92;mu^2&#38;&#92;lambda-&#92;mu&#92;nu&#92;&#92; &#92;lambda-&#92;mu&#92;nu&#38;1-&#92;nu^2&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>That looks dimensionally odd because I normalized the random variables to have variance 1. If instead I had started with the more general covariance matrix <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbegin%7Bpmatrix%7Da%26%5Clambda%26%5Cmu%5C%5C+%5Clambda%26b%26%5Cnu%5C%5C+%5Cmu%26%5Cnu%26c%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bpmatrix%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}a&#38;&#92;lambda&#38;&#92;mu&#92;&#92; &#92;lambda&#38;b&#38;&#92;nu&#92;&#92; &#92;mu&#38;&#92;nu&#38;c&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" title=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}a&#38;&#92;lambda&#38;&#92;mu&#92;&#92; &#92;lambda&#38;b&#38;&#92;nu&#92;&#92; &#92;mu&#38;&#92;nu&#38;c&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" class=\"latex\" /> I would have ended up with <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cbegin%7Bpmatrix%7Da-c%5E%7B-1%7D%5Cmu%5E2%26%5Clambda-c%5E%7B-1%7D%5Cmu%5Cnu%5C%5C+%5Clambda-c%5E%7B-1%7D%5Cmu%5Cnu%26b-c%5E%7B-1%7D%5Cnu%5E2%5C%5C+%5Cend%7Bpmatrix%7D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}a-c^{-1}&#92;mu^2&#38;&#92;lambda-c^{-1}&#92;mu&#92;nu&#92;&#92; &#92;lambda-c^{-1}&#92;mu&#92;nu&#38;b-c^{-1}&#92;nu^2&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" title=\"&#92;begin{pmatrix}a-c^{-1}&#92;mu^2&#38;&#92;lambda-c^{-1}&#92;mu&#92;nu&#92;&#92; &#92;lambda-c^{-1}&#92;mu&#92;nu&#38;b-c^{-1}&#92;nu^2&#92;&#92; &#92;end{pmatrix}\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>So after the conditioning, if we want <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" /> to become independent, we appear to want <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clambda+c&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;lambda c\" title=\"&#92;lambda c\" class=\"latex\" /> to equal <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Cmu%5Cnu&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;mu&#92;nu\" title=\"&#92;mu&#92;nu\" class=\"latex\" />. That is, we want<br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+X%2CZ%5Crangle%5Clangle+Y%2CZ%5Crangle%3D%5Clangle+X%2CY%5Crangle%5Clangle+Z%2CZ%5Crangle&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle X,Z&#92;rangle&#92;langle Y,Z&#92;rangle=&#92;langle X,Y&#92;rangle&#92;langle Z,Z&#92;rangle\" title=\"&#92;langle X,Z&#92;rangle&#92;langle Y,Z&#92;rangle=&#92;langle X,Y&#92;rangle&#92;langle Z,Z&#92;rangle\" class=\"latex\" /><br />\nwhere I am using angle brackets for covariances.</p>\n<p>If we divide each variable by its standard deviation, that gives us that the correlation between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" /> should be the product of the correlation between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X\" title=\"X\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Z\" title=\"Z\" class=\"latex\" /> and the correlation between <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y\" title=\"Y\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Z\" title=\"Z\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>I wrote some code to test this, and it seemed not to be the case, anything like, but I am not confident that I didn&#8217;t make careless mistakes in the code. (However, my correlations were reasonable numbers in the range <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5B-1%2C1%5D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"[-1,1]\" title=\"[-1,1]\" class=\"latex\" />, so any mistakes there might have been didn&#8217;t jump out at me. I might just rewrite the code from scratch without looking at the old version.)</p>\n<p>One final remark I&#8217;d like to make is that if you feel there is something familiar about the expression <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+x%2Cz%5Crangle%5Clangle+y%2Cz%5Crangle-%5Clangle+x%2Cy%5Crangle%5Clangle+z%2Cz%5Crangle&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle&#92;langle y,z&#92;rangle-&#92;langle x,y&#92;rangle&#92;langle z,z&#92;rangle\" title=\"&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle&#92;langle y,z&#92;rangle-&#92;langle x,y&#92;rangle&#92;langle z,z&#92;rangle\" class=\"latex\" />, then you are not completely wrong. The formula for the vector triple product is</p>\n<p><img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x%5Cwedge%28y%5Cwedge+z%29%3D%5Clangle+x%2Cz%5Crangle+y+-+%5Clangle+x%2Cy%5Crangle+z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x&#92;wedge(y&#92;wedge z)=&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle y - &#92;langle x,y&#92;rangle z\" title=\"x&#92;wedge(y&#92;wedge z)=&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle y - &#92;langle x,y&#92;rangle z\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Therefore, the expression can be condensed to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+x%5Cwedge%28y%5Cwedge+z%29%2Cz%5Crangle&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle x&#92;wedge(y&#92;wedge z),z&#92;rangle\" title=\"&#92;langle x&#92;wedge(y&#92;wedge z),z&#92;rangle\" class=\"latex\" />. Now this is the scalar triple product of the three vectors <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5Cwedge+z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y&#92;wedge z\" title=\"y&#92;wedge z\" class=\"latex\" />, and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"z\" title=\"z\" class=\"latex\" />. For this to be zero, we need <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> to lie in the plane generated by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5Cwedge+z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y&#92;wedge z\" title=\"y&#92;wedge z\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"z\" title=\"z\" class=\"latex\" />. Note that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y%5Cwedge+z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y&#92;wedge z\" title=\"y&#92;wedge z\" class=\"latex\" /> is orthogonal to both <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"z\" title=\"z\" class=\"latex\" />. So if <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=P&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"P\" title=\"P\" class=\"latex\" /> is the orthogonal projection to the subspace generated by <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"z\" title=\"z\" class=\"latex\" />, we want <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x-Px&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x-Px\" title=\"x-Px\" class=\"latex\" /> to be orthogonal to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" />. Actually, that can be read out of the original formula too, since it is <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle%5Clangle+x%2Cz%5Crangle+z+-+%5Clangle+z%2Cz%5Crangle+x%2Cy%5Crangle&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle z - &#92;langle z,z&#92;rangle x,y&#92;rangle\" title=\"&#92;langle&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle z - &#92;langle z,z&#92;rangle x,y&#92;rangle\" class=\"latex\" />. A nicer way of thinking of it (because more symmetrical) is that we want the orthogonal projections of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=x&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"x\" title=\"x\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=y&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"y\" title=\"y\" class=\"latex\" /> to the subspace orthogonal to <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=z&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"z\" title=\"z\" class=\"latex\" /> to be orthogonal. To check that, assuming (WLOG) that <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5C%7Cz%5C%7C_2%3D1&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;|z&#92;|_2=1\" title=\"&#92;|z&#92;|_2=1\" class=\"latex\" />,<br />\n<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%5Clangle+x-%5Clangle+x%2Cz%5Crangle+z%2Cy-%5Clangle+y%2Cz%5Crangle+z%5Crangle%3D%5Clangle+x%2Cy%5Crangle-%5Clangle+x%2Cz%5Crangle%5Clangle+y%2Cz%5Crangle&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"&#92;langle x-&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle z,y-&#92;langle y,z&#92;rangle z&#92;rangle=&#92;langle x,y&#92;rangle-&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle&#92;langle y,z&#92;rangle\" title=\"&#92;langle x-&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle z,y-&#92;langle y,z&#92;rangle z&#92;rangle=&#92;langle x,y&#92;rangle-&#92;langle x,z&#92;rangle&#92;langle y,z&#92;rangle\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>So what I&#8217;d like to see done (but I&#8217;m certainly not saying it&#8217;s the only thing worth doing) is the following.</p>\n<p>1. Test experimentally whether for a random pair <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28A%2CB%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(A,B)\" title=\"(A,B)\" class=\"latex\" /> of <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=n&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"n\" title=\"n\" class=\"latex\" />-sided dice we find that the correlations of the random variables <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=X%3D%5Csum_jh_A%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"X=&#92;sum_jh_A(j)\" title=\"X=&#92;sum_jh_A(j)\" class=\"latex\" />, <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Y%3D%5Csum_jh_B%28j%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Y=&#92;sum_jh_B(j)\" title=\"Y=&#92;sum_jh_B(j)\" class=\"latex\" /> and <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=Z%3D%5Csum_j%28c_j-%28n%2B1%29%2F2%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"Z=&#92;sum_j(c_j-(n+1)/2)\" title=\"Z=&#92;sum_j(c_j-(n+1)/2)\" class=\"latex\" /> really do appear to satisfy the relationship </p>\n<p>corr<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CZ%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Z)\" title=\"(X,Z)\" class=\"latex\" />.corr<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28Y%2CZ%29%3D&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(Y,Z)=\" title=\"(Y,Z)=\" class=\"latex\" /> corr<img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=%28X%2CY%29&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"(X,Y)\" title=\"(X,Y)\" class=\"latex\" />.</p>\n<p>Here the <img src=\"https://s0.wp.com/latex.php?latex=c_j&#038;bg=ffffff&#038;fg=333333&#038;s=0\" alt=\"c_j\" title=\"c_j\" class=\"latex\" /> are chosen randomly <em>without</em> any conditioning on their sum. My experiment seemed to indicate not, but I&#8217;m hoping I made a mistake.</p>\n<p>2. If they do satisfy that relationship, then we can start to think about why.</p>\n<p>3. If they do not satisfy it, then we can start to think about why not. In particular, which of the heuristic assumptions used to suggest that they <em>should</em> satisfy that relationship is wrong &#8212; or is it my understanding of multivariate normals that is faulty?</p>\n<p>If we manage to prove that they typically do satisfy that relationship, at least approximately, then we can think about whether various distributions become sufficiently normal sufficiently quickly for that to imply that intransitivity occurs with probability 1/4. </p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 19 May 2017 22:07:47
